PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Discrimination against Women

The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10(c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illness.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Burr,Mr Cadman,Mr Cowan,Mr Fisher,Mr Goodluck,Mr Groom,Mr Hicks,Mr McGauran,Mr Porter,Mr Ruddock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembed, the humble peitition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Dr Theophanous.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2 000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully shows that your petitioners are gravely concerned at hydro-electric or similar development in the South-West Tasmania World Heritage area. This area has been recognised as of National and World importance and therefore is National responsibility.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to ensure all within its power, including the blocking or non-allocation of funds, is done to ensure this area is preserved as wilderness and therefore no road or dam development is allowed. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be required to bear severe financial burden if this occurs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that because television and radio:
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C., and commercial sectors.
Your peititioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commerical broadcasters, to legislate:
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public,
(b) for a ''Dual System of Regulation'' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control.
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Royal Commission on Human Relationships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because the Report of the Royal Commission on Human Relationships and especially its Recommendations-

(a) Have been widely condemned for its support of un-Australian, anti-family, anti-child behaviour and morals such as incest, promiscuity, abortion, pornography, homosexuality, prostitution and brothels, etc. (Note: Refer quotations reverse side)

(b) Have been strongly criticised by the medical profession for the absence of any medical practitioner on the Commission or on its staff of 31 persons, and for the Commissioners action in rejecting or ignoring relevant medical evidence.

(c) Have been discredited as irresponsible in adopting a new definition of the family, i.e., ''a varying range of people living together in relationships of commitment'', which has effectively confused the real meaning and intentions of the Report where it refers to the 'family'.
Therefore the Parliament has a responsibility to the families of Australia not to adopt this controversial Report and its Recommendations.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Australian Parliament will:-
(a) Simply receive the Report and not adopt its Recommendations,

(b) Set up a Select Parliamentary Committee along the lines of the New Zealand Select Committee to conduct a public inquiry into the ways and means of supporting and strengthening family life and providing adequate protection for children from physical and sexual abuse before as well as after birth in accordance with the U.N.O. Declaration of the Rights of the Child as part of Australia's support for the Year of the Child.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will take no measures concerning the Royal Commission on Human Relationships Report that will further undermine and weaken marriage, child-care or the family which is the basic unit of our society.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that:
(1) the high cost of many pharmaceutical items, necessary for the management of diabetes, imposes a heavy financial burden on sufferers of this disease;
(2) while insulin is available on prescription under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, syringes and needles which are the only means of administering insulin, are not.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will extend the provision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to cover syringes and needles required by diabetics.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radford College, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we request that the Government take steps to ensure:
(1) The construction programme of Radford College, Bruce proceeds immediately.
(2) Parents freedom of choice in education is fostered by continuing to provide a basic grant for all Australian children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in Secondary Schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Represenatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay Directory Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respectfully showeth:
That the intention of Telecom Australia to close the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre will:
downgrade telephone services to Mackay and district.
deprive customers of a personalized reliable telephone service.
reduce job opportunities in the area.
increase the likelihood of the eventual closure of the exchange.
We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia has a social responsibility to provide a sound reliable, personalized telephone system.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed closure of the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service for lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans Affairs' pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the Health Care cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the house-bound and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

We the Citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holdens, respectfully show-
1. That the management of General Motors-Holdens has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote-
''The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site'' end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holdens to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The grave concern arising from the Government's handling of matters related to the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Ivanov.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the extraordinary statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday relating to the expulsion of the KGB agent, Mr Valeriy Ivanov, and his association with Mr Combe has led to grave concern because it opens up a number of questions that this Parliament and the nation are entitled to have answered. On 22 April the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) made a statement to the Press that Mr Ivanov had infringed the conventions applying to the proper conduct of diplomats . He said that Mr Ivanov's actions had threatened Australia's national security in a way which could not be tolerated by the Government. The Opposition accepted this statement. It did not question it. It accepted that the Government had available to it information which on its judgment required action, and it acted.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not until last Sunday, 8 May, that the Sunday Telegraph ran an article that an Australian Labor Party member had been implicated with Mr Ivanov. Following that article, newspapers started to run a series of articles building on the assumption that somebody in the Australian Labor Party was involved in this affair. It was not until Australian Associated Press put out a news release reporting on the matters brought before Caucus-that is, that the Prime Minister had made reference to, and had instructed his Ministers not to have any dealings with, Mr Combe-that a question was asked in this House by the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) asking the Prime Minister what were his reasons for that instruction. That brought a response whereby Mr Combe's credibility was put in great doubt. Because of the further stories surrounding the Prime Minister's somewhat inept comments, he felt compelled to make a statement in this House yesterday, trying to justify his actions.

In Parliament yesterday, the Prime Minister made an allegation that is probably the most serious allegation that it is possible to make against a person, short of the outright allegation of treason. The Prime Minister implicated Mr David Combe, the former Federal Secretary of the Labor Party, in an allegation that Mr Combe's relationship with the expelled KGB officer gave rise to 'serious security concern'. The Prime Minister told the Parliament, and the community at large, that, in the view of the Government's National and International Security Sub-committee of Cabinet, Mr Combe either had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Mr Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Government Ministers to deal with him. The Prime Minister went on to say that the relationship that Mr Ivanov had cultivated with Mr Combe was one of the reasons which led to Mr Ivanov's expulsion from Australia a few days ago.

These are extremely grave allegations. They have been made by the Prime Minister in a way which places Mr Combe in an impossible position. In fact, the allegations made by the Prime Minister against Mr Combe represent a massive breach of Mr Combe's civil liberties and rights as a citizen of Australia. The allegations have been made without any substantiation. There is no opportunity, therefore, for Mr Combe to respond to the allegations and to seek to defend himself. There is no opportunity for the community at large to judge for itself the correctness or otherwise of the allegations because no information has been given to support them.

The Prime Minister has alleged that Mr Combe has been compromised to the extent that it is no longer appropriate for Ministers to have a dealing with him. That allegation, of course, has brought vast damage to Mr Combe, even though the allegation, I repeat, is completely unsubstantiated by evidence of any kind. But the matter goes much further than that. What the Prime Minister and the Government are saying in reality is that Mr Combe is a security risk to the extent that he is denied contact with Ministers. But he is allowed to continue contact with public servants, with the business community and with anyone who likes to have a dealing with him. In making the allegation, the Prime Minister has of course cut off Mr Combe from having any contact with virtually anybody. He has destroyed him. Mr Combe's reputation is under the blackest cloud one could imagine. The damage Mr Combe has suffered cannot be redressed-indeed, no attempt can be made to redress it-unless the allegations are substantiated and Mr Combe is given the opportunity to be able to defend himself.

One can only wonder whether the Prime Minister's statement of yesterday was designed to explain what has happened or to hide what has happened. I believe there are very strong grounds for taking the view that the Prime Minister's statement was designed to protect the Labor Party rather than the interests of the community. It certainly was not designed to protect Mr Combe. In fact, one can only wonder whether Mr Combe is not the scapegoat in this affair. The Prime Minister has dealt him an unusually severe blow. It was an extraordinary thing to do to a former colleague.

Quite clearly, the matter cannot be allowed to rest where it is. I am certain that many people within the Labor Party are very unhappy about this situation. Mr Combe has had a long association with the Labor Party. He held a very significant and influential position during the period of the previous Labor Government under Mr Whitlam. Obviously he would have been closely involved with many confidential matters. Mr Combe was also the Federal Secretary of the Labor Party for a number of years while the Prime Minister was the Party's President. One can recall his vigorous defence of Mr Combe when allegations were made about secret discussions to solicit funds from Iraqi officials for the benefit of party operations.

I cannot imagine what prompted the Prime Minister to take such extreme action. It was not done lightly. I am sure it caused him a great deal of anguish to come to these conclusions. The Prime Minister has placed Mr Combe in a position in which no citizen should be allowed to remain. This is not Moscow, Mr Prime Minister. He can blackguard a person if he likes but there are principles and procedures which everybody in this Parliament respects.

Mr Combe has been branded with conduct which gives rise to serious security concern, but he cannot defend himself against that charge. Mr Combe is said to have compromised himself, but he cannot defend that charge. Mr Combe's association with Mr Ivanov has been given by the Prime Minister as one of the reasons for the expulsion, but Mr Combe cannot defend himself against those assertions. The Prime Minister says that Mr Combe understands and accepts why Ministers can no longer have dealings with him. I do not think Mr Combe really had much choice. That was a very generous conclusion to come to. I would be very surprised indeed if Mr Combe did not want the opportunity, publicly and in a proper place, to explain himself and to defend his actions, whatever they are.

I do not know whether Mr Combe has done anything detrimental or potentially detrimental to Australia's security or whether he has acted in ways which could be potentially damaging; no one knows. We have not been told the basis of the Prime Minister's allegations. We have been told that, in the opinion of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and his Department, Mr Combe has committed no criminal offence. We have been told that, in the Government's belief, there is no foundation for any allegation or imputation that Mr Combe is or ever was a Soviet spy. Yet in spite of those assertions the Government has cut off all official contact with Mr Combe, seriously damaging his reputation, and has expelled a Soviet spy as a result of Mr Combe's association with him. If Mr Combe has done anything wrong, and if it is proved that he has done anything wrong, then he should be required to answer for his wrong-doings. If he has not done anything wrong then he should be allowed to show that he has not.

The Prime Minister yesterday said the Government was concerned that Mr Combe should not become the object of public censure without some opportunity to defend himself. Yet that is precisely what has happened as a result of the Prime Minister's unsubstantiated allegations in Parliament. No Australian citizen should be subjected to damaging unsubstantiated allegations no matter what the ground. This is a fundamental principle of human justice. If the Prime Minister is genuinely concerned to give Mr Combe an opportunity to defend himself, and if he is concerned that the community should be able to satisfy itself as to what is the truth of this matter, there is only one course open to the Prime Minister -and that is immediately to establish an appropriate judicial inquiry.

This is an allegation of the utmost seriousness against a private citizen, made in a way which, I repeat, represents a massive breach of that citizen's civil liberties and rights. It demands examination by a judicial inquiry. It also demands an immediate and full explanation by the Government of the circumstances leading up to Mr Ivanov's expulsion. This did not come out in the original statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and it did not come out in the Prime Minister's statement yesterday. The Prime Minister sought to avoid giving an explanation, relying on the convention that security matters should not be discussed. That convention is important, and fully accepted by the Opposition. But on previous occasions-rare though they are-when a diplomat has been expelled , there has been a full statement on the matter. On 7 February 1963 the then Minister for External Affairs and Attorney-General made a full and detailed statement of the reasons for the expulsion of the First Secretary of the Soviet Embassy, Mr Ivan Skripov. Skripov's activities were described in detail to this Parliament. It was appropriate then for a full statement to be made, and it is appropriate now for a similar full statement to be made. It is even more imperative now because in the present case we have the most serious allegations about an Australian citizen.

In summary, Mr Speaker, the situation seems to be that a Soviet agent has been expelled but an Australian citizen has been severely damaged, his credibility has been put at risk, because of the ineptitude of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the Government rejects--
—I take a point of order. Most serious allegations have been made about the Prime Minister. He should be at the table, not hiding behind another Minister.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Speaker, I hope that this debate can be heard in silence. We do not want any of the vaudeville acts of the sort we have just witnessed. Let me make it very clear that this matter of public importance has been raised by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and not by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock).
—Put the Prime Minister up to answer it.

—Just a moment. I ask the honourable member in the name of justice to give me a fair chance for once. Let me make it very clear that, when this matter of national security was brought to the Government's notice, in accordance with the proper principles of bipartisanship the Leader of the Opposition was fully briefed for two hours and given every item of information relating to what has been raised here today. What a hypocritical and miserable action it is to think that the Opposition put up--
—I take a point of order. I would like the Deputy Prime Minister--
—Order! The honourable member will state his point of order.
—The point of order is that the Deputy Prime Minister used the word ' hypocritical'.
—It is a hypocritical action to be fully briefed on a matter and to send somebody else in here today to establish a case--
—Order! I ask the Deputy Prime Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw the word.
—I ask for a withdrawal because of the relevance of a Standing Order, not because the word is considered unparliamentary.

—It is an extraordinary action to send in the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to make a case on behalf of an Australian citizen when the Leader of the Opposition was fully briefed for two hours, expressed himself to be completely satisfied with the action taken and in fact issued a statement in accordance with that position. What is it that we are discussing here today? The matter of public importance suggests that there is some problem concerning the expulsion of Mr Ivanov. Everybody agrees he should have been expelled but, in the process of adding some weight to that debate, we get the suggestion that an injustice has been done to somebody and that his name had been bandied about. Let me go through the points very clearly. There was a two-hour briefing of the Leader of the Opposition. Every aspect of the matter-all of the details-was disclosed. The Leader of the Opposition, whose views we respect, has indicated to us that he also fully briefed the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—He did not.
—No, on the Ivanov matter; it had nothing to do with the other matter , as I told the Prime Minister.
—I want to put on the record, in fairness, that I will accept that position.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members will come to order. The Leader of the National Party was heard with courtesy and the Deputy Prime Minister should also be heard with courtesy.

—I would appreciate the opportunity to make the point-it has been said clearly-that there was a two-hour briefing of the Leader of the Opposition. It is now denied that the Leader of the Opposition indicated that he had fully briefed the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—Not on David Combe; that was expressly understood.

—Well, would the honourable member accept the view that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also saw him after Question Time on 10 May and asked him what was going on because, on that date, the Opposition raised a number of questions, one of which was his own? Would he accept also that, later that evening, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) having gone on Newsvoice and having again raised the matter, the Leader of the Opposition was again asked to see the Prime Minister, which he did, saying that he would adjust the matter by discussing it with the right honourable member for New England and others. I do not know where we are going on this question of bipartisanship if we had two discussions with the Leader of the Opposition and now we are not given any chance to suggest that in fact it happened. Let us come to the nub of the question raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—Order! I remind the Deputy Prime Minister that the honourable member for Richmond is actually the Leader of the National Party. I understand that the honourable member for Bennelong is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—I was referring to the Leader of the National Party. One would have thought that he would have been briefed on the matter. Are we to accept now that he knows nothing about it? Is that the situation; that the Opposition now goes to the extent of bringing forward a matter of public importance, raising all these issues, yet the man they put up to present it had no briefing on the matter? Do honourable members really accept that that is the situation? Is this the ridiculous situation-that the Opposition has allowed an honourable member who has had no briefing on the matter to bring up for discussion this matter of public importance? How dishonest can they be; how ridiculous must the Opposition look in the eyes of the public if a matter of the gravest importance is presented for discussion by a person who has had no briefing on it? Let us come to the question of the sincerity of what the Opposition has done.
—What about the civil liberties of people?
—Then why does the honourable member impugn them? The members of the Opposition are the only people who have dragged in the name of the individual.
—No way! Come on.

—No way? If I may be heard in silence, let me tell honourable members what happened on 10 May. How did the matter arise? What evidence was produced? We find that one of the first questions raised on that day was raised by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) who asked whether it was not a fact that a senior Labor man had been one of the most important figures involved?
—That was reported in the Press.
—Yes, but the matter was raised in the Parliament by the honourable member. His leader had already been fully briefed.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party was heard in silence. The Deputy Prime Minister should be heard in silence also.
—I can appreciate the reason for the interjections, but the matter was first raised by a front bench member of the Opposition.
—It was raised in the Press.

—That the person concerned was a member of the Labor Party was raised here in the Parliament by the Opposition. That was the first question. Soon after that, the next question was raised on the same day by the Leader of the Opposition himself. Of course, he raised it on the basis of what was, he said, a Press report. He said that a former senior Australian Labor Party official was involved. That was the first time that word had been used, and it was raised by the Leader of the Opposition. He, of course, had had a briefing, but he was quoting a Press report. It was never a true Press report because the Prime Minister clearly said that never at any stage did he indicate who the person was or what his former position had been. What was the pattern or the intelligence of the Opposition on that day? Firstly, there was a question about a Labor Party person. The Leader of the Opposition himself quoted a false Australian Associated Press report asking whether a Labor Party official was involved when, of course, he himself knew the position. The Prime Minister denied it and he denied it accurately. Now that Mr Sinclair is trying to interject, let me quote the third question. We must assume, of course, or at least we would have thought, that Mr Sinclair would have been aware of the matter, but what was his question?
—Order! I remind the Deputy Prime Minister of the custom with regard to referring to members by electorates.

—All right, the right honourable member for New England; he is also the Deputy Leader of the National Party. The question of the right honourable member for New England, which was headed Mr David Combe, asks:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Prime Minister instructed the members of his Government to dissociate themselves from . . . , Mr Combe?

Why is it that that trio of questions comprise, firstly, the suggestion that it was a Labor man involved; secondly, the suggestion that it must have been a Labor Party official; and thirdly, the question of whether it was Combe? Today, during debate on the matter of public importance, we heard about the dreadful miscarriage of justice in the bandying around of Combe's name. Who bandied it around? Who did it and for what purpose?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, your Prime Minister.

—The right honourable member for New England was anxious to go on Newsvoice and he mentioned quite actively that afternoon who Combe was, what he had been in the past and what he thought of some of the actions including Iraqi breakfasts. There is no suggestion of Mr Combe's getting fair play on Newsvoice. Surely the Leader of the Opposition will not deny that there was a second conference with him later about what he was going to do about the matter. He said: 'Well, I will go and tell them'. That was about the best he could do at that stage. In other words, he said that he would try to get Opposition members to understand what honourable members would all agree is in the interests of national security. If we were able to disclose to the Opposition all the information, we would expect other members of the Opposition to act in accordance with the code and not in any way infringe it by asking questions in the Parliament or, worse still, coming in here as they did today to make a specious defence of a man, whom they would happily see done away with, on the basis that he has been denied natural justice.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I make the point concerning the statement that was made yesterday by the Prime Minister. He said that Mr Combe had a chance and had availed himself of it with his legal adviser to go through the whole of the evidence available to the Government. Following that discussion, which his lawyer approved, Mr Combe is on record as saying that he understands and accepts the Government's decision that Ministers should not associate with him as a lobbyist. As I said, he had the opportunity to go through the Government's case line by line; he accepted the Prime Minister's statement to the Parliament. What could be fairer than that? We want to make the point, in response to the question of what there was to hide, that there is nothing to hide. All the information was given to the Opposition. The Opposition knew of the information; if it did not, then that is an indictment of the Leader of the Opposition. I think he is more capable than that . But we are not prepared to accept the view put here today by a person who apparently alleges-I suggest he does so somewhat tongue in cheek-that he knew nothing about the matter, that there has been no defence available to Mr Combe and that there has been a cover up, and he wants a judicial inquiry. Surely, if he-the Leader of the National Party-wanted to help Mr Combe, that would be the last thing he would want. Surely that is the position from the Opposition's point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you know?

—I know no more than what your leader knows. Honourable members opposite are urging that something should be done on the basis that it would be able to assist Mr Combe. We are all anxious to assist Mr Combe. Assistance will always be available from the point of view of his lawyer having access to any information he wishes.
—How does he defend himself?

—I do not know how he will defend himself now in the terms of the Opposition's indictment of him. It is honourable members opposite who apparently are deliberately playing this action for their own party political purposes.
—Where are your civil liberties?
—Order! The House will come to order.

—Honourable members opposite feign disdain on the question of civil liberties. They raised the man's name when the Leader of the Opposition was fully aware of the circumstances. It is the Opposition which is asking for information when all information has been provided. Does the Leader of the National Party suggest that the Government acted improperly in expelling Mr Ivanov? He cannot say that. There is no evidence of that at all. The real issue which the Opposition has to face is that because it wants to try to destroy Mr Combe it will use knowledge given to the Leader of the Opposition.
—You have done it.

—We did not raise the matter; the Opposition raised it. The innocence in which this matter is apparently raised is astounding. I make the point that the matter of public importance was raised to discuss a matter of grave concern, the expulsion of Mr Ivanov. I think he got a brief five seconds mention in the speech made by the Leader of the National Party who said that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) had said that Mr Ivanov had to be expelled and made a statement accordingly. The rest of his speech was on the basis that an injustice had been done to Mr Combe. Yet, I repeat that the person who has made the allegations never bothered to ask his own leader what were the facts. The Leader of the Opposition allowed-I must say he virtually connived in what happened-the matter of public importance to be raised today on the basis that the real position was not known about the person mentioned. Again, it goes against all sense of justice in this country to think that, on 10 May, a series of prearranged questions were asked, one of them by the Leader of the Opposition , to guarantee that Combe was named. I think it is dreadful to expect this House or the people of Australia to accept that as an honourable action. The Opposition has destroyed itself. It deserves the greatest indictment from Mr Combe and others for what it has done to him. The Opposition did it all.
—It is shocking behaviour to a colleague.

—There is no need to shout me down. The Leader of the National Party is guilty of informing on this man with information that was within his own knowledge and privilege. He has destroyed the concept of bi-partisanship. He does not deserve to hold his position as a leader. That is the position. The Leader of the National Party is not entitled to remain in this Parliament because he used confidential information given to him in Opposition to malign and to destroy a decent citizen. He talks about justice and civil liberties. It is the Opposition who has destroyed this man. The Opposition raised it. It is the Opposition--
—Order! The Minister's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. As a personal explanation, my remarks therefore must be necessarily brief. I will relate the matter to the facts. Certain allegations have been made by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen). On 21 April, I was called by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I received a briefing from him and officials on the matters relating to Mr Ivanov and also Mr David Combe. I advised the Prime Minister on that occasion that, in regard to the briefing given to me about Mr Combe, I would say nothing at all and he concurred. In regard to Mr Ivanov, I said that I would relate this matter to my senior colleagues. At a later stage, I did inform them of my support for the Government 's action in expelling Mr Ivanov. There were no further briefings, to the best of my knowledge and recall, until last Thursday night, 5 May, when we spent an extensive period examining matters relating to articles in the National Times. After that again I indicated that on this occasion I supported the Government, and I advised the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony), the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The next briefing I received was also on the National Times article and the High Court of Australia hearing-bearing in mind that since 21 April no mention had been made of Mr Combe-and it was on Tuesday morning, 10 May.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday afternoon, 10 May, while in this Parliament I was handed, as honourable members will recall, a telex of the Australian Associated Press news release which indicated that a story had been given that the Prime Minister had discussed this matter in the Caucus, and I asked a question relating to this. The facts were explained by the Prime Minister, that it had been raised in the Caucus. We later understood that the matter was exacerbated by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) giving a Press briefing in which he told the Press what the Prime Minister had indicated to the Caucus. Later that day the Prime Minister and I met and he indicated his concern with the question that had been raised by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, which related to ministerial dealings with Mr Combe-the subject matter of the Press release that there had been no ministerial briefings. I indicated to him that I had not briefed the Deputy Leader of the National Party in regard to David Combe. The Prime Minister asked me to inform the Deputy Leader of the National Party of certain matters relating to Mr Combe and I gave him the assurance that I would. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party will confirm, I executed that duty after indicating to the Prime Minister that I would do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you did.

—Thank you. As the Prime Minister's statement yesterday indicated, the decision regarding Ministers, which was the subject matter of the question of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, was in the first instance made by the Cabinet on 26 April and endorsed by the full Ministry on 2 May. As I have indicated to honourable members, I had no discussions with the Prime Minister relating to Mr Combe between 21 April and the evening of 6 May. On 6 May it was public knowledge that it had been discussed in the Caucus. The briefing of the Leader of the House had ensured that; the Prime Minister's answer to a question in the Caucus had generated that Press briefing by the Leader of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: So I reiterate: The conduct of the Opposition and me is entirely proper. When I am briefed on matters of national security I indicate to the Prime Minister to whom I relate these matters. I do not go out, nor am I given any writ to go out, and inform all members of my party on this matter. I have not departed from that at all, nor will I until he releases me from this. These are briefings that are given to me and I have at all times told him to whom I have relayed certain matters and when.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition has corrected, in his view, certain statements that were made. I suggest he is now proceeding into a more general area which is beyond a personal explanation.

—I draw the matter to a close, Mr Speaker. The facts support the statement that I have made, both in relation to dates and times, on the accuracy and the proper conduct of the Opposition in this matter. The fundamental error was made by the Prime Minister in breaking a long standing convention. It should never have been brought into the open. It should never have been compounded by the Government.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition is now going into a point of order.
—The Government should never have behaved in this manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. It is not so much what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said that may be inaccurate; I do not say it is inaccurate. It may be misinterpreted. What he said was that I gave the briefing to the Press, which was part of my responsibility after the Caucus meeting. The record of that briefing will show that the name of David Combe was never mentioned. It was raised in the Caucus following the publication of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald, under the byline of Paul Kelly, that an Australian Labor Party person was involved. One of our colleagues, who again was not named at the Press briefing, had raised the question with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Prime Minister had told the Caucus, again without mentioning anyone's name, that there was no member of the Government involved. It was felt desirable that I should relay that to the Press. On all other matters concerning this question, I told the Press-and it will show on the records, because most of the Press representatives use tape recorders-that all questions should be referred to the Prime Minister's office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Prime Minister claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Mr Speaker, indeed, by both the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). It is relevant and instructive that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, at the outset of his speech this day, proceeded from a deliberate misrepresentation which is based upon the proposition--
—He has not spoken.
—I mean the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony). They switch and change so much that it is hard to keep up with them.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr Speaker, if Opposition members think that they can avoid the substance of what I am about to say by this nonsense, let them think so. Let us go to the facts. The Leader of the National Party, in his speech today, started from the basis of a deliberate misrepresentation in respect of what I had done on this matter in the Caucus. He proceeded on the basis of that deliberate misrepresentation, picked up subsequently in these proceedings by the Leader of the Opposition, on the basis that I had in this matter referred to an Australian Labor Party official in the Caucus. Let us have straight the facts to which the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has alluded. I repeat that what happened in the Caucus was that a member of the Government, a Minister, referred to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald and raised a question as to whether he was the person involved. Faced with that question, I answered simply and exclusively that neither he nor any other member of the Government was involved. There was no question. If members of the Opposition or any member of the media want to ask the Chairman, the Secretary and every member of the Caucus, they can undertake any inquiry that they like, but they will find that the fact is that I did not mention Mr Combe or any Labor official. There was no mention at all by me of Mr Combe. Yet on the basis of their prearranged determination to introduce the name of Mr Combe into these proceedings-which deliberately by me had not at any stage in this House been introduced; a full protection to the civil liberties of Mr Combe had been pursued by me-the Opposition introduced into this House the name of Mr Combe, and on the basis that I had mentioned Mr Combe in the Caucus.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat to this House that, with a full sense of the obligation of this Government with respect to both the security of this country and the civil liberties of individuals, I did not-repeat, 'not'-in the Caucus mention the name of Mr Combe or of any Labor Party official. I repeat that in response to a question from one of my Ministers I said: 'It is not you or any member of the Government'. Mr Combe's name was not mentioned. In the light of that explanation , I trust that there will be no further repetition of the deliberate misrepresentation which has been undertaken in this House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for proposed expenditure announced.
Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, together with its companion Bills, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1983-84 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1983-84, seeks interim appropriations for the services of the Government for the period 1 July 1983 to 30 November 1983, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills (Nos 1 and 2) and the appropriation Bill for Parliament, which will form part of the Budget for 1983-84, will have been enacted. Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $5,741.3m for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $925.3m or about 19.2 per cent greater than the equivalent amounts provided in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1982-83. A large part of the increase reflects higher staff ceilings approved by the previous Government after the 1982-83 Budget, salary and other cost increases and an extra payday which falls within the Supply period in 1983-84 as compared with 1982-83.

I mention two specific provisions in the Bill. First, in line with the Governor -General's Speech the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) will be introducing Bills for referendums on fixed term Parliaments and other matters of constitutional reform, a sum of $21m is included under the Australian Electoral Office for the purpose of the referendums. Secondly, $150m is provided for the Advance to the Minister for Finance, $25m more than in 1982-83. Apart from an adjustment made last year to bring the Supply Bill (No. 1) provision into line with that included in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), this is the first increase in the amount provided in the No. 1 Advance since 1979. The need for the increase reflects the growth in expenditures over this period and the pressure placed on the Advance in recent times.

The need for the Government to seek urgent interim appropriations at the special sittings in April-including supplementation of the Advance in the Appropriation (No. 1) 1982-83-was a clear manifestation of the pressure. I wish to emphasise that this Bill does not anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the 1983-84 Budget context. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Moore) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for proposed expenditure announced.
Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill seeks interim appropriations totalling $998.7m for expenditure on capital works and services, payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory and certain other services for the period 1 July to 30 November 1983. The amount is $201.5m or about 25.3 per cent greater than provided in the Supply Act (No. 2) 1982-83. The main increases include:

$55m for estimated establishment costs associated with the proposed Medicare medical benefits arrangements, the Government's commitment to which was confirmed in the Governor-General's Speech to the Parliament.

$41m under the Department of Housing and Construction for payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory to give effect to the previous Government' s decision to increase grants for welfare housing.

$28m for construction of the new Parliament House; this reflects the planned expenditure pattern for the stage of construction now reached and is necessary to enable completion of the building in time for the official opening in 1988 as part of the Bicentennial celebrations.

$1.2m is included under the Department of the Special Minister of State to enable the Government to publicise initiatives flowing from the National Eonomic Summit Conference, as called for by the Summit communique.

For reasons similar to those I outlined in relation to Supply Bill (No. 1) this Bill also includes $120m for the advance to the Minister for Finance, an increase of $20m over the equivalent amounts provided in recent years.

While provision is made in this Bill in respect of establishment cost for the Medicare arrangements, concerning which the Government's broad intentions have already been announced, the provisions do not otherwise anticipate decisions yet to be taken in the Budget context. This is fully in accordance with convention. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Moore) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation for proposed expenditure announced.
Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill seeks interim appropriations to meet expenditure by the parliamentary departments during the period 1 July 1983 to 30 November 1983. The appropriations sought total some $14m which is $3.1m or about 28.4 per cent greater than the amount provided for the same functions in the Supply period 1982-83. This reflects, in large part, an additional pay day, that falls in the Supply period in 1983-84, and wage and salary increases. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Moore) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Lloyd had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until-
(1) the legal action against the Australian Broadcasting Commission instituted by the Premier of New South Wales is concluded, and
(2) an assurance is given by the Government-
(a) that no action will be taken to alter the existing membership of the Commission until the Bill is again before the House at the conclusion of those legal proceedings, and
(b) that there will be no Government interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its programming policy'.
(Quorum formed).
Mr Lloyd-I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Is this the first time that the Government has ever called a quorum on itself?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the House last night we heard the contribution of the Opposition to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) moved an amendment to the second reading and indicated that it was proposed to move further amendments in Committee. It was indeed disappointing that the Opposition was unable to make a reasonable contribution to such an important subject. I propose to deal briefly with the amendments and the arguments in support of them. I will then move to what the Bill will do for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, as clearly the Opposition has failed totally to grasp what the Bill is about. The amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray proposed that the Bill should not proceed until legal action against the ABC, instituted by the Premier of New South Wales, is concluded and an assurance is given by the Government that no action will be taken to alter the existing membership of the Commission until the Bill comes back into this House at the conclusion of such legal proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposition can be described only as ludicrous. The report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, known as the Dix report, was tabled on 29 May 1981, almost two years ago. The Opposition is now suggesting that because of litigation between the Premier of New South Wales and the ABC this legislation should be delayed pending the conclusion of such legal proceedings, being a time which is uncertain. It is difficult to believe that such a ridiculous suggestion could have been made, but it was and is on the record as an amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray. Five of the commissioners retire in June. The Opposition is suggesting that the tenure of the present board should be extended, not even for a definite period, until the legal action referred to is concluded. That could be one month, six months, a year, two years, three years or whatever.

In the meantime the Government would be expected to take no action on this Bill and would thereby bury the enthusiasm for the modernisation of the ABC generated by the Dix report. That is the way in which the Opposition has addressed the matter in the debate. I must say that when I first saw the amendment at 8.30 last night I was sufficiently charitable to think that the Opposition may have thought that the establishment of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would, in some way, complicate the legal proceedings. However, it is clear that this is not the case, as the Opposition's argument was not based on that premise which would have been at least a misunderstanding of the position. The Opposition's argument was worse than that. It was an attempt to bury the first essential step in the implementation of the recommendations of the Dix report.

Before leaving this point it is necessary to refer to clause 9 (1) of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983. It does appear that there may still be some misunderstanding of this question by the Opposition. Last night one Opposition speaker was under the impression that the establishment of the Corporation, in fact, turned it into a company and put it under the provisions of the Companies Act. Clause 9 (1) of the principal Bill deals specifically with the legal proceedings question. Clause 9 (2) provides that the alteration of the name and constitution of the Australian Broadcasting Commission does not render defective any legal or other proceedings instituted or to be instituted by or against the body corporate as any proceedings against the ABC may be continued against the body corporate by the name of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. In order that those opposite are at least clear on that, it is necessary to put it on the record at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it was not that point that we were making.

—I am glad that it was not, but nothing would surprise me. The other part of the amendment related to there being no interference by the Government in the independence of the ABC and its programming policy. On this issue the Bill establishes clearly the independence of the Corporation in a way never contemplated by the Opposition. The Bill will guarantee such independence.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to move to the amendments, copies of which the Opposition provided at 9.30 last night, as its proposals to be put forward at the Committee stage which may well have been reached last evening, but was not. The first amendment proposes that the no work as directed, no pay provision be included in the Bill. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) directed his attention to this issue. It should be pointed out to him and to all other members of the Opposition that such a provision is contained in sections 44 and 44A of the Broadcasting and Television Act. Such provisions were inserted by the Liberal- National Party Government several years ago. As far as I am aware, this provision has never been used by the ABC and it should be congratulated on the fact that it has not adopted that confrontationist course. The inference of the Opposition is that the failure to include such a provision in the Bill leaves the ABC management without authority. This is patently untrue. There are disciplinary provisions for ABC officers who wilfully disobey or disregard directions. I refer the Opposition to clause 64 (10) and clause 64 (1). The latter provides for dismissal, transfer, reduction in salary and the right to refuse salary increments. It may, of course, be that that is not acceptable to the Opposition because, in its attitude to industrial relations, that would not be sufficiently draconian. But the fact of the matter is that the ABC management has ample authority to deal with members of staff. The suggestion that the no work as directed, no pay provision should be reinstated in the Bill is totally rejected.

The attitude of the Opposition on this issue clearly indicates its lack of understanding of industrial relations and its obvious desire to bring about confrontation. This Government came to office with a commitment to examine restrictive industrial relations legislation applying to Australian Government employment. The no work as directed, no pay provisions which give power for the non-payment of salary to employees who refuse for industrial reasons to comply with a direction to carry out work normally performed are seen to be in this category. The non-inclusion of these provisions in the legislation to establish the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is consistent with the commitment and with industrial relations policy objectives included in the statement of accord by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions regarding economic policy. These objectives are aimed at improving industrial relations in Australia to the benefit of workers, employers and, of course, the public in general.

To achieve its objectives in this regard the Government intends to create a better industrial relations climate by itself adopting, and encouraging other employers to adopt, a rational and less confrontationist approach to industrial relations. This is a matter which is just not understood by those opposite. The Government encourages the settlement of disputes between employers and unions by conciliation without recourse to legislative or common law provisions. The Bill reflects this approach of the Government in relation to the ABC.

The next amendment to be proposed at the Committee stage relates to the complaints procedure. On this matter the honourable member for Murray referred to the British Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission. The total lack of knowledge of the Opposition on this issue is exposed by the fact that the BBC Complaints Commission no longer exists. The correct position is that Britain has a Broadcasting Complaints Commission which covers both the BBC and the Independent Broadcasting Authority. In other words, both the BBC and the commercial radio and television networks are covered by the Commission. The commissioners are appointed by the relevant Minister. Is it now the policy of the Opposition to have such a commission in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing new about that. We have it all here.

—That may be so but the honourable member's information is defective. I repeat that the commissioners are appointed by the relevant Minister. Is it now the policy of the Opposition to have such a commission in Australia covering the ABC and the commercial services, and is it suggested that the Minister for Communications should appoint the commissioners? That is what the proposals in fact put forward last night mean. The honourable member said that the Opposition 's policy was based on the British position, which he has totally misread. I am glad to see that he is nodding his head in acknowledgement. Is that the policy which in fact the Opposition now has? Does it propose that we should have a broadcasting complaints commission covering the ABC and the commercial sector and that the commissioners should in fact be nominated by the Minister, who in this case will be me? If that is its policy, the Opposition should come out and say so.

SPEECH.PARA: The next point to be raised on this issue is that, according to the Opposition' s definition, a complaint may be made if a program is unjust or unfair. It will be interesting to see how the Opposition proposes to define unjust or unfair. Is it suggesting that where there is no error of fact-that is, that what the ABC has said is true-there will be instances that will warrant investigation on the basis that the report was unjust or unfair? A complaint could, of course, be made on the basis of invasion of privacy, but that issue is dealt with elsewhere in the Bill. Protection is afforded people in that situation. To allow complaints on the basis that a program is unjust or unfair is, to say the least, dangerously unclear and would permit the complaints procedure suggested by the Opposition to be used as a method of engaging in unjustified interference in the programming of the ABC.

Last year, the then Minister for Communications raised the possibility of looking at the BBC model. That possibility reappeared in the Parliament at 9.30 last night. It is interesting that the Opposition has kept quiet on the issue until now, obviously fearing the consequences of making its views available for public comment and, particularly, of an obviously adverse response from the ABC and its staff. The proposal by the Opposition would establish an outside body to monitor the ABC. That would reflect the infamous view of the former member for Gippsland that a political monitor was needed. It is a tragic reflection on the Opposition that it has made no advances since those days of threats and intimidation against the ABC. That is obviously still its preferred position, since it seeks an outside monitor of the ABC. So much for the crocodile tears of the Opposition concerning non-interference in the affairs of the ABC. What absolute humbug!

All of the Opposition's amendments are rejected by the Government, which intends to proceed to establish the Australian Broadcasting Corporation so that the important work of reconstructing and modernising Australia's national broadcaster can go ahead without further delay. Until this Bill is passed there can be no effective implementation of the recommendations of the Dix report. The Government is committed to maintaining a strong and independent ABC, one that is able to meet the broadcasting needs of Australians. The Government believes that the ABC, as Australia's only national broadcaster, has served and must be able to continue to serve, in the forefront of Australian broadcasting. The Bill gives the ABC a charter which clearly sets out its functions and obligations.

The charter, which is set out in clause 6 of the Bill, requires that the Corporation provide innovative and comprehensive radio and television services of a high standard, and also to provide programs which contribute to a sense of national identity and inform, entertain and reflect the cultural diversity of the Australian community. The charter makes clear the need for a balance between programs of wide appeal and those that are more specialised. It also acknowledges the role of the ABC as an international broadcaster and provider of educational programs and reaffirms its role of encouraging and promoting the musical, dramatic and other performing arts in Australia.

The Dix Committee criticised the ABC for failing to take account of changes in the composition of the Australian community. The charter has been expanded to include a provision that requires the Corporation to recognise the multicultural character of today's Australian society. That recognition is seen by the honourable member for Murray as an indication that the Special Broadcasting Service would be replaced by the ABC. This view is an indication of the lack of understanding of the need for the ABC to recognise the multicultural character of Australian society. Is the honourable member for Murray in fact suggesting that the ABC should not pay regard to the multicultural nature of Australian society? Those were, in fact, the amendments moved by the Opposition last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not all moved then.

—The first amendment was moved last night; the other amendments will be moved in the Committee stage. At this stage I indicate, for the reasons that I have already set out, that they are not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move on to some more positive aspects of this matter. They relate to what the Bill does. With respect to how the legislation will benefit the ABC I think that there are some matters the Opposition should understand. The ABC will have its own Act of Parliament. Its legislation will be extensively modernised. The independence of the ABC will be strengthened. There will be a clear charter setting out the functions and the obligations of the ABC. There will be a statutory recognition of Radio Australia and the ABC's television news service. The legislation will clearly spell out the duties of the Board and the managing director. There will be a major upgrading of advisory mechanisms. There will be an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council and provision for similar councils in relation to a State, Territory or region of Australia. The position of the chief executive of the ABC will be substantially upgraded. He will exercise statutory powers in his own right and will be a member of the Board.

There will be a substantial modernisation of administrative provisions as set out in part V including removal of Public Service controls on salaries and terms and conditions of employment, early retirement, efficiency to be the sole criterion for promotions, provisions for more than one promotions appeal board as set out in clause 41 and for appeals against temporary promotions as in clause 40. Part V division 3 deals with updated redeployment and disciplinary provisions including provisions for a tenure appeal board as well as a disciplinary appeal board. There will be greater ABC control over transmission facilities. The ABC transmitters located within the national transmitting stations will be transferred to the ABC ownership. The ABC will be given control of links between its studios and local national transmitting stations. The Minister will, in certain circumstances, be able to transfer individual transmitting stations to the ABC. The limitation on ABC contracts requiring ministerial approval will be lifted from $250,000 to $500,000.

The matter over which all the crocodile tears have been shed is the issue of independence. I move now specifically to talk about how this legislation strengthens the independence of the ABC. Firstly, there will be an expressed statutory obligation on the board to maintain the independence and integrity of the ABC; that is set out in clause 8 (1) (b). The Corporation will be given wide powers under clause 25 and will be able to make its own rules thereby lessening its dependence on government. There will be statutory recognition of the ABC's independent television news service. All Public Service Board controls on salaries and terms and conditions of employment will be removed. I dealt a moment ago with the other issues of the general benefits provisions, ownership of ABC transmitters and those issues arising in respect of the transmitting stations.

The matter which seems to have caused some difficulty for the Opposition-a considerable number of aspects has caused it difficulty-has been that of complaints. I will now deal with the changes that were made in this Bill to the Bill which came forward from the then Government in September and December of last year. (Extension of time granted). I thank the House.

An important change to the 1982 legislation is that the Government decided not to proceed with the appointment of a commissioner for complaints. One of the most important changes to the Bill that the then Government brought before this House in September and December last year is that decision not to proceed with a commissioner for complaints. The establishment of such a position outside the ABC with broad powers to investigate a wide range of complaints smacks of political censorship. However, the Government does accept that there should be some mechanism within the ABC to investigate complaints regarding errors of fact or invasion of privacy.

The Bill, therefore, provides for the Corporation to establish positions for community affairs officers to deal with such complaints. Under clause 82, a national community affairs officer appointed by the Managing Director will co- ordinate the work of community affairs officers in each State, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory If a complaint is found to be justified, the Managing Director will be notified and will be required to arrange for a prompt apology or retraction to be broadcast. The ABC will also be required to include a summary of the activities of these officers in its annual report to the Parliament.

As far as we are concerned, that matter has been dealt with in the fairest way possible from the point of view of the ABC and also from the point of view of the public who may consider it necessary to make complaints against the ABC. It is a far better proposal than that which was put forward last year. It is a far better proposal than the somewhat confused view that was put forward here last night which purported to be based on the British Broadcasting Corporation system and obviously is not. In any event, the BBC arrangement was introduced in 1981. There is certainly no indication that that is necessarily the perfect model to follow. The problem was that the Opposition got it all wrong and the proposal it put forward did not even follow the British model.

The other matter which is causing some difficulty to the Opposition-I understand this to some extent-is the question of consultation in respect of appointments to the Board. At this stage, I point out to the Opposition that there will be consultations on a party basis in respect of the appointments to the Board. The Opposition spokesman on communications, the honourable member for Murray, last night asked whether his party would be included. I really do not know how anybody on the Opposition side could think that we on this side of the House would exclude them from consultation. I mean, I was somewhat--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not ask whether we would be included. I just asked what your definition of 'parties' was.
—The numbers of the National Party may have been depleted but it is still defined as a political party.
—Not us so much. You might have been referring to others.
—If the honourable member is worried about whether the Australian Democrats will be included, I assure him that they will be.
—No, I was not.
—I do not know whom the honourable member is worried about then.
—I put those questions to you and I asked for your answers, not for comments on the way I asked the questions.
—I have answered the questions. The political parties will be--
—What about the radio station at Charleville?

—I will not leave out the honourable member for Maranoa. On the question of consultation, the honourable member for Murray does not need to suffer any paranoia. I have no doubt that he will be satisfied with the procedure. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) interjected just a moment ago and I certainly have not forgotten him. He at least showed some concern for better broadcasting facilities for the people whom he represents. I can assure him that the Government is conscious of the problems that he put forward here last night and puts forward regularly in correspondence.
—But his Government did nothing about it.

—The fact of the matter is that the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) last night, of course, dealt with that issue. I note in passing, as has always been the case, that when an interjection comes from the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) it is always very much to the point and is accurate. As the honourable member for Grayndler indicated, it has been a long time since we were in government. In the whole of the post-war period we have interrupted the Liberal Party's reign of terror for only three years. In fact from 1949 to 1972 the Liberal Party was uninterrupted in government and then again from 1975 to this year. Nevertheless, that was dealt with last night. I think the honourable member for Maranoa was prepared to accept that the view put forward by the honourable member for Grayndler was a reasonable one. I found it rather interesting to hear that view put forward at this stage. The proposition put forward by honourable members opposite, that we cannot ignore the needs of the people they represent, particularly the matters they raised specifically last night, is reasonable. I assure members of the Opposition that we are conscious of the problems. The Charleville A.M. station is in the program for the next three years.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Lloyd's amendment) stand part of the question.
