PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 45-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new Division 2A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) After Division 2 of Part V, page 28, insert the following new Division ( comprising clauses 45A and 45B):
'Division 2A-Failure to work as directed
No work as directed-no pay.

45A. (1) Where an officer or temporary employee refuses or fails to comply with a direction given by a person having authority to give the direction, being a lawful direction with respect to work that he is performing or is to perform, the Managing Director may declare that the officer or employee is not to be paid salary.
(2) A declaration under sub-section (1) in relation to the refusal or failure of an officer or temporary employee to comply with a direction-

(a) shall specify the time (which may be a time before the declaration is made but not earlier than the time when the officer or employee refused or failed, or first refused or first failed, to comply with the direction) from which the declaration is to have effect, or is to be deemed to have had effect; and
(b) has effect and shall be deemed to have had effect, according to its tenor, from the time so specified until it is revoked in accordance with this section.

(3) An officer or temporary employee is not entitled to be paid salary in respect of any period in respect of which a declaration under sub-section (1) has effect, or is to be deemed to have had effect, in relation to him.
(4) The Managing Director-
(a) may, at any time, vary or revoke a declaration in force under sub-section ( 1) either wholly or in relation to a specified officer or temporary employee; and

(b) shall, upon becoming satisfied that an officer or temporary employee in respect of whom a declaration under sub-section (1) is in force has been complying, or will comply, from a particular time, with all relevant directions with respect to the work that he is performing, or is to perform, given by persons having authority to give those directions, revoke, as from that time, that declaration, or that declaration in its application to that officer or employee, as the case requires.

(5) A declaration made under sub-section (1) in respect of a refusal or failure of an officer or temporary employee to comply with a particular direction, or with particular directions, has effect in accordance with sub-section (2) notwithstanding that, at any time while it is in force, the officer or employee-
(a) attends for duty and performs work other than work to which that direction, or any of those directions, as the case requires, relates; or
(b) attends for duty and, in the performance of his work, complies with that direction, or with some or all of those directions, as the case requires, in part only.
(6) A declaration under sub-section (1), and a variation or revocation of such a declaration-
(a) shall be made in writing; and
(b) shall be signed-
(i) by the Managing Director; or
(ii) by a person to whom the Managing Director has delegated his powers under this section.

(7) Subject to sub-sections (8) and (9), the powers conferred on the Managing Director by this section are in addition to, and not in substitution for, any other powers conferred by or under this Act on the Corporation, on the Board, on the Managing Director or on any other person in relation to an officer or temporary employee.

(8) While a declaration under sub-section (1) is in force in respect of the refusal or failure of an officer or temporary employee to comply with a direction, or with 2 or more directions, proceedings shall not be taken against the officer or employee under section 64 in respect of any refusal or failure of the officer or employee in respect of which that declaration was made.

(9) Where proceedings are taken against an officer or temporary employee under section 64 in respect of any refusal or failure of the officer or employee to comply with a direction, or with directions, of the kind referred to in sub- section (1), a declaration shall not be made under sub-section (1) in respect of any refusal or failure of the officer or employee in respect of which those proceedings have been taken unless those proceedings have been finally determined or otherwise terminated.

(10) Where a declaration is made under sub-section (1) in respect of an officer or temporary employee, or such a declaration is varied or revoked, the Managing Director shall cause such notice as he deems appropriate to be given of the making of the declaration or of the variation or revocation of the declaration, as the case may be.

(11) The period during which a declaration under sub-section (1) has effect in respect of an officer or employee forms part of his period of service or employment under this Act for the purposes of the Superannuation Act 1976 but does not, unless the Managing Director otherwise determines, form part of his period of service or employment under this Act for any purpose of this Act or of any other Act.
(12) In this section, unless the contrary intention appears-
''direction'' includes an order and an instruction;
''salary'' includes wages or other remuneration and any allowances that are declared by the rules to be included in salary for the purposes of this definition.
Declarations to prevail over awards
45B. (1) Section 45A has full force and effect, and declarations in force under sub-section 45A (1) have full force and effect according to their tenor, notwithstanding any inconsistency-
(a) with any other provision of this Act;
(b) with any other law of the Commonwealth enacted before the commencing day; or
(c) with any award made before, on or after the commencing day.
(2) Section 45A shall be deemed to be a prescribed provision of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1982 for the purposes of-
(a) sub-section 22 (2) of the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920; and
(b) sub-section 41A (1) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904.
(3) Except as provided in sub-section (1), nothing in a declaration in force under sub-section 45A (1) shall be taken as affecting-
(a) the application of any law, or of any award, to or in relation to an officer or temporary employee; or
(b) the terms and conditions of employment of an officer or temporary employee. '.

I move this amendment for the following reasons. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), when he replied earlier, stated that there is a disciplinary provision still in the legislation. That is Division 4-Discipline. I remind the Minister, honourable members of the government and those listening to the debate that that disciplinary provision was still in the Bill that was introduced into this place by the previous Government. In spite of the comments that have been made by certain honourable members on the Government side, I want to remind everybody that the basic legislation that we are debating here today was introduced by the previous Government; so nothing new or revolutionary is being suggested. What we are doing with this amendment is moving for the reinsertion of the no work as directed, no pay provisions which were in the original legislation.

The reason for that is that if one looks at the disciplinary provision, it will be seen that it refers to certain actions which are available to the managing director in relation to matters of discipline with individual employees in the Australian Broadcasting Commission. That does not cover and was considered by the previous Government not to cover those actions which are now taken all too frequently by unions, whether they be in the public or the private sector, which do not come under the code of individual discipline but which come under the more general definition of rolling strikes. Perhaps it is not a case of actually not working but refusing to do the work which employees are instructed by management to do. This puts management in an impossible position.

The point was made by the Minister that this particular provision has not been used very much since we, as the Government, introduced it into the legislation generally covering the Public Service. The present Government is obviously intent on removing all of these provisions in relation to the Public Service. This is the first time we have met this situation with the new Government. However, situations can arise in which, in spite of management being sensible- management must be sensible to co-ordinate, to co-operate, to talk and to discuss and work out problems as they arise-unless it has this added provision of no work as directed, no pay, with the modern approach of unions and staff associations to interfere with the work that they should be doing or not actually going on strike but not doing the work that they should be doing, management has no ability to manage. We are placing the management of the ABC or any other Public Service management-for that matter, any employer-employee relationship-in an impossible position. Therefore, we believe that this clause should be reinserted.

I make the point in conclusion in regard to the comment earlier that amendments were received at a certain time that they were certainly provided as soon as they were available. I also point out that this morning we made no attempt to curtail the Minister's reply.

TALK.START.PARA: 11.45)-I will take only a moment of the Committee's time. The Opposition seems to be obsessed with the clause it wishes to insert into the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill. As the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) rightly pointed out earlier today, there is really no need for it because just about everything is covered under clause 64 of the Bill. If this sort of clause were put into legislation or an award connected with private enterprise I am sure there would be a backlash not from the employees but from the employers. They would not want to wear this sort of thing. If we want better industrial relations and not confrontation then the sort of clause that the Opposition wishes to put in is just not on. The Opposition has an obsession with it similar to the obsession with confrontation which it had for seven years under the previous Prime Minister and which obviously it still does have under the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) who was for years a member of the Cabinet that brought in various draconian pieces of legislation and who was the Minister for Industrial Relations for a time. It still has that direction of confrontation. Obviously it has not learned its lessons and so will be on the other side of the House for quite some time. The honourable member for Murray ( Mr Lloyd) mentioned that the no work, no pay provision in the Broadcasting and Television Act has been used only a few times. My research says it has never been used.
—I did not say it had been used a few times.
—The honourable member said it had been used on only a few occasions.
—I did not say in relation to the B and T Act. I accepted what the Minister told me.

—I will relate it to the Broadcasting and Television Act. As far as my research goes, the provision has never been used. To insert it as a big stick to hold over people would be ridiculous. We are looking at the broadcasting industry in an attempt to get it off the ground with a right and proper charter and with an Act of Parliament, which it will have after today. For all those reasons we on this side firmly reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clauses the Committee is discussing are very important because this is the first occasion on which this issue has arisen in this Parliament. Of course undertakings have been given by the new Government that it intends to remove in a number of areas-I guess that this is the first one-clauses that were inserted previously in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and in other areas of industrial relations requiring public servants to work in accordance with instructions. The reason for clauses like this in legislation such as we are discussing, and in other legislation is not in any way to be confrontationist.
—Rubbish.

—It is not in any way to be confrontationist. Nobody would desire to use legislation of this sort but it is a recognition of the changed attitude to industrial relations which has occurred in this country in recent years. One of the reasons for the change is the nature of the work place. We are now in a position where, because of the equipment that is being used and because of the often limited numbers of people with particular skills, workers can refuse to work in accordance with instructions so that a whole department, a whole range of work that needs to be done, can be brought to a halt not by all of the people involved in undertaking work but by a small number of people. Very often only one, two or three technicians need be withdrawn.

SPEECH.PARA: This has changed the whole way in which industrial relations are undertaken. In the past there was a saying used in the trade union movement of 'one out, all out' on an industrial question. I think that had some justification because what it meant was that, when dealing with an issue of principle, the employer was denied his income and the employees, of course, went without their income. All work was brought to a halt and, on an important question of principle, both sides were bargaining essentially on an equal basis. Now what we have seen occurring is that a limited number of people go out on strike-maybe, only half a dozen. That can mean that thousands of people have nothing to do but they continue on the payroll and the trade union movement is its bargaining is substantially advantaged. Honourable members opposite may see that as being desirable. But in this case the Government is the employer.

It needs to be understood that, in a situation where the Government is being held to ransom by one or two people who will not work as they are required, many thousands of other people who will benefit from whatever the industrial question is that is being argued, will still be paid when they are unable to work. I think honourable members will recognise that that puts the Government in a very difficult position. It has been said that clauses like this have not been used. They have not been used because they brought about a different situation. They put the employer and the employees essentially in an equal bargaining position and they negotiated more realistically. Of course, in the Public Service area these provisions have been used. I think they were used on about four occasions in relation to postal workers, telecommunications employees, ACTION buses in Canberra and the dispute involving the Department of Social Security. They were the four occasions on which I recall their being used. They were difficult questions but I do not think anybody would realistically say that it was inappropriate in those circumstances that the provisions be used. It meant that, where the Public Service was concerned, the people of Australia benefited.

Just because a particular provision is not used is no reason for it not to be there. Assuming in criminal law that there was never a murder, would one want to legislate to say that there should not be a crime of murder? That is the sort of argument, the sort of logic, that is being used. It is appropriate to have a clause of this sort in the legislation. It is appropriate that in all the areas affecting the Public Service there be a clause of this sort, as was provided by the previous Government-not to be used, but to ensure that the Government employees and the Government are in a roughly equivalent position when negotiating-so that people will do exactly what honourable members opposite have argued, that is, sit down and talk realistically without resort to unfair practices on either side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have dealt with this matter in considerable detail in my second reading speech and again this morning in reply to the second reading debate. In order to save some time at the Committee stage, I do not propose to take much time on this matter at this point because, as I said, I dealt with it in some detail this morning. One thing ought to be said arising out of the contribution of the honourable member for Dundas ( Mr Ruddock). The equation of murder with industrial relations was extremely interesting in the sense that is probably does in some way indicate the state of mind of those opposite. The honourable member for Dundas puts forward a most extraordinary proposition by suggesting that, if the 'no work as directed, no pay' provision is not in a Bill, that in some way is analogous to saying that in fact there ought not to be a crime of murder because that crime is not committed very often. Quite clearly, the issue here is the basic philosophical difference between the Opposition and the Government in respect of industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: In outlining the views of the Government on that matter last night and again today-it was so well put this morning in the Committee stage by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles)-I assured honourable members that there was no way that the Government was convinced by the arguments that were put forward last night. I notice that the learned lawyer, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), has deigned to grace us with his presence again this morning. No doubt we will have a learned discourse from him later today on this matter. It would want to be better than his contribution last night.

There was some confusion regarding sections 44 and 44A of the Broadcasting and Television Act. In order to clarify the situation and put it on the record, what I said in my speech this morning was that it should be poined out that the provision contained in sections 44 and 44A of the Broadcasting and Television Act was inserted by the Liberal-National Party Government-who else would insert them-several years ago. As far as I am aware, this provision has never been used by the ABC and it should be congratulated on not adopting such a confrontationist course. In reply the honourable member for Murray-I do not want to make a great issue of it but it ought to be clarified-indicated that he thought I said the provision had not been used very much. I think those were his words.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I accept that you said it had not been used by the ABC. I said that generally, meaning across the whole spectrum of the Public Service, it had not been used very much. That was confirmed by the honourable member for Dundas.

—It is all right as long as the honourable member understands that. As far as the ABC is concerned, I stand to be corrected if he can find an example. Obviously the management of the ABC does not take the same view as those opposite that it is necessary. I ask honourable members opposite to consider this matter very carefully-not that they are likely to give it a great deal of thought because, as I say, it represents a deep philosophical difference between us-in the context of the Dix report. After all, the Bill is the start of the implementation of the recommendations of that report. Under the heading ' Personnel management' the Dix report referred to the emphasis being on co- operation and counselling rather than confrontation. That is basically what we are about in industrial relations. I have outlined that in some detail. I do not intend to repeat it unless it is necessary, unless we have another contribution by the honourable member for North Sydney, for which we all wait so eagerly, any time he decides to display his obvious knowledge which he thinks we are entitled to hear.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the question of confrontation. This matter was raised also by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). They made a great point about the provision not being used but being in the legislation and able to be used as some sort of a threat all the time. It was interesting to note-when the honourable member for Dundas spoke he had no notes before him-all the instances in which the big stick had come out and had been used in industrial situations. He was aware of them all. They just clicked out of his mind automatically because it is something that he understands. If there is to be confrontation, that is the way he wants it. That has been the record of the Fraser Government in relation to industrial affairs. However sincerely the honourable member takes the view that he is correct on this issue it is my view that confrontation is what it leads to. That is the attitude of the Government and that is why we have in fact taken the view that we have in respect of this Bill. We will start with the ABC. Let the ABC deal with its industrial relations in the way that it thinks fit.
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12 noon, I interrupt the Minister. In accordance with sessional order 101 (A) I shall report progress.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister give Mr Combe any opportunity to explain his position either to him, the Prime Minister, or to his Attorney-General before the Prime Minister directed that Ministers not have further contact with Mr Combe in his role as a consultant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for his question. The answer is no. I know that the honourable member will want me to go beyond that and I wish to do so. As I have tried to indicate to the House from the outset in this matter, the Government has attempted assiduously and with all the fairness that it can command to take into account at one and the same time the two considerations which we believe any responsible government must take into account in circumstances such as those with which we are dealing and to which the honourable member addresses himself in his question. Those two considerations are, firstly, the proper security considerations of this country and, secondly, in action taken to protect those security interests, the rights of individuals.

ANSWER.PARA: It was apparent to me and to my fellow Ministers in the appropriate Cabinet committee dealing with these matters that in taking the decision that we had to take in respect of the expulsion of the KGB officer Ivanov the questions and rights of Mr Combe, the person who it has now emerged was implicated, were in issue. I and those of my fellow Ministers who were in possession of the knowledge relevant in this respect determined that in our handling of it those rights of Mr Combe would be protected as far as it was within our capacity to do so. Therefore, in making the decision that we did in respect of the position that no Ministers should have further dealings with Mr Combe, I did not rely, in the discussions with Cabinet and the full Ministry, on those points relating to the relationship with Mr Ivanov but, indeed, referred to matters which I think all members of the House, and certainly members of the Opposition, would agree were appropriate. I said that my Government should not be in a position where there could be seen to be some improper relationship or due advantage given to people in respect of relations with us being channelled through a person who had previously held high position in the Australian Labor Party. We deliberately-I say this quite straightforwardly; I think the honourable member will understand- did not go to the full Cabinet and the full Ministry in terms of raising the question of Mr Combe's relationships with Mr Ivanov.

I point out to the honourable member that all members of the Cabinet and all members of the full Ministry accepted the basis that I put to both the Cabinet and the Ministry as in itself a good and sufficient reason for the recommendation which I put to them and which they accepted. From that point I at all times, and I believe all my Ministers as well who were in possession of the information, did nothing at all in fact to prejudice Mr Combe's reputational position by making any public acknowledgement here or in any other forum of the relationship of Mr Combe with Mr Ivanov so that through no action of either myself or those Ministers with knowledge would Mr Combe's position be prejudiced by the knowledge that we had. I believe, and I hope that the honourable member will appreciate, that in those circumstances not only I as Prime Minister but also those few Ministers privy to these facts did everything that we possibly could to ensure his civil liberties. I know through the honourable member's history that that is an issue that he has a real concern about. We did everything that we possibly could to ensure that nothing that we did acted in a way to infringe those liberties and rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: In view of the fact that recent events have raised fundamental questions regarding the operations of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the rights of Mr Combe, will he say what is the attitude of his Government to these matters? Is he in a position to indicate how he proposes to respond?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust that all members of the Parliament, including members of the Opposition, are interested in knowing the position on this matter and that I will be able to outline it to the Parliament in response to the very serious and proper question addressed to me by the honourable member for Burke. Let me say, in regard to Mr Combe, as has now been clearly established, particularly as a result of events of this morning, that I, as I have indicated also further in answer to the previous question, have done nothing and have said nothing, including in the Caucus, to mention Mr Combe's name. I trust that that is now fully understood and accepted. Once, however, the name of Mr Combe was introduced into this House as part of a carefully co-ordinated set of questions on the part of the Opposition, designed to introduce his name, it was clear to me and those with whom I consulted that we then must move to do what we could to give Mr Combe every opportunity to look at the decision of the Government and the basis for the decision of the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: We proceeded to do something which has never before been done in the country in terms of protecting the rights of an individual affected by a decision of Government in a security area. We got Mr Combe, with his lawyer, to have discussions with the Attorney-General. May I say that this was done with the full concurrence, and indeed the involvement, of the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Mr Combe prepared his statement of his knowledge of his past associations and what he had been doing. Mr Combe was given then the opportunity-I repeat that this was done with the full involvement of the Director-General of Security; so let there be no spurious suggestions that the Government was acting in a way contrary to the proper security interests of this country-with his lawyer, of examining the basis of the Government's decision.

As a result of being given that opportunity, which I repeat to the House had never before been given to anyone in this sort of situation but was done with the full co-operation of the Director-General of ASIO who, for part of the time was present, Mr Combe in those circumstances of knowing the basis of the Government's decision associated himself with the statement put by me to this House that he understood and accepted the decision of the Government. Mr Speaker , I suggest to you and to all honourable members of this House who are capable of looking at this in terms of the twin issues of the security of this country and the rights of the individual, that this Government, in the circumstances where Mr Combe's name was raised by the Opposition and not by us, immediately did every possible thing it could do to ensure that Mr Combe had an unparalleled and historically unprecedented opportunity of knowing why the Government had acted as it did.

I repeat that once Mr Combe had had that opportunity with his lawyer, the Attorney-General and the Director-General of ASIO he indicated that he understood and accepted-the Queen's English is pretty plain-the decision of the Government that the Ministers of this Government would not have any further dealings with him in his capacity as a professional lobbyist. That decision taken by the Government was understood and accepted by Mr Combe. I repeat that, in the interests of Mr Combe, once his name had been deliberately introduced into this House and therefore to the public by the Opposition, this Government moved to do everything immediately within its power to see that Mr Combe had every opportunity to look at the facts as we, the Government, knew those facts. On the basis of those facts, we believed in terms of the interest of this country that we had to act. Mr Combe understood and accepted our decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —That he was a security risk? Is that what he accepted?

—I will respond to this interjection -it is not something I always do- because it is relevant to this answer. The people opposite who are professing-I must not use the word 'hypocritically' and I will not, Mr Speaker-their great concern for the civil liberties of Mr Combe now, by interjection, say that he accepted that he was a security risk. What concern have these people now for the civil liberties of Mr Combe when, by interjection, they say that he accepted that he was a security risk? What legitimacy does the Opposition have to stand up and profess concern for the rights and civil liberties of Mr Combe when, by interjection, it puts in the forefront of the public's mind the suggestion that Mr Combe has accepted that he was a security risk. What sham! The Opposition ought to be ashamed of itself.

ANSWER.PARA: I proceed with respect to the rights of Mr Combe in terms of what this Government is doing in this whole issue. As I indicated in an answer which I gave in this House on Wednesday of this week, I make it clear that we are moving in the area of review of the security organisations--

TALK.START.PARA: —You said no, didn't you?

—I know it takes more than once for some members to understand. I refer the honourable member to the answer I gave with respect to this question of intelligence organisations. On Wednesday of this week in answer to the Leader of the Opposition I gave an indication of what we were proposing. It can be found on page 412 of the Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: In these circumstances I take the matter further because it goes to the issues raised by the honourable member for Burke, and that is the rights of Mr Combe and the question of the security organisations. Not moved by the events of yesterday but in terms of our overall consideration of this matter, last week I had discussions with Mr Justice Hope as to his availability to undertake a new judicial review, a new royal commission into the security services of this country. That discussion that I had with Mr Justice Hope had followed discussions that I had had with members of the security organisations. This is not something that is being imposed. I made it clear to them that it was appropriate that there should be a judicial review-a point which has been accepted by them. Mr Justice Hope properly put to me-I remind you, Mr Speaker, and the House that this took place last week, not this week-that whether he would be available did not lie within his area of discretion but properly was a matter which would have to be referred through the appropriate channels to Chief Justice Street.

I point out to the House that these proceedings were under way last week-that is, proceedings to initiate a judicial review into the operations of security organisations. I now say to this House that I have also instructed the Attorney- General to draw up the terms of reference of such a royal commission. But I now want to inform the House of something of which, in the nature of things, I could not inform the House when I gave the answer on Wednesday because at that stage the duplicity of the Opposition had not been revealed. But let me say that now that Mr Combe's name has been mentioned the first term of reference and the matter upon which we will be seeking the royal commissioner to report first are these things: First, the circumstances surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov; secondly, Mr Combe's involvement in that issue; and, thirdly, the actions of this Government in respect to those matters. There will be a full judicial inquiry by the Government into the security organisations. The first term of reference will be a request that there be an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the expulsion of Mr Ivanov, Mr Combe's involvement and the actions of this Government in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister intend that the criteria outlined on page 3 of his statement of 11 May with respect to future contacts between Ministers and lobbyists be applied equally to all former Labor Ministers, staff members and party officials?

—If the Opposition would like a full inquiry into the relationship of previous members of this Parliament as lobbyists with the former Government and with this Government, I am quite prepared to accommodate it. Indeed, I will ask Cabinet when it considers the matter to which I will refer in a moment to consider whether it is appropriate that that inquiry should take place. I am more than happy for a full inquiry to be held into the relationship between previous Liberal or coalition members of this Parliament as lobbyists with the previous Government. I think it is a good idea. As I have already indicated to this House I have asked the relevant Minister to prepare a submission to the Cabinet as to the question of the registration of all lobbyists. This is something which the previous Government had full opportunity to do but did not do. We have already acted to put this matter on an appropriate basis. It may well be that, in the process of doing that, it is worthwhile to conduct the sort of inquiry to which I referred.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister, who is Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the Minister assure the House that the Government has given appropriate assistance to Father Brian Gore? Is the Government continuing to keep closely in touch with the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House knows that the Minister for Foreign Affairs has taken a very close interest in this matter. In fact, he was in the Philippines recently and saw Father Gore. The Government, through the Minister, is closely monitoring the situation in the Philippines. I am assured by the Department of Foreign Affairs that there is close contact with Father Gore virtually on a daily basis. The Department will be able to monitor the legal proceedings that are taking place in the Philippines. On that note, it is of some concern to report that there has been a series of legal proceedings against Father Gore. Some time last year he was charged with an offence, that he was inciting rebellion and was in possession of explosives. That matter was adjourned and he was released on bail. Pending that matter he was again the subject of a hearing as to whether he should be deported because of charges that were apparently either then being made or likely to be made. That matter was also adjourned.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently a further charge, of murder, was laid against Father Gore and others, including a Father O'Brien and a Father Dangan, six church workers and six others. In other words we have three charges, none of which has yet been finalised, the last one being laid only in recent days. In respect of the latter proceeding, I am advised that Father Gore has obtained release on house arrest. He has sought bail. The bail application was before the court on 10 May and I understand will be heard on 17 May.

It is a matter of record in Australia that missionary priests are not likely to be involved in the sort of action for which these people are now the subject of charges in the Philippines. It is of concern to Australia that the issues of justice should always be applicable to all citizens .

We are able to say, as far as we can follow the information, that the due process of law has been followed in the Philippines to the present. We are very mindful of the human rights interests because missionaries work in areas which are usually deprived. Obviously one motivation would be to try to improve the lot of those with whom they work, and they are not likely to be involved in any criminal activity.
I assure the House that the Australian embassy has full consular access to Father Gore, and embassy officers are attending all hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister. Did he, the Treasurer, the Minister for Resources and Energy, the Minister for Aviation and Mr David Combe have discussions on 5 April this year on the subject of the development of Australia's uranium deposits?

—I cannot speak for my other Ministers. I suggest, therefore, that the honourable member seek, by whatever processes, to direct the question to them. I can speak only for myself and answer in the negative.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. It is a follow-up, in a way, to the answer of the Prime Minister to the honourable member for Forrest. In view of the recent problems regarding an alleged lobbyist for a foreign country, will the Government consider United States or similar legislation requiring the registration of all those receiving benefits from foreign countries in exchange for trying to influence government policy on behalf of those countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Prospect touches on the most important aspect of this whole matter, and it is obviously one which honourable members opposite would be conversant with, that in the United States any person representing a foreign country and its interest in Washington-some States have complementary legislation-must register as an agent for that foreign country. That is one point.

ANSWER.PARA: Those of us who were in Canberra during the 1970s certainly would have witnessed the great blossoming of what we now term the lobbying industry. Most of those people who have been attracted to the industry have been ex-politicians , ex-public servants and ex-journalists. I suspect that honourable members on both sides of the House could claim not only to know many or all of them but also to have among their ranks some personal friends.

The problem of dealing with this question of lobbyists and their influence is not a singular matter. Some people, of course, wish only to have, and direct their attention to, influence on the Executive of government. In the United States, of course, there are great pressures and influences on the legislature. There the discipline of the party vote is not so great as it is in Australia. Problems associated with this situation are not encountered in this country. Nevertheless, we have witnessed a great number of people, some who work independently for a number of companies, and I suspect, in some cases, for foreign countries, as against others who may be classified as single industry lobbyists who represent, say, the Confederation of Australian Industry or some of the various chambers that have directors. Those problems also have to be looked at.

Let me give notice to honourable members-obviously discussions will be held on this matter before any final resolution is put to the House-that it is my hope to seek the views of Opposition members, who have been in government for a lot longer than we have and have had to deal more with lobbyists, because lobbyists tend to take a lot more interest in the Government than they do in the Opposition. It may be that the ranks of lobbyists will be added to now by the 18 Liberals who lost their seats at the last election. The other difficulty that we have in this House, as honourable members opposite would know, is that if an ex- member of parliament becomes a lobbyist he has access to the facilities of the House. It is an added advantage to anybody representing a company if he has access to members of parliament in areas which are set aside just for members of parliament so that they may carry out their work. Those sorts of things will also have to be looked at.

If honourable members opposite have any ideas on these questions that they think would be beneficial to the proper recognition of the role being played by these people in Australia, I would welcome the opportunity to discuss them. I hope that we never face the day when the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony) is a lobbyist here. I could not imagine him calling on us to give us his views and telling us a few things about what he wanted done for Australia. I think that he has done enough damage. However, as the Prime Minister has said, the matter is being looked at seriously by the Government, and it is hoped that we will be able to bring forward recommendations in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does he intend to continue to seek to intervene in Australian Broadcasting Commission programming, as it is alleged he did in his telephone conversation with Dame Leonie Kramer on 8 February? Does he agree with her account of that conversation, and, if not, in what respect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that on the day in question, following an approach to me by Senator Button and the putting before me of information in regard to events on an AM program of 4 February, and other matters, I rang Professor Kramer at about 4 p.m. and put to her my concern. Let me go to one aspect which personally concerned me-but which, I assure the Leader of the Opposition, was not the matter upon which I spent most time talking with Professor Kramer. On the AM program of 4 February, at the end of a long piece about the rather unusual events of the previous day, there was an observation, which obviously referred to me, that perhaps the Australian Labor Party may not be entitled for too long to proceed with some euphoria about the changed circumstances that flowed from the previous day, because there existed in a safe somewhere around the country something in the Costigan report involving me.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that, despite some contretemps which the Leader of the Opposition and I might have had which were not too pleasant, he would regard it as appropriate, if, say, in his case something had been said on an AM program which implied that there was something in the records of the Costigan Royal Commission adversely affecting him and he knew it to be untrue-as in my case I knew that what had been said was untrue-that a complaint should be lodged about it. But I point out to the honourable gentleman that that was one of a series of matters. It seemed to me that it should not go unchallenged that the person who set herself up as the spokesperson for the ABC should regard a comment about me as not a matter for concern but should regard an interjection put in by one of the staff of the ABC in regard to President Reagan as something about which to be concerned. In the context of that juxtaposition, I certainly strongly complained to her about what I perceived to be a rather unfair treatment of matters which were involved in the election. I spoke strongly about it and I said that that ought to change, that the coverage of the campaign should not proceed like that.

The report that Professor Kramer has given that I spoke to her and spoke strongly is accurate. I did. I repeat to the honourable member that I believe that he would regard it as proper, and certainly I think he would act in the same way, if a program on the ABC impugned his integrity as the AM program did mine. I think he would be very upset about it and I would certainly understand that, in the circumstances, he would strongly complain, as I did in the context of the other matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is it a fact that tensions have arisen between the Australian Government and the Northern Territory Government over issues such as the Yipirinya school and the proposed recreation lake in Alice Springs? What effect are these tensions having on the process of good government in the nation? What steps does the Government propose to take in view of these tensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is true to say that there have been some tensions. But due to an understanding now existing within the Northern Territory Government of the view of this Government that we will assert our constitutional prerogatives in these matters, not in any heavy-handed way but with a view to trying to produce rational and sensible approaches which are in the interests of all the citizens of the Northern Territory, many of the tensions have been reduced. In saying that I am bound to thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory for his very sound contributions and advice.

ANSWER.PARA: The two areas which at the moment are a matter of negotiation are, first of all , in respect of the proposal by the Northern Territory Government to create a recreational lake on the Todd River which would have the effect of flooding sacred sites-sites which are very important to local Aboriginal people. As a result of this proposal, I have written to Mr Everingham and suggested that there ought to be an inquiry to look at the environmental issues, an inquiry in which the Commonwealth, the Northern Territory Government and local Aboriginal people are represented. There has been a very positive response to that.

In respect of the Yipirinya school, for those honourable members opposite who perhaps are not aware of all the facts, I state that the matter is very close to resolution. The position in respect of this school is simply this: Some Aboriginal children were living in very difficult circumstances on the Todd River. These children simply could not fit into any of the existing educational institutions that were provided by the Government of the Northern Territory. As a result of the initiative of the local Aboriginal community, with the assistance of some churches and some teachers, their own independent school was established. This was a legitimate attempt by an Aboriginal community in Australia to provide educational facilities for its children, and I believe it deserves the encouragement and support of every honourable member in this House, particularly having regard to the commitments given by the Leader of the Opposition and some of the spokesmen opposite when they hawked themselves around Australia talking about their commitment to the rights of parents to educate children in the schools of their choice. How was it, when the Leader of the Opposition and his cohorts were making those statements, that the position in respect of this small Aboriginal school was such that the Government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a part had refused any funding at all for it? When the Aboriginal parents chose to exercise their legal rights and establish their rights by going to law, the former Minister refused that group of citizens any legal assistance at all and in fact told the Central Aboriginal Legal Service that if it provided these people with legal advice its funds would be cut off. Because I know honourable members are interested in the rights of parents to educate their children, I am happy to table the file so it can be examined by any honourable member opposite. If they do I think they will reach one conclusion. I would not be permitted to say that it would show the Leader of the Opposition and his cohorts as being the pack of political hypocrites that they are. Mr Speaker, as you would rule that out of order I will not say it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw; he has already said it.

—I withdraw that which I would not have said. I happily lay the file on the table so that honourable members, members of the Press and the people of Australia can see the kind of double talk and double standards which the Opposition and some of its spokesmen, including the Leader of the Opposition, are prepared to engaged in on an issue of such importance.
—Does the Minister for Communications share Senator Button's regrets about the appointment of Dame Leonie Kramer as the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission? I want a precise answer.
—I am not aware of Senator Button having expressed regrets that Dame Leonie Kramer had been appointed Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. What progress has been made on further Government declaration to extend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park? In particular, what is the state of negotiation between the Federal Government and the Queensland Premier?

—I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his excellent question. First of all, I welcome the call by the Premier of Queensland to declare the whole of the Great Barrier Reef to be within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Since 1975 when the Whitlam Government passed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, only 14 per cent of the reef region has been incorporated in the park. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has submitted to me in the last few days reports on the declaration of the majority of the Great Barrier Reef region not already in the park. The Government will be examining those reports and will decide on the declaration in the next week or so. Although the Federal Government is not dependent on the approval of the Queensland Government, and there are still some inshore areas which the Queensland Government is not enthusiastic about including in the park, it is my wish that these differences can be ironed out amicably. Thanks to the co-operation of the Queensland Government and the Premier's obvious enthusiasm for the park, the way has now been cleared--
—Consensus in action.

—That is right; bringing Australians together. The way has been cleared for 80 per cent of the reef to be included in the park. That is why I look forward with a sense of excitement to the forthcoming Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council meeting on June 3 in Townsville, in the honourable member's electorate. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and I will meet the Premier and the Honourable Tony Elliott, Minister for Tourism, National Parks, Sport and the Arts to discuss the future of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It is true that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism has had some differences with the Queensland Premier over Australian fauna and introduced species. But he has had some support recently from an American entertainer with regard to his dispute about koalas. At the conclusion of the meeting we shall undertake an inspection of the reef, including the Low Islets off Port Douglas in the electorate of the honourable member for Leichhardt and Lizard Island which is a continental island with fringing reef, where the research station is located. We shall also undertake an inspection of the northern parts of the reef .
—Will the Minister kindly table the documents from which he was quoting?
—Was the Minister quoting from a document on public affairs?
—I table the document.

—I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations: What action does the Government intend to take following the decision of the New South Wales shearers not to return to work as a result of this week's decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission concerning the wide comb shearing dispute? I wish it would show the same sort of concern about the shearers as Joh does with respect to the reef.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shearers' dispute is a dispute which the Government has viewed very seriously indeed. I have previously spoken to the House at Question Time about this matter. I indicated then that initiatives were being taken to try to bring the matter before the Arbitration Commission for rehearing and, indeed, subsequent to my statement to the House on Tuesday of last week, that application came before the Arbitration Commission on the initiative of the Australian Workers Union.

ANSWER.PARA: There was some negotiation in the suspension period during those proceedings earlier this week. The Commonwealth put various propositions to both parties-the AWU and the graziers. That resulted in an agreement between the parties which included agreement that there should be a return to work on the basis of the present award-that is, the award including the provision with regard to wide combs-that the union would have the right to direct its members not to use the wide comb, and that the employers would do nothing in this period to expand the use of the wide comb.

That agreement was reached by all parties and the Commission therefore left the matter in the position that it would hear a full case from the union if there was an immediate return to work. The union therefore recommended to all its branches that they return to work. As the honourable member has indicated one State, New South Wales, has not done so. I am pleased to say that all other States have seen fit to abide by the union recommendation and have returned to work. The Government regrets very much the decision of the New South Wales shearers not to abide by their union's recommendation to return to work. This means that this serious dispute continues in New South Wales.

I view that matter very seriously indeed and I will have meetings with the AWU in the near future to try to persuade the New South Wales shearers to take a different view of the position. It is not something that the Government will tolerate. We will not sit back and let the dispute go on as it is. We will take every step possible to get the New South Wales shearers back to work. If that happens, they will get the rehearing which the New South Wales branch officials passionately told me they desire. If the New South Wales shearers do not return to work, I can presume only that they are not so confident in their case. They expressed to me full confidence in their case. If they have that confidence, they should return to work without any hesitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations: What progress has there been in the Government's initiatives to achieve lasting stability in the building industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for that question. I have previously indicated to the House my great concern about the state of industrial relations in the building industry. A major element in that bad industrial relations situation has been the totally unacceptable behaviour of the Builders Labourers Federation of Australia. The previous Government responded to that behaviour some two years ago by moving to deregister the BLF. That case is still before the Federal Court. It is our belief that deregistration would be unlikely to result in a satisfactory resolution of the industrial situation in the building industry, simply because, even though deregistration would still be there, we would be likely to see a very bloody period of industrial disruption following that deregistration which may or may not result in some long term solution.

ANSWER.PARA: Having that view, when I became the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, I moved to establish a national building industry conference under ex -Commissioner Vosti. That conference had terms of reference which required it to try to obtain a binding agreement from the BLF in regard to future industrial behaviour and to abide by an agreed dispute settling procedure.

I am pleased to say that I have had a report from Mr Vosti which indicates that substantial progress has been made. The deregistration proceedings are to come before the Federal Court next Monday. When the Court resumes a statement will be made on behalf of the Commonwealth regarding the agreement which has been reached to this stage. It is not appropriate for me to reveal the details of that agreement before it has been revealed fully to the Federal Court, but it does provide the basis for real optimism about the BLF's future industrial behaviour.
I note also that when final agreement is reached it will enable the setting aside of the deregistration proceedings which have so far cost the Commonwealth almost $2m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper, I wish to add very briefly to an answer which I gave to the honourable member for Sturt.
—The Prime Minister may proceed.

—The House will recall that the honourable member for Sturt asked me whether, on 5 April, I had discussions with Mr Combe and a number of Ministers about uranium development. I said correctly, speaking for myself, no and that he would need to direct the question to others to find out about them.

QUESTION.PARA: I do not want to be in a position where anything I said could have left any misunderstanding in the House. I am reminded that on 5 April the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory came to see me. The arrangement was made through my office that I would see him on matters that he wanted to talk about. When he came into my office Mr Combe was with him. I had no idea that Mr Combe was coming with him. He came in there--

TALK.START.PARA: —He was there.

—I think the Leader of the Opposition is listening to me. I give the House and particularly the Leader of the Opposition my clear undertaking that Mr Combe was not involved in the discussions. He sat next to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.
—Oh!

—The honourable member will have the opportunity of checking that with the Chief Minister. I trust that the honourable member will get on his phone and do so. I want to assure the House that my agreement to see the Chief Minister was not involved in any arrangement that I had made with Mr Combe. At any stage when the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory wishes to have appropriate discussions with me, of course I will seek to make myself available.

QUESTION.PARA: I want to assure the honourable member for Sturt that the answer I gave was a totally accurate one. When I was reminded of the fact that it was on 5 April that I saw the Chief Minister and that Mr Combe was with him, I did not want to leave any misunderstanding or any possibility of giving a misleading answer to the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister has requested that all further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. The Leader of the Opposition has indicated to me that he wishes to correct a matter of fact. I indicate to other honourable members who have sought to make personal explanations that they will have the opportunity of doing so after the presentation of papers. I will allow the Leader of the Opposition indulgence to make the correction.

—I wish to advise the House that in my personal explanation earlier this morning, after detailing correctly the dates 21 April, 5 May and 10 May, I inadvertently referred at a later stage to 6 May. As will be clear from the earlier part of my explanation, this date was of course 10 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) said in answer to a question I asked today that I was not aware of the facts. I just wish to draw to the Minister's attention the remarks made by his supervising Minister as reported in the Australian dated Monday, 9 May. I will quote briefly from that article. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking after the program, Senator Button said that although he had-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mitchell was claiming a personal misrepresentation.
—Yes, my word was impugned, I think, by the Minister in regard to--
—I think the honourable member is going beyond the bounds of a personal explanation.
—Perhaps the Minister would like to read the article in the Australian .
—Mr Speaker, would you like me to clarify the matter?
—The Minister says that he can clarify the matter. I will grant my indulgence to do so.

—I did not indicate that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was not aware of a view having been expressed by Senator Button about the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I said I was not aware of it. How would I know what the honourable member was aware of? The honourable member is an extremely clever man and he obviously may have knowledge of which I am not aware. I indicated to the honourable member that if Senator Button had expressed the view attributed to him, I was not aware of it, not that he was not aware of it. He might be aware of anything.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, most heinously.
—I will allow the honourable member for Perth to make his personal explanation.

—I refer to an article which was published yesterday in the Australian. Honourable members on the Government side of the House would not, of course, recognise that newspaper as one being noted for its fidelity. The article is entitled 'Standing orders revoked by the member for Perth'. Your sensitivity, Mr Speaker, would, of course, allow you to appreciate the rather veiled reference to your ability to officiate in the House. But let me pass on to the substance of the article. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Ric Charlesworth will put aside his parliamentary duties for the next fortnight. Instead, the ALP member for Perth will attempt--

The article goes on to say that I will be involved in some sporting contest which is presently under way in Perth. I would like to inform all honourable members and all members of the Press Gallery that in fact I am here. I have no doubt that those of my constituents who are listening will also draw the same conclusion from my explanation. I reject the statement that I will put aside my parliamentary duties for the next fortnight. It is one that is without foundation and is very misleading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—At page 327 of House of Representatives Hansard of Thursday, 5 May 1983, and consequently in the Age newspaper of 9 May, there are published statements of an insulting nature to me, as expressed by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) on Thursday, 5 May. SPEECH.PARA: Since then I have been absent from the House and this is really the first opportunity that I have had to raise the matter. The statement questions first my intelligence, then my appearance and again makes what is a rather constant reference to the circumstances of my association with and involvement in the Liberal Party of Western Australia. I believe that the circumstance of intelligence can only be relative and I would imagine that the Minister concerned, considering his background, would accept an academic level as some measure; so I table for his information the highest educational certificate that I ever received, which was my leaving certificate. Unfortunately, I lacked the financial resources to do any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! May I remind the honourable member that he cannot table the document. He has read the fact into Hansard.

—The Minister might like to pick it up later and tell me whether his was better. Further, when we talk about appearance I guess that is also relative . I am skinny and scarred. I do not know whether it makes any difference if you are fat and flaccid.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to raise the issue of my involvement with the Liberal Party of Western Australia and remind the Minister and the honourable gentleman sitting next to him, firstly, that when I was endorsed by the Liberal Party, it certainly was not as a result of the efforts of some backroom operation. I had to stand for endorsement on two occasions.
Secondly, I would quite happily--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was because you told a fib the first time.
—It is amazing that the interjector--
—Order! I invite the honourable member to ignore interjections and deal with the matter that he is raising.

—The point has been made on numerous occasions in this place to try to denigrate me personally.
