SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) After Part VII, page 49, insert the following new Part (comprising clauses 77A to 77Q):
''PART VIIA-COMPLAINTS ABOUT PROGRAMS
Division 1-Preliminary
Interpretation 77A. In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears-
'Commission' means the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission;
'Commissioner' means a member of the Commission;
'complaint', in relation to a program, means a complaint as to any one or more of the following matters:
(a) that the program was unjust or unfair;
(b) that an unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of a person took place in the course of obtaining matter for inclusion in the program;
(c) that the program constituted an unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of a person;
'person affected', in relation to a complaint, means the person by whom, or on whose behalf, as the case may be, the complaint is made;
'program' means a broadcasting or television program of the Corporation broadcast or televised, as the case may be, after the commencement of this Part.
Division 2-Establishment, Functions and Powers of Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission.
Establishment of Commission 77B. For the purpose of this Act there shall be an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission
Functions of Commission 77C. The functions of the Commission are to consider and adjudicate upon complaints with respect to programs.
Making of complaints 77D. (1) a complaint made to the Commission shall be in writing and shall identify the person affected.
(2) Subject to sub-section (3), a complaint shall not be entertained by the Commission unless made by the person affected or by the person authorized by him to make the complaint.

(3) Where the person affected is a deceased person or is a natural person who for any reason is both unable to make a complaint himself and unable to authorize another person to do so for himself, a complaint may be made by the personal representative of the person affected, or by a member of his family, or by some other person or body closely connected with him.
Entertainment of complaints 77E. (1) The Commission is not required to entertain a complaint if, in the opinion of the Commission-
(a) the complaint is with respect to the broadcasting or televising of the relevant program on an occasion more than 5 years after the death of the person affected;
(b) the subject matter of the complaint is the subject of proceedings in any court;

(c) the subject matter of the complaint is a matter in respect of which the person affected has a remedy by way of proceedings in any court, and in the particular circumstances it is not appropriate for the Commission to consider the complaint;
(d) the complaint is frivolous or vexatious, or was not made in good faith;
(e) the person affected does not have a sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint;

(f) in the case of a complaint made under sub-section 77D (3) by a person other than the person affected or a person authorized by him-the complainant's connection with the person affected is not sufficiently close; or
(g) the complaint has not been made within a reasonable time.

(2) Where the Commission does not, for any of the reasons specified in sub- section (1), entertain a complaint, it shall, as soon as practicable and in such manner as it thinks fit, inform the complainant and the Corporation of the Commission's decision and of the reasons for the decisions.

(3) Where the Commission does not entertain a matter that is the subject of several complaints, sub-section (2) does not require it to notify each of the complainants if the Commission is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome to do so.
Consideration of complaints 77F. (1) Subject to section 77E before proceeding to consider a complaint, the Commission shall send a copy of the complaint to the Corporation.

(2) A complaint may be considered by the Commission at a hearing or without a hearing, as the Commission thinks fit, and, at a hearing, the Commission is not bound by the rules of evidence and may inform itself on any matter in such manner as it thinks fit.
(3) A hearing under this section shall be held in private, and each of the following persons shall be given the opportunity to attend and be heard:
(a) the complainant;
(b) the Managing Director or an officer of the Corporation authorized by him in writing for the purpose;
(c) any other person who, in the opinion of the Commission, is responsible for the making of provision of the program concerned.
(4) Where the Corporation receives from the Commission a copy of a complaint, the Managing Director shall, if so required by the Commission-

(a) make suitable arrangements for enabling the complainant and any Commissioner or member of the staff referred to in sub-section 77K (1) to view or hear the relevant program, or any specified part of it, if and so far as the Corporation has in its possession a visual or sound record of it;

(b) provide the Commission and the complainant with a transcript of so much of the relevant program, or of any specified part of it, as consisted of speech, if and so far as the Corporation is able to do so;

(c) provide the Commission and the complainant with copies of any documents in the possession of the Corporation, being the originals or copies of any correspondence between the Corporation and the person affected or the complainant in connection with the complaint; and
(d) furnish to the Commission and the complainant a written statement in answer to the complaint.

(5) Where the Commission proposes to consider a complaint, the Corporation shall, if so required by the Commission, arrange for one or more of the Directors, officers or employees of the Corporation to attend and assist the Commission in its consideration of the complaint.
Reports by Commission 77G. (1) Where the Commission has considered and adjudicated upon a complaint, the Commission shall furnish a report on the complaint to-
(a) the complainant or, if there is more than one complainant, each of the complainants; and
(b) the Corporation.

(2) Where the Commission has considered and adjudicated upon a matter that is the subject of several complaints, sub-section (1) does not require it to notify each of the complainants if the Commission is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome to do so.

(3) Where the Commission furnishes a report to the Corporation under sub- section (1), it may require the Corporation to publish, in a manner specified by the Commission, a summary of, and of its findings on, the subject matter of the complaint and may, if it thinks fit, require the summary to be in a form prepared or approved by the Commission.
(4) The Corporation shall comply with any requirements made of it by the Commission under sub-section (3).

Duty to publicize Commission and its functions 77H. The Corporation shall make ( by means of broadcasting or television or otherwise) regular announcements publicizing the Commission and its functions of considering and adjudicating upon complaints.

Delegation by Commission 77J. (1) The Commission may, by resolution, either generally or as otherwise provided by the resolution, delegate to a Commissioner or to a member of the staff referred to in sub-section 77K (1) all or any of its powers under this Part (other than this power of delegation and its powers to consider and adjudicate upon complaints and to furnish reports upon complaints).
(2) A power so delegated, when exercised by the delegate, shall, for the purposes of this Part, be deemed to have been exercised by the Commission.
(3) A delegation of a power under this section-
(a) may be revoked by resolution of the Commission (whether or not constituted by the persons constituting the Commission at the time the power was delegated);
(b) does not prevent the exercise of the power by the Commission; and
(c) continues in force notwithstanding a change in the membership of the Commission.
(4) Section 34A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 applies in relation to a delegation under this section as if the Commission were a person.

(5) A certificate purporting to bear the signature, or a facsimile of the signature, of the Chairman and stating any matter with respect to a delegation of a power under this section is, upon mere production, prima facie evidence of that matter.
Staff 77K. (1) The staff required for the purposes of this Part shall be persons appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922.

(2) The Chairman has all the powers of, or exercisable by, a Permanent Head under the Public Service Act 1922 so far as those powers relate to the branch of the Public Service comprising the staff referred to in sub-section (1) as if that branch were a separate Department of the Public Service.
(3) For the purposes of sub-sections 25 (5) and (6) of the Public Service Act 1922, the Chairman shall be deemed to be a Permanent Head.
Division 3-Constitution and Meetings of Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission
Membership of Commission 77L. (1) The Commission shall consist of not less than 3 nor more than 5 Commissioners.

(2) A Commissioner shall be appointed by the Governor-General on a part-time basis for such period, not exceeding 5 years, as is specified in the instrument of his appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment.
(3) The Governor-General shall appoint one Commissioner to be the Chairman of the Commission and another to be the Deputy Chairman of the Commission.

(4) The performance of the functions or the exercise of the powers of the Commission is not affected by reason that there is no Chairman or Deputy Chairman or by reason of the number of Commissioners falling below 3 for not longer than 6 months.

Remuneration and allowances 77M. (1) A Commissioner shall be paid such remuneration as is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal but, if no determination of that remuneration by the Tribunal is in operation, he shall be paid such remuneration as is prescribed by the regulations.
(2) A Commissioner shall be paid such allowances as are prescribed by the regulations.
(3) This section has effect subject to the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973.
Leave of absence 77N. (1) The Minister may grant leave to the Chairman to be absent from a meeting of the Commission upon such conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Minister thinks fit.
(2) The Chairman may grant leave to any other Commissioner to be absent from a meeting of the Commission upon such conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Chairman thinks fit.
(3) References in sub-sections (1) and (2) to the Chairman shall, if a Commissioner is acting as Chairman, be construed as references to the Commissioner so acting.
Resignation of Commissioners 77O. A Commissioner may resign his office by writing signed by him delivered to the Governor-General.

Disclosure of interests 77P. (1) Where a Commissioner has or acquires any interest, pecuniary or otherwise, that could conflict with the proper performance of his functions in relation to a complaint made to the Commission-
(a) he shall disclose the interest to the parties; and
(b) except with the consent of the parties, he shall not take part in any deliberation or decision of the Commission with respect to the complaint.
(2) Where the Chairman becomes aware that a Commissioner has, in relation to a complaint, such an interest as is mentioned in sub-section (1)-

(a) if the Chairman considers that the Commissioner should not take part, or continue to take part, in any deliberation or decision of the Commission with respect to the complaint-he shall give a direction accordingly; or
(b) in any other case-he shall cause the interest to be disclosed to the parties.
(3) In this section, 'party', in relation to a complaint, means the complainant or the Corporation.
(4) References in this section to a Commissioner shall, if a person is acting as a Commissioner, be construed as including references to the person so acting.
Termination of appointment of Commissioners 77Q. (1) The Governor-General may terminate the appointment of a Commissioner for misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.

These clauses basically put into the legislation, in place of the community affairs officers it is proposed that we have in this Bill, a complaints arrangement which is completely independent of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. When the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) closed the second reading debate, he said that there was confusion on this side of the House. I suggest to the Minister or to those who have advised him that he or they are the ones who are confused. During the second reading debate, I referred to the British Broadcasting Corporation complaints procedures and the formula it used. I pointed out that I thought that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation should adopt the same formula. I have in front of me a document relating to the British Broadcasting Complaints Commission. I acknowledge that it covers commercial and non-commercial broadcasting in the United Kingdom. It was made quite plain in the amendments that have been proposed and in the Opposition's approach that obviously it applies only to the ABC and, in commonsense, can only apply to the ABC because that is what this legislation is about. If one examines it further, one will note that in the legislation before us complaints can be made to community affairs officers only if there has been an error of fact or an invasion of privacy. The British Broadcasting Complaints Commission which commenced on 1 June 1981 in the United Kingdom can investigate complaints of unjust or unfair treatment in sound or television programs, unwarranted infringement of privacy in or in connection with the obtaining of material. If honourable members examine our amendment, they will see that basically similar words are used. In part, our amendment states that the program was unjust or unfair or that there was unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of a person. Today the question has been asked: How are these things defined? I point out to the honourable member who asked that question that the Complaints Commission structure has been operating now in the United Kingdom for a couple of years and obviously it is able to handle complaints concerning programs.

The main point I make is that the complaints procedures which were contained in the original legislation introduced by the previous government would have been passed by the Parliament before the date of the last election if the coalition Government had remained in office and an election had not been called. I say once again that those amendments are based on the experience of the British Broadcasting Corporation in the United Kingdom. I understand that, if the Australian Democrats had been given the opportunity in the Senate, they would have moved amendments basically identical to those the Opposition has moved here . Their amendments would have reflected the British Broadcasting Complaints Commission procedure.

I draw to the attention of all honourable members the very clear distinction between the legislation that the new Government has introduced, what we are suggesting and what we would have put in place if we had remained in power. The major difference is whether there should be an internal complaints procedure or an independent complaints procedure. In relation to the community affairs officers for whom this legislation provides, the Managing Director of the Corporation shall appoint community affairs officers in each State. In addition, the Managing Director shall appoint an officer of the Corporation-that is, an employee of the ABC-to be known as the Principal Community Affairs Officer whose duties will include the co-ordination of the activities of the community affairs officers. Other powers are given to the Principal Community Affairs Officer, including the right to decide whether a complaint is justified. In other words, the whole complaints procedure being proposed by the Government will be dealt with by officers within the ABC.

I wish to make two points in this respect. I recall honourable members on the other side of this House after asking how policemen investigate other police officers and how the people of this country or the people of a State can be shown that justice is being done when an internal inquiry procedure is being undertaken. I think that more than ever now, because of the attacks on the ABC by certain members of the Labor Government there has to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—I agree that the attacks were rubbish but, nevertheless, they were attacks. More than ever there must be independence so that complaints can be followed through and the people of Australia have to be able to see that there is independence. The only way that there can be justice for the ABC itself and justice for the people of Australia who pay for the ABC is to have a completely independent complaints procedure so that not only will justice be done but also will justice be seen to be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment. In relation to the question of complaints, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill 1983, without this amendment, is feeble to the point, as it were, of pointlessness on two grounds. The first, that of organisational grounds, has been covered by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). The Bill provides no independent or outside adjudication and no right of appeal. This is in contrast, for example, to what was proposed in the former Government's amendment to the original Act and in contrast to the British Broadcasting Corporation model. I remind the House that a person is disqualified from being on the complaints commission in the United Kingdom as long as he is an employee of the BBC or appears to be concerned with or has an interest in the preparation of programs. That is for the obvious reason that independence and the appearance of independence are of great importance. That provision is completely removed from this Bill. I have nothing further to add to what the honourable member for Murray has said about that point.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise another point which I think is important. It concerns the definition of 'complaint'. I raised this matter last night and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) interjected. I would like to deal with this now. The definition of 'complaint' in the former Government's Bill included inaccurate, unfair or biased programs. A complaint could be about bias or unfairness. In the new measure before the Committee, reference to bias or unfairness has been removed entirely. No complaint is to be permitted on the grounds of bias or unfairness. In other words, it is a nugatory proposal, a trivial proposal, whereas in the Bill proposed by the former Government-indeed, this applies to the BBC's arrangements and to the arrangements of any comparable country-one can complain on the grounds of unjust or unfair treatment in a program. The Minister last night intervened by way of interjection and said:
Would you like to define bias and unfairness?
Of course, that has an obvious, superficial and immediate appeal because people do disagree.

Nevertheless, the point I am making is that not only do other organisations such as the BBC solve this problem but so do the Minister and the Government because in clause 8 (1) (c) which outlines the duties of the Board, the Bill states:
to ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is . . . impartial according to the recognised standards of objective journalism; . . .

I put it to the Minister-I do not see how he can avoid dealing with this matter- that he cannot say that there is no such thing as unfairness or bias when every fool and his brother knows that there are such things even if they are difficult to define. The Minister recognises that fact. Clause 8 (1) (c) places a duty on the Board to see that programs are impartial according to the recognised standards of objective journalism. That duty is imposed upon the Board but when a citizen wants to complain he may not even complain in terms of the duties imposed on the Board. He cannot go to the community affairs officer and say that the Board has not carried out its duties of ensuring that the programs are impartial according to recognised standards of objective journalism. He can only complain about an error of fact-that a program got a date wrong, an initial wrong or something like that or that there was an invasion of privacy.

I have no complaints about the invasion of privacy provision. That is fine. But I object to deleting any reference to bias and unfairness when they are the main grounds of complaint about programs. This applies to commercial television and broadcasting as well as to public broadcasting. They are repeated and predictable. But even if they are not repeated and not predictable, the main grounds for complaint are bias and unfairness. The citizen is to be deprived of the right of complaining about that despite the fact that that right is incorporated in the statement of the duties of the Board. The amendment will meet that need. It deserves the support of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to take much time on this matter because it has been dealt with twice already-in the second reading speech and again this morning. I inform the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) that the question last night was not who will define what is unjust and unfair, but what the definition is. There has not been any definition come forward today as to what is unjust or unfair. The duties of the management of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in presenting programs in an impartial manner are entirely different matters to allowing people to make complaints on the basis of something being unjust and unfair. As this Bill now stands, the provisions cover these points: Inaccuracy of fact, the truth of statements which give rise to a complaint and invasion of privacy. As the honourable member indicated, there is no dispute about the latter.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most interesting aspects of the amendment is that it brings some consistency at least to the Opposition's argument. One of the objections to the amendment is the same objection as we and many other people had to the proposal that was put forward in the Bill presented by the then Government last year; that is, the fact that an outside body will control these sorts of matters so far as the ABC is concerned. We on this side of the chamber are prepared to allow the ABC to run its own affairs. That is one of the issues which have been discussed by honourable members opposite quite extensively over recent weeks when it has suited them. It goes to the basic argument that has been going on, that is, the question of the independence of the ABC. With the community affairs officers and the obligation on the national co-ordinator to report to the ABC on the officers' activities, we are confident that the complaints provisions which have been provided in this Bill will meet any concerns that the public has. The Opposition seems to have some fetish that for some reason we should take that away from the ABC.

As I have said over and over again in this debate, we have attempted to start down the long road of implementing the recommendations of the Dix Committee of Review into the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The handling of complaints within the ABC-as we proposed last year and as is now proposed in this Bill-is in line with the Dix report. For all of the reasons that have been pointed out, the amendment is not acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested to learn the problem the Government has with the definition of 'fairness' because my understanding is that the Government is looking very hard at whether there should be a fairness code for commercial radio and television. I think fairness and unfairness could easily be defined in such a code. I conclude by quoting from an answer by Senator Button in the Senate on Tuesday, which adds to the confusion that he seems able to create in the area of the Australian Broadcasting Commission at present. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the Australian Broadcasting Commission, as the national independent broadcasting service, makes statements which are untrue and defamatory of members of this Parliament, those complaints will be investigated by an independent officer . . .
I repeat:

. . . an independent officer and, if necessary, the ABC would be requested to retract. That is an appropriate procedure which is identical almost to the procedures of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Senator Button's understanding of the legislation is rather different once again from the responsible and, I believe, more accurate description which the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has been giving the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of untrue and defamatory statements being investigated by an independent person has been raised. Under the proposals regarding the complaints provision that we are providing, people will be appointed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Clearly if the complaints are not going to be investigated independently they will be investigated impartially. There is no doubt about that. We are not saying that someone will wander along to somebody in the office of the ABC and make a complaint and that is as far as it will go. We agree that the complaint has to be properly investigated. There does not appear to me to be any contradiction in that.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has a problem concerning definition . It may well be that the fairness code is a matter the Government will have to look at. Unlike some people who have this enormous confidence in their capacity to define these things, it will be a matter that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will look at. As I said earlier, it is not necessarily a matter we would have to be committed to as a government because the ABT has been asked to look at that fairness code. It may come back and say it is extremely difficult, for the sorts of reasons we have raised here today, but that is a matter we will look at when we get the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). The Opposition seems to have some paranoia about this clause. I suppose one should not be too surprised about that. Last week the Minister put before the House comments that the former member for Gippsland made about the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Mr Nixon said:

SPEECH.PARA: Never in its history will the ABC be under such close scrutiny as during the coming election campaign.

That was the 1975 election campaign. Mr Nixon tried to interfere in the affairs of the ABC on several occasions. Notwithstanding that, the former Government is back again trying to get passed several pages of amendments that will bring about a body to look into all sorts of complaints in regard to the ABC. One has to look at the ABC as a part of the whole industry. In the commercial industry if one has a complaint one goes to the station. Unless it is a monumental complaint that one is past the post with one does not really get anywhere. One then has to be shuffled off to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

Here the Opposition is asking for a body to be set up with all sorts of powers to look at all sorts of things in regard to the ABC, and I think it is ridiculous. I do not think one can look at one clause in isolation, as the Opposition has done. We must look at the whole Bill that we are introducing for the setting up of the Corporation. I think the Bill the Government has put forward is a very sensible one. All of the clasues are highly commendable. We will be rejecting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) raised the question of someone independent looking at a matter which was untrue or defamatory. Certainly that would be the case because that would not be a complaints procedure. The independent person who would be looking at that would, of course, not be within the context of this Bill. It would be a court, as has happened. At this stage we do not know the ultimate result of the case. That seemed to be the right which was being denied to the Premier of New South Wales when it was suggested that the action which he took should not have been taken. In fact if the ABC makes some statement on either television or radio that is untrue or defamatory, for example in relation to me, I do not think I would go to the Commissioner for Complaints whether in the context of this Bill or of an outside monitoring body that the Opposition obviously favours . I would certainly be going somewhere else. As far as that is concerned it would be an independent body; it would be a court.
—I thank the Minister for trying to help--
—The honourable member for Murray has spoken twice to the question. He cannot be called again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the last statements on this clause by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) have further confused the situation. He talked about an independent body. He said that it would be a court. Yesterday Senator Button, in another place, in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Commission said that the complaints would be investigated by an independent officer. The clause we are discussing today nowhere has a provision as to the definition of independence. I think we need to hear the Minister's views on that .

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button also says that the procedure-I assume that he is talking about the Government's Bill; we hope that he is-is almost identical to the procedures of the British Broadcasting Corporation. I should like the Minister's views on that, because the clause that the Government has presented is nothing like the BBC provisions in relation to the independence of the complaints officers. How will the complaints officers be independent? That does not appear from the legislation itself. What are the criteria of independence? There is no reference to those. What is the composition of this complaints procedure as compared with the BBC procedure? The Minister owes us an explanation, particularly as I understand that Senator Button is the Minister assisting this Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) cares to look at the clause on community affairs officers, clause 82, he will see that the appointment is by the Managing Director and that the complaint is referred to a community affairs officer in accordance with proposed subsection (1), which relates to an error of fact or an invasion of privacy. Clause 82 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a complaint is referred to a Community Affairs Officer . . . he shall, as soon as practicable after the complaint is referred to him, inquire whether the complaint is justified and report his findings to the Principal Community Affairs Officer.

The community affairs officers are within the ABC, the Managing Director's appointment of them does not mean that they are not independent on this issue. The fact is that the community affairs officers are going to examine complaints in an independent way. That is why complaints will go to them and not to management. That is the whole principle of the matter.

The honourable member for Higgins is now claiming that some answer that Senator Button gave in the Senate yesterday conflicts with that. No doubt one of his colleagues will be able to ask Senator Button what he meant. What was specifically in Senator Button's mind at that time is something that I ought not to be expected to be able to relay here today. I am not clairvoyant. That is a matter that can be questioned. But, as I say, the community affairs officers appointed by the Managing Director will be acting independently. They are not going to be told by the management of the ABC how to conduct the operation. They are appointed within the structure. What we are saying is that we do not want imposed on the ABC somebody from outside who is going to take over the complaints procedure, because we have confidence in the ABC conducting its own affairs in relation to complaints that will be made against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) said that he was not clairvoyant in relation to what Senator Button may have said in another place about the Minister's portfolio. However, I return to the point about independence. I admire the Minister's attempt today to define what independence means and what his colleagues, he thought, were saying in the Senate. But the point remains that, notwithstanding the Minister's hopes about the independence of the Principal Community Affairs Officer and of the community affairs officers, there is no provision in the legislation for independence in the sense that Senator Button mentioned in another place yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear to me that what the Opposition is looking for is an independent inquisitor to hear complaints against the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. From the previous Bill which the Opposition introduced last year, it is clear what it is after. The Opposition wants an inquisitor to be able to enter the homes of employees of the Corporation. That is quite clear, because--
—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are not discussing the Bill introduced previously. We are discussing the amendments that we introduced today, which are completely different.
—Order! The honourable member for Murray will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—For the information of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the reason I am drawing attention to the previous Bill is the fact that he, too, mentioned that Bill. I shall refer to just one or two of the clauses of that Bill, because they show what the Opposition is obviously after. Opposition members want inquisitorial powers over members of staff of the Corporation. Clause 84 of the previous Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner may administer an oath or affirmation to a person required to attend before him pursuant to section 83 and may examine the person on oath or affirmation.
Let us look at the clause 85, which the Opposition was proposing. That states:
For the purposes of an investigation under this Part, the Commissioner or an authorized person may, at any reasonable time of the day--
I wonder what that means-
enter any place occupied by the Corporation and may carry on the investigation at that place.

It is very clear what members of the Opposition are after. They want an inquisitor. They want to be able to put employees of the Corporation on the rack . We can see through this. It will not be approved.
Question put:
That the Part proposed to be inserted (Mr Lloyd's amendment) be so inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 4 May, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy) read a third time.
Address-in-Reply
Debate resumed from 10 May, on motion by Ms Fatin:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Stirling. I remind honourable members that the honourable member for Stirling is making his maiden speech and should be accorded the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -May I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and Mr Speaker on your election to the distinguished positions which you hold. I am sure that we on this side of the House are confident that the House will flourish and prosper under your leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General's Speech reflects the enormous trust and responsibility given to us by the electors of Australia. In this respect, I acknowledge with gratitude the trust and consideration given to me by the electors of Stirling. I want to say more about the electorate of Stirling shortly, but may I say at this point that I stand ready and am proud to represent all electors of Stirling in this, the Australian Parliament.

Mr Deputy Speaker, with my background previously in economics, education and industrial relations, and having had contact with business, government and union organisations, I am looking forward to using these skills in my efforts to represent the electorate of Stirling in the Australian Parliament.

It is important, Mr Deputy Speaker, to emphasise that the election of 5 March represented a significant departure for the Australian electorate. The electorate chose to move towards a more co-operative and humane set of policies, away from the more divisive policies of the past. I add at this point my particular appreciation to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for the effort that he gave in the electorate of Stirling to secure the vote that I obtained. I can assure the House that the vote we obtained in Stirling is a reflection of the support and trust given to the Prime Minister.

On the question of co-operation and leadership, I wish also to thank most warmly my family and my many friends and supporters who supported me most thoroughly during our 14-month-long campaign for the Federal seat of Stirling. Honourable members will understand when I point out that one cannot build co- operation and support without a loyal family and selfless friends and supporters . That I am here today is a recognition and acknowledgement of their contribution and the trust of the wider electorate.

I also add that members of the Government and of the Opposition have a collective responsibility-I emphasise that I believe we all have this responsibility-to ensure that the national crisis we face is resolved in the form of good government for all Australians. One thing that we gained during that 14 month long campaign was the knowledge that the people out in the electorate were saying that they did not want spectacles in the Parliament where we engaged in a lot of sideshows. They want genuine solutions to their economic and social problems. After the extended period of government under the previous administration, it is quite evident that we have to confront many problems, and it is our job to try to do something to resolve them. It is pointless for us simply to stay here and score points without attending to these major issues. To some extent the events of the last few days might reflect on that as well.

I cannot let this occasion pass without reflecting on the personal pleasure I gain from being the first Labor member to represent the Federal seat of Stirling since Harry Webb, who held the seat until 1972. Some honourable members here would remember warmly the contribution that Harry Webb made. One of the things that also have to be acknowledged in the game we are in is that many of us here had prior to our election candidates who, so to speak, ran the ball up for us. In this respect, in Stirling Mr Graham Reece and Mr Grenville Pitts had previously unsuccessfully contested the Federal seat of Stirling but to some extent they whittled away the vote of the Liberal Party.

During our campaign we had the opportunity to meet and listen to a large number of electors. Over 14 months one really does get that opportunity. One of the things I want to say in respect of the speech I am making today is that I believe my role in the Federal electorate of Stirling is to try to react to, reflect, and to some extent convey the aspirations and wishes of the electors of Stirling. That is a major responsibility because one thing that does happen in the process of government is that very often electors feel quite shut out of the whole process of government. The job of many of us here-there are many honourable members on the Government back benches-is to try to make sure that our electors are brought into that process of government. Therefore, I particularly want to talk about two themes in my speech. One is the theme of access and the other is the theme of participation. It seems to me that whenever we look at Australian society we are looking at two very key issues. I would like simply to read through these. There is clearly a demonstrated need to improve people's access to jobs, to housing, to financial stability and security as well as to social justice, educational opportunities and clean environment.

I now turn from the notion of people having access and look at the fact that people have a right to participate. One of the clear things in Australian society is that we must create opportunities for people to participate in employment, in housing, in education and in the conduct of their work place. I want to say more about that shortly. Particularly important is that women should be enabled to participate equally in society, as should people in the ethnic communities of Stirling such as the Yugoslav, Macedonian, Greek and Italian people. That is very important.

I emphasise the view again that I am conscious that as the representative of the Federal seat of Stirling I must be a person who affords where I can the opportunity for our electors to have access to me and thereby access to the Government, and also at the same time to participate in that process. That is a very serious and thorough process through which we must go. These goals of access and participation have been foundational in our whole campaign. We spoke to many thousands of electors and asked them their opinions. We surveyed them, knocked on their doors and spoke to them at shopping centres. Many of the things I am saying this afternoon reflect the observations that they made but also, obviously, they reflect the policy and philosophy of the Australian Labor Party and of the Government of which I am proud to be part.

I go on to talk briefly about the electorate of Stirling. It is a very interesting electorate. It contains suburbs that lie to the north of the city and stretch from the coastal areas of Scarborough, Wembley Downs, Trigg and North Beach through Innaloo, Karrinyup, Gwelup, Carine, Hamersley, Stirling, Balcatta, Osborne Park, Nollamara, Balga, Tuart Hill and Mirrabooka in the east. It has been said about this electorate that in many ways it is middle Australia. It certainly does have those characteristics but importantly, under the economic impact that we have recently experienced, it also reflects much of the poverty and housing problems, problems that women face and problems that migrant groups face. It is essential in our process of government that we do something to try to redress those problems. It is also, interestingly, the electorate which has the distinction of being the residential area of the new Premier of Western Australia, Mr Brian Burke, and of the previous Premier, Ray O'Connor. I know that the electors who live in Balga, where Brian Burke lives, are particularly proud to have their Premier living in their midst. In the whole change of politics in recent times one of the things that we are hoping to do in Australia is restore some pride and some dignity to people because I believe that some people, who have recently left this place, have sought to downgrade pride and dignity in the Australian society. The fact that many of us are here as new members is a reflection of the fact that we believe those values are important. I would like to re-emphasise that.

The electorate contains substantial numbers of people who have chosen to make Australia their home and the electorate is much the richer for their having joined us. I am privileged to have been welcomed by many of these people, among whom the late Herb Graham was a well recognised and worthy friend. I take particular pleasure in sharing the friendship of people such as Mr Len Girando, Alec Damos, Vic Radis, Sam Adamos, Mick Martinovich, Barry Udovich, Vladi Radalj and Sam Vincuillo. I also recognise the late Tony Marcon. I say this particularly because very often many of us make statements about the worth of people in other communities without being able to say whom it is we know, whom it is we relate to and why they are worthy. I choose to point out that there are many who are very worthy in those communities. We must ensure in our society that those who choose to join us are given the right to participate fully in the wider involvement of our community.

Another aspect of the electorate is the importance of small and medium business . The industrial area of Osborne Park, in particular, and all the service industries in the electorate have been particularly hard hit by the recession experienced by the Australian economy. Some of the responsibility for this can clearly be laid at the feet of the previous Government but, to be fair, other influences are at work. I go back to what I said before-our business here must not be to lay blame; our business here must be to offer solutions. I would like to direct many of my energies towards that. Importantly, the National Economic Summit Conference afforded the opportunity for many of us to look towards genuine solutions for these problems, particularly in industries such as metal fabrication, motor vehicles, market gardening and the electrical and general retail industries in the electorate of Stirling. I believe that we must come up with some real solutions to those industrial problems.

I turn now to the question of unemployment. As I have already remarked, this is a major issue facing the people of Australia and the electorate of Stirling. The policy pursued by what we might call the lamentable Fraser regime was designed to lay blame on the unemployed. It was also designed to lay blame on the education system. I think it is fair to say that there was a deliberate strategy to say that young people who could not get jobs were work shy-some people were known to use the term 'dole bludgers'-or that the education system had failed them because somehow it had not fitted them into the work place. But this completely slipped past the major question; that is, that somehow the society as a whole had failed young people. I think that is a clear recognition that we have to take. The fact that so many of us are members of parliament means that we must bear an obligation to young people to try to stop laying the blame at their doorstep and to try to offer some genuine solutions to their problem. If we were to approach the education system and the needs of young people with open minds we would cease laying blame and would begin to look for genuine solutions.

I might add also at this point that I believe that the role of education can be considerably advanced. Recently I worked in the arena of business studies. I found that was an area in which vocational education was particularly important, where people could be enabled to get jobs. I signal the feeling that I believe that the technical and further education system offers a great deal of future. I had the privilege of working in the educational system in New South Wales. I believe that there is a lot to be said for that system. It is also worth noting that in many of the major areas of Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth and so on, the suburbs that are very deprived are the ones from which many of those who enrol in technical and further education colleges come. If we have an obligation to try to open up opportunities and access and to give people the right to participate, it is in those suburbs that we must have an obligation to do our best. I believe we can do it.

Further to my theme on participation, I have a particular concern about the participation rates of young women in the tertiary education sector. I believe that one of the things that have happened in recent times is that young women have been led to believe that they ought not to have aspirations and that they ought to accept some of the blame for this economic damage and to curb, so to speak, their determination to get on. I believe that we have a major role to perform here. We have to make sure that that area of disadvantage is somehow remedied. In taking my point further, we as a government will pursue the theme developed in the Governor-General's Speech and in the National Economic Summit Conference communique to restore economic growth and stability so that all those people whom I have mentioned might experience reduced social disadvantages. The secret of the Summit was that it not only developed social, political and economic expectations about the proper and responsible role of government but also demonstrated that we in Australia can approach national problems in a bipartisan way. I believe that there is a clear message here for us and those who have gone before us.

Housing represents a major social and economic necessity. I believe that we must increase people's access to and participation in housing. I wish to cite some interesting and, I believe, very damaging figures on the housing circumstance in the Federal electorate of Stirling. Let us look at the area of tenancies. Of the current stock of tenants that the State Housing Commission in Western Australia has, 58 per cent, which amounts to 27,951 tenancies, are in receipt of rebates. Let me explain what that means. In order to qualify for a rebate in the State Housing Commission one must be getting a gross family income of $180 a week or less. Fifty-eight per cent of the people who are in Housing Commission tenancies in Western Australia are, therefore, on a gross family income of $180 a week or less. If we look at the current new tenancy rate-in other words, those who are coming into the system-we see that in the last year 84 per cent qualified for some rebate in terms of State housing. In other words, 84 per cent of the people who came into State Housing Commission tenancies in Western Australia in the last year were on incomes of $180 a week gross or less. If we look at that as an indication of poverty, we have a major and damaging issue to face. I repeat: It is not one with which we ought to start playing and say: 'Let us try to lay the blame here or there'. Let us at least recognise that that is the dimension of the problem which we face.

A solution to that problem, I believe, might well be to try to generate many more jobs and activities in the housing industry. In line with this, one of the recommendations I am making is that we try to extend the charter of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation so that we can provide insurance cover for those who borrow money. Currently the Housing Loan Insurance Corporation provides insurance cover for those who lend money. Clearly, if we were to extend that charter, many more people could get into the housing industry in terms of buying houses and we would certainly do much to increase jobs and people's access to housing.

I move now to access and participation in industrial relations. We were all heartened by the Economic Summit and the theme that it stressed. I think it is clear that already we have under way in Australia a deal of access and participation in industrial relations. However, might I add that we have a major role to play in terms of getting unions and employers more involved in the solution of major industrial problems. One of the grave problems of the past, as has been pointed out, was that many of those who sit opposite sought to enhance industrial conflict. Clearly, our job must be to try to resolve industrial conflict. The electors of Stirling, in fact, suggested that one of the major tasks that we must pursue is to try somehow to resolve industrial conflict. Incidentally, one of the things that does stand out in this connection is that some 94 per cent of those electors who were surveyed said that there ought to be price surveillance along with wage restraint. What they are after is the sort of equity that I have been talking about this afternoon, that is, a degree of equity in the industrial relations arena.

What we also need to do in terms of industrial relations in Australia is to advance the whole notion of what I would call project planning. When we develop major projects in Australia, we do not look simply at the engineering and construction aspects; we look also at the human aspects involved. We look at the access to child care in major development projects and we look at the array of social facilities to which people might have access. If we are sincere about this we will do much more to enhance the growth and development that is present, certainly in Western Australia, but it will be shared. People will have public equity or, if one likes, community equity in these major projects. We will not have the narrow and rather limited approach to projects which we have had in the past.

The way ahead is clearly indicated. With the development of new technology in Australia-we can talk about the new sunrise industries-I believe there is a way ahead. If we are to pursue the policies of co-operation with respect to these industries, much can be done. Clearly and obviously we underinvest in research and development not only in terms of the Government but also in terms of the private sector. The comparisons between Australia and other countries are not good. We must do more to try to get research and development pursued. We have many people who have had distinguished careers. We have many institutions which offer high levels of distinction in terms of their work. It is our responsibility to ensure that that is supported. I believe that we have a lot to offer the rest of the world.

In summing up, I draw attention to a matter which underpins all of which I have spoken, that is, the question of nuclear weaponry and the threat of war. We all have some access to the areas about which I have spoken. We can participate in and have a say in them. Now that we have done something major about changing government in Australia, we will get some responsible and reasonable decisions. But in the arena to which I have just referred, many of us are left out. Unless we face up to that question and unless we go about deliberately and humanely restraining the threat of nuclear weapons, all of which I have spoken before will be lost.

I am encouraged by the support and trust which we received in the election campaign. I am warmly encouraged by my colleagues in the Federal Parliament. I am certainly encouraged by the support which I have received from the electors of Stirling. I can only say that I look forward to the task ahead. With the support that my family has given and the support which I am getting here in the Federal Parliament I am encouraged in believing that with optimism and good sense we will overcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) on his thoughtful and constructive approach to the Address- in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech. I hope that his period as a member of this House will be not too long but that, while he is here, he can continue in this constructive fashion. Mr Deputy Speaker, I also congratulate you on your election to your high office. I wish you well in the performance of your difficult duties.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, in the Address-in-Reply debate, I wish to turn to the subject of health policy. His Excellency the Governor-General, referring to the Labor Government's intentions in the field of health, had this to say:

My Government will proceed to fulfil its undertaking with regard to the proposed Medicare arrangements, to ensure that the costs of health care in Australia are fairly shared and that proper health care is available to all.
The Governor-General went on:

My Government will end the existing fragmentation of policies and funding for the aged through the creation of an Office of Aged Care. The Government proposes to modify the present over-emphasis on nursing home care for the aged and improve the availability of hostels and community care services.

Dealing with the second paragraph first, let me say that the Opposition supports the creation of an Office of Aged Care, which was well under way during the period of the Fraser Government, and was announced formally in Mr Fraser's policy speech. The Opposition also supports the objective of improving the distribution of taxpayer funds for aged care across the spectrum, with additional emphasis on hostel and home care. However, I should point out that the flat statement that the creation of the Office of Aged Care will end the fragmentation of policies and funding for the aged is typical of the sweeping statements made by this Government that are misleading if not downright deceptive.

The truth is that the creation of the Office of Aged Care will be but the beginning of the difficult process of co-ordinating policies at the Federal level only and, even there, exceptions will have to be made for war veterans. It will not, for example, end the inconsistencies between Federal and State policies, or the difficulties experienced by voluntary bodies and the private sector in the provision of aged care. The incoming Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) will have the benefit of studies commissioned by the Fraser Government to assist him in the resolution of these immensely difficult problems which I regarded as the most complex in the health field during my period as Minister for Health. It does not help the present Government to begin by raising expectations well beyond its capacity to deliver, as it does in the wording of the Governor-General's Speech.

However this instance of hyperbole is trivial when compared with the outright deception contained in the policy speech of the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke ) when he proclaimed in Messianic terms that 'nine out of 10 Australians will pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families'. Even allowing for the literal impossibility of this claim, in that two out of 10 Australians already pay nothing for hospital and medical care, and taking the charitable view that what the Prime Minister meant was that of the eight out of 10 Australians currently required to make some provision for their hospital and medical care, nine out of 10 will pay less under Labor, the assertion is demonstrably false. The present Minister himself gave the lie to the Prime Minister's claims when he said in a document distributed privately to Australian Labor Party members in January 1983:
For those who elect to pay the health levy only-nine out of ten will pay less or continue to receive free services under Labor's Health Plan.
He went on:

For people desiring extra private cover in a public hospital the total contributions (health levy plus private hospital insurance) under Labor's plan will still be less for approximately three out of four Australians than the after-tax cost of similar cover under the present scheme.

The question I ask is: Why did the present Minister for Health countenance a claim in his leader's policy speech that was demonstrably false? Was he excluded from the preparation of the health section of the speech? If so, why did he not seek to explain publicly the discrepancy between the Prime Minister's claim and his own briefing to his colleagues? If he was consulted on the wording of the policy speech and condoned the use of deceptive and misleading words in that speech he has a lot of explaining to do to this House and the Australian people. Clearly, with this Government, it is necessary to examine the fine print.

Of course even the claim that three out of four will pay less is over- optimistic, to say the least. During the election campaign I drew attention to a simple error of arithmetic in Labor's costings of $680m, in that it had assumed that it could make use of the money released by abolishing the income tax rebate on health insurance during the first year of the scheme. Labor had forgotten that rebates are paid out in the tax year following the year they are earned, and therefore during the first year of Medicare they would still be liable for the tax rebate from the previous year. The present Minister fudged the issue by talking about the introduction of Medicare in January, thus spreading the miscalculation over two years, but a gross oversight it remained. In any case the starting date has now extended to February and may well extend further.

Another aspect of the costings I questioned was the administrative cost, which had been estimated at an additional $25m in the first year. A paper presented in March 1983 by the Health Insurance Commission-Medibank Private-states:
. . . in the first year, the additional administrative costs to be incurred by the Commonwealth in respect of the Medicare program will be of the order of $75m .

Thus, administrative costs are likely to be three times the original estimate, a trivial matter perhaps to the socialist reformer but an extra $50m to the person paying taxes. There are other aspects of the costings about which I have grave doubts too, but these two examples will serve to illustrate that the initial cost estimates of this scheme, despite the lengthy consideration the Minister claims to have given them, are yet another Fabian fantasy. What this means is that the proposed one per cent levy on incomes, increased from the 0.75 per cent of an earlier forecast, will not be enough to finance the scheme. Additional sums will be required from general tax revenues, making the levy itself merely an artificial basis for false comparisons of cost with that of the existing scheme.

Let us make no mistake about this. The introduction of this new means of financing will not reduce the nation's health bill. It will, however, disguise the real size of it, and in so doing make it easier for providers and patients alike to expand it at an undesirable rate. So much for the Prime Minister's false policy speech claim that will dog this Minister for Health throughout his term of office. I will be watching closely as the sums unfold to document the full extent of this falsehood and expose it to the public gaze.

Let me now return to the first paragraph on health in the Governor-General's Speech, which refers to the introduction of the Medicare program. In response to my criticisms of this program the Government will no doubt claim that it has a clear mandate to introduce such a scheme, on the grounds that it has been proposing it for some time under the label of the Hayden Health Plan, and although it eschewed the equally alliterative attractions of the title 'Hawke Health Plan' in favour of the term 'Medicare', it remains nothing more than a revival of the same old Medibank that was peddled in 1972 and implemented so disastrously in 1975.

But despite the claim of a mandate, despite the long period of earnest salesmanship by the Minister for Health, and despite, it must be said with humility, the warnings put out by previous health Ministers, the public has not a clue what is in store for it under Medicare. In a survey conducted by Morgan polls 12 months ago, 78 per cent of those polled did not know what the Hayden Health Plan was all about. It is my belief that they still do not know. So much for the mandate.

So let us examine exactly what it is that we are about to have thrust upon us. Why should we be embarking on fundamental and disruptive change to our national health program at this time, particularly when there is a need to concentrate on the key economic issues, such as unemployment? What substantial benefit will there be for the Australian people that would justify this change at this time?

In the months ahead, the Opposition will demonstrate that if change is required in health care policy and practice in Australia, and I believe it is, the change by the Government is in exactly the wrong direction. The Minister often refers to Canada as a model for the ideal health scheme. After a decade of operation, the Canadian scheme is breaking down. We are about to repeat Canada's error despite 10 years of experimental evidence that indicates failure. We shall show that the Government is about to follow a profoundly mistaken course, which if implemented according to plan, will cause deep concern and dismay to patients, providers and taxpayers, and necessitate even more difficult corrective action than we were obliged to undertake after the last Labor health experiment.

What then is wrong with Medicare, the scheme with the deceptive package and soothing name? Firstly, it will cost more than is claimed, even if the levy is set at the one per cent promised. Costs not covered by the levy will be met from higher taxation or higher deficits which have much the same effect on the taxpayer in the end. I have already given two examples of high costs, and will identify the remaining examples as soon as the detailed scheme is announced by the Government.

Secondly, contrary to the Government's claims of greater simplicity, the scheme will in fact be more complicated for the majority of those currently insured. Instead of one-stop shopping with the one health fund, a person not content with basic cover-that is, without choice of doctor in a hospital, to take the simplest example-will need to shop at two places: Medicare for basic cover and a private fund for the extras. More than half of those currently insured do insure for extras, so far more than half the scheme will be more complicated, not less.

Thirdly, it will damage to a much greater extent than have previous government interventions, the ideal of private professional medical practice. The Government is already a disturbing third party to the transaction between the professional person, the doctor, and the client, the patient. The increasing presence of the Government in the surgery has had a demoralising and in some respects corrupting effect on this relationship. Evidence of this has been presented to the Public Accounts Committee in its recent inquiry. Under Medicare , the Government will take a giant step down this road by making it possible for doctors to bulk bill the Government not only for pensioner health benefit and health care card holders but for all patients. If the doctor is prepared to accept 85 per cent of the schedule fee, the patient will have a so-called 'free' service.

The implications of this proposal might not be clear at first sight, but they are far reaching. Patients will be encouraged by this anti-private-practice Government to demand that their doctor bulk bill. For most patients the doctor will not be obliged by law to comply, but he or she will be under pressure. Pressure will be applied through the ban on gap insurance, that is, the capacity of the patient to insure for the 15 per cent gap between the schedule fee and the amount paid by the Government for each consultation. With no gap insurance allowed, with the prospect of bad debts arising from the non-payment by the patient of the 15 per cent difference between schedule fee and government reimbursement and the threat of losing patients to nearby doctors who will bulk bill, doctors will be sorely tempted to give in and join the Government payroll.

If they do, they will be sounding the death knell of private medical practice, and will be threatening the long term quality of health care. Bulk billing encourages the overuse of medical services. It will clog surgeries with those not truly needing assistance to the disadvantage of those in genuine need. It will encourage the less scrupulous practitioners to provide unnecessary services . And it will place the medical practitioner in almost total bondage to the Government, which will then tighten the screw. I hope that the Australian Medical Association and other professional organisations will conduct a major campaign to alert their private practice members to the dangers of bulk billing for the general patient.

Fourthly, it will place additional strains on an already stretched public hospital system by discouraging the use of private hospitals. Not only does Medicare reintroduce the unfortunate concept of so-called 'free' public hospital treatment without income or means test, but also it loads the dice heavily against private hospitals in the competition for privately insured patients. There are heavy disincentives under Medicare against private hospitals in this proposed insurance and subsidy arrangement, and the proposal to provide the private hospital bed subsidies through block grants to the States will encourage Labor State governments to pursue their own vendettas against private hospitals. As public hospitals are already suffering queuing problems, they will be placed under further strain with the new weight of numbers wishing to transfer from private hospitals. It is ridiculous that privately financed facilities should be thrust into idleness at a time when every public dollar is being stretched to the limit.

Before leaving the subject of public hospitals I should draw attention once again to the plight of Queensland, which already has a 'free' public hospital system. Queenslanders will be forced to pay a new levy for services they already receive free. After this outrage was pointed out by the Queensland Minister for Health, Mr Austin, and myself during the election campaign, the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) made a hasty promise in Brisbane to make up the difference with a special grant. On my figures it would need to be at least $70m, as that is the amount that Queenslanders would lose in the first year alone under the scheme.

Fifthly, the centralisation of all basic insurance under Medicare will increase costs and throw thousands of private health insurance fund employees out of work . In what must surely be one of the craziest acts of a government faced with high unemployment, Medicare will take away over 60 per cent of the business of the private health insurance funds, that concerned with basic insurance, and leave them with the scraps of 'extras' insurance. Not only will this action throw thousands of employees of the funds out of work, but it will also make the 'extras' insurance more costly pro rata than it now is because of the smaller scale of operation of the funds. The private funds have offered to operate the basic insurance of Medicare on an agency basis at good non-profit private enterprise rates, but the Government seems hell-bent on transferring this function to the more costly public sector, in line with its socialist inclination to have everything run by the Government. As we all know, private enterprise can do much better.

Today I have in the time available been able to give only a broad outline of these profoundly mistaken proposals. I shall, in succeeding weeks and months, expose their fallacies in more detail. At the same time I shall be examining afresh the Opposition's approach to the problems of health care, in both its preventive and delivery aspects. As Labor takes an historic-to use the Prime Minister's favourite adjective-backward step, we shall be determining new policies that will take health care forward on the basis of individual choice, high quality, restored professionalism and greater encouragement for the private provision of services. Our aim will be to improve the standard of public and private provision alike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Perth I remind the House that the honourable member is delivering his maiden speech and should therefore enjoy the usual courtesies. I call the honourable member for Perth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I congratulate you on your appointment. I wish you well in the execution of what is a most responsible position. I trust that you will convey my congratulations to Mr Speaker also.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a tendency for traditional thanks to be glibly uttered by speech makers in many forums. What I would ask is that Australian Labor Party supporters appreciate the depth of my gratitude for their efforts to secure my election to this Parliament. It is my task to justify their faith, efforts and idealism. If we accept that a political maiden is someone new, fresh and untried I would fall into that category. I earnestly believe that, as a maiden performer , I can bring to my electors a fresh approach and a new vigour. To be untried and ultimately succeed is preferable to being seen to have tried and quite obviously failed. My electorate has clearly perceived that to be the case in its assessment of the defeated Fraser Government.

Fundamental to the task of solving the problems of Australia in general and my electorate in particular are the issues of true democracy and the restoration of economic growth. That our system of democracy is superior to many others is incontestable. True democracy underpins every activity pursued by this Parliament. The electorate of Perth is not anywhere near as well served as it should be in this area. The same can be said for the nation as a whole.

In my electorate nearly 1,500 people voted informally on 5 March. Australia- wide that represents more than 150,000 Australians whose votes did not count, Australians whose votes in most circumstances were disallowed because of technicalities. The situation regarding the Senate is a travesty of democracy and is much worse. Optional preferential voting, the nomination of political parties on ballot papers and perhaps the use of new technology in time would make for a fairer and simpler voting system. In Western Australia and Queensland we still struggle under the confusion of dual rolls for the State and the Commonwealth. The state of these rolls is a cause of great concern. However, more so was the coalition's blatant use of political power to close the rolls 24 hours after it called the last election. Hundreds of thousands of Australians were thereby disenfranchised. We must legislate to ensure that in the future the rolls remain open for one or two weeks after the calling of an election. Young people, country people and many transient flat dwellers deserve most consideration in this regard. The right of Australians to vote must be clearly established. My electorate contains large numbers of migrants, who almost invariably are confused as to their voting privileges. We need to communicate better with these Australians.

Finally, my electorate contains many hospitals, hostels, homes for the aged and nursing homes. There is an urgent need for mobile polling booths. The depoliticisation of postal voting is essential. Electoral officers rather than political parties should have responsibilities in this area. We will thus improve the conduct of our democracy and eliminate the abuses that presently occur. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has set in motion a joint select committee to investigate electoral reform. I applaud his initiatives. Honourable members on both sides of this House should see the fairness and good sense of such an approach.

Competent and imaginative economic management will be fundamental to providing us all with the means to exercise the liberty and implement the reform that we all see as attainable and desirable. A misguided monetarist approach destroyed the capacity of our economy to grow. The short term reactionary decisions of the past were often without direction or useful economic purpose. Unquestionably, it will be extremely difficult to chart a course of economic management that will be smooth sailing. Many of my colleagues will, I am sure, address the complexities of the economy. However, I would like to tackle one of the more vital areas of this whole question, one which has far-reaching consequences for our country, our future and, especially, our children's futures.

Manufacturing and primary industries, service functionaries and mining are the traditional areas of our economic base. The future of many of these areas, and many new areas, will depend on our ability to adapt to and embrace new technology. But more important than adaptation will be our commitment in research and development to the skills and minds of our fellow Australians, a commitment to our advancement and initiative. The ramifications go throughout the whole structure of industry, the economy and industrial relations. A well known lyricist of the 1960s and 1970s wrote that 'the times they are a changing' . Some of his words should echo in this House and in another place. He said:
Come senators, congressmen, heed ye the call, Don't stand in the doorway, don't block up the hall, For he that gets hurt will be he who has stalled.

I submit that this country has stalled. In many areas Australia's industrial base has barely changed since the 1950s. The steel industry has the technology of the 1950s. No wonder we cannot compete! We were on the winning side in 1945, but how do losers like Japan and Germany look now? As the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) pointed out so eloquently yesterday in answer to a question from the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi):
. . . of 24 nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Australia ranks twenty-third, and a poor twenty-third at that.

He was referring, of course, to two indices, the value of high technology exports and the ratio of imports over exports. Our expenditure on research and development each year averages about half of that being spent by ten other nations of comparable affluence. Almost without exception high technology industries are in foreign hands. Ad hockery in decision making by successive governments-I point out that for 30 of the last 33 years they have been conservative governments-shortsightedness with regard to research and development, the extent of foreign ownership and a less than full commitment to education are among the reasons for this. I am not suggesting for a moment that we can compete in every area of new technology or scientific research, but if we choose our mark we can succeed in many different projects. The choice is very clear. We can remain the users, the buyers, the installers and the quarriers or we can commit ourselves to broadening the base, scope, efficiency and self- reliance of our economy. To be sure, there will be risks, but the greatest risk will be not to act and to do so will be to accept economic regression and eventual collapse.

It is important that we plan our future very carefully. I will give an example: In 1981-82 Australia bought $410m worth of computers from overseas. Over the last three years we have spent more than $1 billion buying computers overseas. The ratio of imported to locally made computers and microprocessors overwhelmingly leans to the former by 30:1.
