We are exporting jobs overseas. Unless extraordinary initiative is shown by Australian governments, business and scientists in the next 15 years, it is unlikely that computer assembly will be a major employer here in Australia. I add that it is anticipated that the market will expand rapidly. The Government's role must be to monitor changes and anticipate trends. Using this information, we can suggest appropriate new technologies and expand our base where desirable. We should aim to expand in areas that have good employment prospects and are relevant to Australia's condition, culture, ecomony and environment.

Computer hardware is an area in which we may have missed the boat to some extent, but the production of software is an area that is much more labour intensive and for which there is a great demand throughout the Pacific basin. We have a major language advantage over our Asian neighbours and certainly this is a very attractive area for expansion.

Biotechnology is an area about which we often hear the Minister for Science and Technology talk. It has a strong skill base in Australia and the prospect of being a great growth area in the 1980s. Australia has to be there, get involved, support and encourage financially these frontier areas. The offshoot of success in this area could be vital to our industry, primary producers, mining, medicine and public health.

In Western Australia research on genetic engineering is presently being carried out. It uses microbes produced by cloning deoxyribosenucleic acid-this process is part of the so-called recombinant DNA technology. These microbes might be able to clear up industrial waste, play a role in extracting metals for industrial purposes, unlock a cure for jarrah dieback, or help create a new strain of wheat. I am sure honourable members from the National Party would appreciate that.

Development of water treatment and water recovery systems is vital to every State in the Commonwealth. Perhaps we should exclude Tasmania from this statement. It seems to have too much of the stuff and it seems intent on submerging itself in a proliferation of man-made lakes. But again, biotechnology is providing answers that are vital to water supply problems. Communications technology is an area needing urgent development. Scientific instrumentation, lasers, medical technology, industrial ceramics-the list goes on and on. All offer opportunities for investigation, expansion and development. All of this, of course, is underpinned by two key elements. The first is a fundamental commitment to research, development and education. The Government must and will expand research and development and assist in providing venture capital where required to new high technology enterprise.

In the area of education, Australia has been sadly left behind. Seventy per cent of American, Canadian and Japanese children complete high school. Alas, the figure in Australia is about 35 per cent. We have about half as many young Australians completing tertiary studies as in those countries. Our tardiness in the area of education will greatly hinder the restructuring of the work force which must take place if we are to develop, remain competitive and expand. A bright light on the horizon is the planned allocation of funds to provide secondary schools with computers. Of course, Australian hardware must be used. It is to be hoped that in the future our total commitment to further equality and advancement in education will have its rewards in the long term.

The second element which underpins our embracing technological changes is the planning that must take place. In consultation with industry, workers, unions, scientists and, most importantly, the public in general, technological advancement must be planned so as to reduce undesirable effects. Changes which are too rapid can completely disrupt the whole structure of the work force. The questions of job sharing, working hours, early retirements, incentives for increasing participation of young people, and retraining must be debated and solutions found. The greatest challenge between now and the year 2000 will be to institute changes in a planned and balanced manner, to be selective and aware when we make planning decisions. The right decisions can mean the creation and generation of wealth, new employment opportunities, increased productivity in established areas and expansion into new areas of expertise. Again, I quote from the Minister for Science and Technology in the answer he gave yesterday in the House:

Science and technology is the greatest single factor in promoting high growth rates in modern economies. . . . New high tech industries . . . are not just valuable in themselves; they provide essential forward and backward linkages with our existing industrial structures which must update and diversify if they are to meet murderous competition overseas.

We must accept this challenge, anticipate the problems and meet them face to face with humane and realistic solutions. Success in the areas of our democratic reform and economic management will provide the impetus for the pursuit of the great social measures which can benefit this country. Education will play a vital role, as I have already outlined.

Health policy is an example of what we must tackle as a basic priority, even though the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) just minutes ago said that this is not a basic priority. It is an issue fundamental to the well being of all. For the past seven years we in the profession have endured five different health schemes that have been confusing, complicated, inequitable and discriminatory. No government should countenance the fact that approximately two million Australians are not covered by health insurance. It has been a conscious decision for some to gamble on good health. Unfortunately, for most people such gambling has been an economic necessity. I commend the concept of community sharing of the health burden and utterly reject the user or 'sick' pays philosophy of the former Government. Our Medicare proposal will restore equity, simplicity and universality to health care. Most Australians expect that their health insurance should cover the costs of health care and many recoil in horror at the extra outlays often incurred.

The whole question of doctors' fees, Commonwealth schedules, Australian Medical Association lists and pharmaceutical benefits must be examined and brought up to date. I might add that such an examination must take place with the profession, and I commend the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for the attitude of co- operation that he has established with the medical fraternity. Medifraud must be examined and action must be forthcoming. Criminal fraud is deplored by all Australians and the medical profession is not immune. The delicate situation of overservicing must come under scrutiny. Again I emphasise that the medical profession must be privy to any assessments. This delicate balance between overservicing and careful medicine is very complex.

Perhaps, however, the areas of greatest need lie outside the realms of doctors' services and therapeutic medicine. Our aging population, and one which increasingly creates its own ills, leaves us with many new challenges. Rehabilitation and prevention are key areas for action. Community-based nursing and health care are essential and of rising importance. Chiropody, physiotherapy , dietetics, occupational therapy and many other areas of care will be enhanced, encouraged and made available by the establishment of community health centres. The Mayo Clinic, perhaps the most famous centre of advanced medical science and research, has in its midst a community health clinic. The everyday problems of medicine cannot be forgotten. We will also emphasise the development of a community care program to provide support for those aged people who wish to remain at home. All honourable members have no more precious gift than that of health. The Australian Parliament has the capacity and obligation to provide for every Australian equal opportunity for adequate health care.

Finally, I wish to make one broad comment with respect to my electorate of Perth. The most outstanding demographic feature of the Perth electorate is that it contains the largest concentration of migrants in Western Australia. The decision to migrate has often resulted from much deprivation and difficulty. Many have come here as refugees because of war, famine or political persecution. Others are in Australia to be reunited with their families. Whatever the reasons , these people represent one of the most socially needy and disadvantaged groups . Their unemployment is higher and the problems associated with beginning again in a new country are many. Special assistance is required for language study and teaching. Counselling and services with regard to unemployment and social welfare are vital. We must not fragment these Australians. It is their inalienable right to pursue their cultural heritage and, in so doing, they will continue to enrich the whole cultural framework of Australia.

My electorate and in fact all Australians are looking for a long term approach to the issues and the problems that confront us. I have used my time today discussing just some of those problems which, in my view, are central to those whom I represent. Australians want and deserve to have a say in our democratic process. Their capacity to vote formally, their eligibility and the value of their vote must be simple and just. They deserve equality of opportunity in education, health care and social welfare. They deserve a planned approach to the new challenges in our economy. They do not want nor do they deserve division , political expedience and ad hockery. The Government's mandate is very clear. The Governor-General has outlined the program succinctly. I, along with fellow supporters of the Government, will strive conscientiously to give Australians a better democracy and greater equality of opportunity and direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to compliment the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), who has just completed his maiden speech, and the many other honourable members who have made their maiden speeches in this debate. Their idealism is refreshing and is to be encouraged. I hope it is not too quickly dimmed. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I convey my congratulations to the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) on his election, unopposed, to the high office of Speaker of the House of Representatives. I recall, as other members do, his previous occupancy of the office of Chairman of Committees and Deputy Speaker during the previous Labor Government and the occasions since then when he has acted as Deputy Chairman of Committees. In all of those offices his capability and fairness has been evidenced clearly and consistently. We wish him well.

SPEECH.PARA: I add my congratulations to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your election to the office of Chairman of Committees. Indeed, in many debates when I was a Minister in charge of piloting legislation through the Parliament and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, were chiding my political philosophies you nevertheless declared a number of times that I was a nice bloke. I thank you for that. I believe you too , sir, are a nice bloke and I wish you well. May I further say, as other members have said previously, that the previous Chairman of Committees, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), filled that office with great distinction. His outstanding capacity, impartiality and his delightful sense of humour added status and prestige to that office. He has, I am pleased to say, earned the respect and, I believe, the admiration of honourable members on both sides of the House. I would like to add my tribute to his splendid contribution.

The opening speech by the Governor-General at the assembling of a new parliament is necessarily a broad blueprint of the direction proposed by the elected Government. Precision and detail is supplied as the foreshadowed legislation itself is subsequently presented to the Parliament. The program, however, in many instances is disappointing. It commences with excuse and apology. All the problems of unemployment, inflation and recession which in its policy speech the Australian Labor Party said would be remedied virtually overnight are now given as the very reason why the Government's promises will not be fulfilled. In the history of Australian government there has never been so rapid a turnaround. Taxes which were to be so definitely reduced in February' s manifesto are now predicted to increase. The Budget deficit which, in February , was not at all important-the Labor Party claimed that as a stimulus it could be increased for the nation's benefit-is now presented as disastrous and as the reason that the program, the mandate, has been so quickly abrogated.

In Opposition in this place, day after day, we saw the Labor Party blame the then Government for the nation's ills. As the Westpac Banking Corporation review says, it is now a matter of facing up to reality. That is a good review. It is rather kind to the Government, I must admit, but it has got some good common sense in it. The principles espoused in it will be neglected by the Government to its detriment and at its peril. We knew when we were in government that the rate of unemployment was unacceptably high. The then Opposition said that we should and could create jobs. Scenario after scenario was painted involving massive expenditure on government job creation schemes. What a difference now.

Small business, the manufacturing industry and the private sector were depicted as the villians making massive profits. The then Opposition conceded no blame to the escalation of wage and salary demands or the impact of deep world recession. Now it sees that crucial to recovery and reconstruction is the development of a strong, competitive manufacturing industry. Well, the Australian Labor Party has learned something. Mention of small business was made in the Governor-General's Speech, but only just. Small business was allocated four and a half lines in a speech of 15 pages which magnanimously recognises the vital contribution of the small business sector to the Australian community. However, in spite of all the election campaign blandishments this gives little comfort and little ground for any expectation that this section of the community which provides the vast majority of Australian jobs will not collapse yet under escalating costs, union demands which it cannot afford and increased taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet they didn't mention anything about the sugar industry.

—No, it did not rate a mention. Australia is a great trading nation but one would not think so from the Governor-General's address. There is no comment at all about the disastrous effects of industrial militancy which has threatened our reputation as a reliable supplier. There is no reflection on the demands for wage increases and reduced hours which have been translated into increased costs and which mean that we are pricing ourselves out of world markets. What a facetious utterance the Government makes. Listen to it:

SPEECH.PARA: Multilateral and bilateral trade policies will be pursued to ensure that markets for Australian exports are made secure and developed to their full potential.

That sounds great but the obtaining, securing and developing of markets can be assured only if our customers can rely on delivery, if they can be assured that strikes will not close our factories and mines so that we cannot produce, that our sheep can be shorn, that our wheat and minerals can be shipped, that transport and rail carriage will not be paralysed, that armadas of ships will not be anchored for long periods at sea because our ports and wharves are closed by strikes.

What does the document say about Australian primary producers securing markets for wheat and livestock and then union militants blacklisting those markets and refusing to handle the exports? In fact, what does the document say about primary industry? There are precious few words and very little of them is of substance.

Similarly, I was greatly disappointed to see but four lines about something I regard as very important, the devotion to veterans affairs. In these few words in the Speech, I note the commitment of the Government to establish a royal commission to inquire into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on veterans of the Vietnam War. I do not think I can be justly accused from any side of the House of any lack of compassion or desire to find the answers which the Vietnam veterans desperately seek. I have spoken on a number of occasions in this chamber on this very matter. I do not propose to repeat in any detail what I said in the past. It will be known that I have reservations about this approach. I do not oppose any such commission or any other endeavour to find the answers, but I do say this constructively and with a lot of sympathy: We still need a thorough scientific and epidemiological study whether we have a royal commission or not. A royal commission cannot be a substitute for such a study. It may complement it; it may reinforce it; and I hope it does: But it is more than a question of compensation and pension, although those things are important. There must be a concentrated scientific and medical study. A judicial inquiry cannot as well or as completely answer the many questions which desperately worry veterans and their families. They have questions such as: 'Am I likely to develop a cancer or other delayed complication in later years? Is there treatment to best protect me against such an event? Should I father children, as I desperately want to do as a family man? What genetic defects can I transmit?' A judicial inquiry cannot answer those questions. I appeal to the Government- although never convinced that a royal commission alone can satisfactorily adduce such answers as that, I will never oppose any sincere endeavour to provide answers-not to forsake, overlook or neglect the scientific and medical study before it is too late and for which there can be no substitute.

Disproportionately in quantity and ominously revealing the Government's real priorities in the Speech we find almost two pages devoted to what is euphemistically called electoral and constitutional reform, a top priority, involving changing electoral laws to the detriment of already under-represented country people, referenda to control election timing and the like, and other assaults on the Australian Constitution. I am not going to pick up the detail of those matters in this debate. We will robustly debate that when the legislation comes before the House. The matter of priorities that we see in the Speech is of concern to me. Almost two pages are devoted to excuses and alibis and almost another two pages to electoral reform-in total over 25 per cent of the address- yet small business, trade and primary industry, surely the areas of great concern in any economic discussion or recovery, in total do not even get one page. I believe that clearly sets out the priorities and the pedigree of the Government. I suppose we should not be surprised when we see how selective and largely unrepresentative of many sections of the community the National Economic Summit Conference in actuality became.

Nor is there any commitment in this Speech, in this document or this program to a real continuation of the wage pause beyond a month or two. There is already talk about increases this year and speculation as to what the percentage might be. There is no firm statement that escalation will not be allowed to destroy the gains that a wage pause could bring. Indeed, in this House last week, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) virtually indicated to the Builders Labourers Federation that, if it fails to get what it wants in orthodox wage demands, there are all sorts of other special allowances by which it can, via the back door, end up with the pay packet that its members want anyhow. The Prime Minister's justification to the House was that these were special allowances which were confined to that industry and that they would not spread across the board. What absolute rot. If one industry circumvents the wage fixing procedures in that way, there is not an industry or union which will not employ the same tactic and the credibility and purpose of the central wage fixing commission or tribunal, about which we have been hearing in this place, will be absolutely shattered. If that is going to be the approach, where a wink is as good as a nod , the costs are still loaded, whatever they are disgusised as, on to business and industry. Profits, if there are any, will further disappear. Businesses will increasingly fail and our tragic army of unemployed will continue to grow.

Any of the promises of tax relief-there were plenty of those before the election-and a reduction of the deficit, clearly now stand exposed as 'pie in the sky when we die' if that is the course that the Government is destined to follow. That is the definite indication not only of increased taxation but also of the Pandora's Box of new exotic taxes we have heard extolled by Labor over the years and on which, during the campaign, there was a breathless hush. Now they are coming out of the mothballs, as we knew they would. Even indirect taxes , about which the Government protested and which it condemned, are now respectable, even most desirable and worthy and capable of increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about retreaded tyres?

—Yes, the sales tax on retreaded tyres is a case in point. It was raised in this House the other day. I was very disappointed in the response that we got from the Government benches. Nothing is safe from this taxation grab. This is also the formula which will ensure that the electorate will quickly become very disenchanted with this Government. That is probably why electoral reform has such a disproportionate and high priority in the very disappointing document we are now discussing.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never hesitated in this House or in any place to stand up and examine critically the stewardship of even my own Government. I have no hesitation in saying that there would be bipartisan support for real endeavours to beat inflation, create jobs, bring down interest rates, reduce the deficit and reduce the burden of inequitable taxation which is also a major contributor to our present dilemma. Honourable members will find that I have been absolutely consistent in all of those contentions. But I cannot find any program or any blueprint that gives me any confidence that that is what the Government is about in the document that we are discussing today.

If the Government follows the course of disaster, where militancy succeeds in destroying wage restraint and responsibility in wage fixing, where inflation and unemployment inevitably increase-that will be triggered by the program the Government is following-and the Australian taxpayer, in increasing proportions, has to pay for that economic folly, not only I, not only the other members of the Opposition, but also the whole Australian electorate will be totally unforgiving of this Government. Bland promises which are soon abrogated, platitudes and cliches may on occasions bring electoral success, but when they are exposed for what they are they become the very ropes which hang a government on its own gallows. In just weeks we have seen evidence of these ingredients. We have looked in the document of government proposals at the convocation of the Thirty-third Parliament for a clear battle plan for the defeat of inflation, unemployment and economic recession. We looked for development of the grand designs of the election policy statements. We looked with hope and expectation. We got-what?

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of broken promises.

—Yes, that is true. We got an apologetic account of alibis and excuses. We got a vague and very disappointing treatise underlining a different order of priorities which are blatantly partisan. We looked for a battle plan which every section could support and promote. This was to be the great accord. This was to be the consensus manifesto. We got a paper which will not curb greediness and militancy; indeed, it may encourage them. We got a blueprint which has as many loopholes and as many qualifications as our taxation Acts, which I have consistently criticised for such a long time. I hope that the Government will do something about those Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot be all things to all people and succeed in responibly leading this nation to recovery. I hope that the Government understands that. I hope that it has learnt that lesson, because soft options which placate one section are the additional weight in the saddle-bags, which become an intolerable burden for other sections. But this is the mud map that the Government has placed before us . It is in every sense a mud map. It bears all the signs of retreat. It is an abrogation, and the signs on the road ahead have a remarkably similar appearance to those which this nation followed to disaster in the period 1972 to 1975. It is a repeat, all over again. It is a disappointing exercise in vagueness, with very disturbing innuendoes. It is not the definite, courageous, determined prescription which can inspire this Parliament and this nation to accept, albeit with sacrifices, to support and to endorse in the best interests of our nation and every one of our citizens. It is a disappointing document altogether.

If the Government declares that big government, big spending and big deficits will be attacked and reduced, we could all support that. If the Government says that inflation, unemployment and economic recession will be firmly and resolutely attacked and defeated, we could support that. If the Government says that it will reduce the load of taxation, and bring to book the cheats, we could support that. If the Government says: 'We will commit ourselves to strengthening the federal system and not undermine State and local government rights' we could support that. But we have seen the reverse of that. That would be accord. That would be consensus. But this document says none of those things. If the words are there, the intent is quickly diminished, qualified or altered somewhere else in the context.

I would much rather have been able to stand here and congratulate the Government and indicate support for its economic program. If this is the document and this is the basis, I cannot, sadly, do either, because this document is the most disappointing and most indecisive of any of the addresses which a government has asked a Governor-General to present since I was first elected 10 years, or six elections, ago. It will not give the encouragement and the lift in spirits which people looked for, hoped for and, perhaps, voted for. It will do nothing to stimulate confidence. It commences with a roar and ends with a whimper, and it was the very vehicle which could have brought purpose and direction, but it got hopelessly lost somewhere along the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Flinders, I remind the House that the honourable gentleman is about to deliver his maiden speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. May I offer you congratulations, and ask you to convey, at your earliest convenience, congratulations from the people of Flinders to the Speaker on his elevation to that high office. We trust that he is granted health and happiness for many years to come to enable him to occupy that chair.

SPEECH.PARA: I have risen to speak on the Speech given by the Governor-General. I must state here and now that the speech that I heard was definitely the best that has been given by a Governor-General to the Australian nation in the last seven years. My thanks go to my wife, Anne, and my children, Alan, David and Jane, who have given me love and support during the hectic election campaign and through this most difficult period of learning as a parliamentarian. I thank the people of Flinders for the trust and honour that they have bestowed on me. As the electorate of Flinders has not been represented in the Federal Parliament by the Australian Labor Party for 29 years, I trust that I can fulfil the responsibilities and the obligations placed upon me.

As in the normal Address-in-Reply debate, I should like to take this opportunity to talk about the electorate of Flinders-however, with this difference: I have risen to speak about conservation; conservation on a grand scale. I should like to describe the electorate of Flinders after it has been obliterated by a one-megaton atomic weapon-a small one. If the city of Frankston is the target, those living within a six-kilometre circle will be incinerated immediately. These people are the lucky ones. Those approximately six kilometres out who happen to be looking in the direction of the blast will be blinded instantly, fractionally before any exposed skin is burnt off and they are set alight. They will then be hit by the shock wave, and, if they are fortunate, this will kill them. If it does not kill them, they will die within 10 minutes in excruciating pain. Those within a 10-kilometre radius will suffer third degree burns and probably die. There will be no doctors, no hospitals, no drugs. They will die in agony over a period of days. Most property will either burn or be destroyed by the blast.

The people on the rest of the peninsula will be exposed to radiation and may die within a short time, through vomiting, diarrhoea, shock and other radiation- related illnesses. Any who happen to survive the first month will undoubtedly die of cancer or leukemia in the ensuing years, that is, if they survive the fighting for food and shelter which will occur. The electorate of Flinders will have scattered over its once beautiful countryside decaying and rotting corpses. These will be infested by rodents and insects, many of which will survive the blast.

The possibility of this scenario is rapidly drawing closer, not only for the people of Flinders but for everyone on this exquisite and wonderful planet. In 1972 the Doomsday Clock was showing 12 minutes to midnight. In 1980 it was showing seven minutes to midnight. Today it is set at four minutes to midnight. We must not allow the time to run out. The Sir Basil Zharhovs of this world are starting to beat their drums. The arms dealers are peddling their wares with dollar signs in their eyes. The arms build-up is well under way. The factories are already increasing production. The bomb is primed, the finger is already on the trigger. A conventional war, a war within someone else's country, is a great way of getting the economy moving again and I am afraid that some countries have this contingency already well under way. Flash points set up and ready to go are the Middle East, Cambodia, El Salvador, Afghanistan and Korea.

The economic correlation between a conventional war and buoyant economic conditions is well known. However, a conventional war can easily accelerate into a nuclear war. Expenditure on weapons of destruction is about $2,000m per day or $104,000 per minute. In the 20 minutes that I will be speaking, about $2,080,000 will be spent on weapons of destruction. That figure excludes many millions which are spent on arms and hidden from public scrutiny. In 1982-83 we in Australia spent $4,662m on war. How much has been spent on peace? I believe the figure within Australia is very close to zero.

We have, in the leaders of the super-powers of this world, a trio of belligerent people-Andropov, Reagan and Thatcher. These are the people who will give the order for their automatons to press the button. How stupid are we as a species to allow ourselves to have a method of destroying humanity 20 times over , developed and put into a state of readiness? Yet we still have people who want to develop even more atomic weapons. What has taken nature millions of years of evolution to construct, we now have the ability to destroy within hours. Who knows, in another million years, the only record of our existence may be written on a satellite which has just left our solar system. Others will wonder why this unknown, intelligent species has disappeared. Will they guess that it was because of our own stupidity?

We in Australia can play a unique and important part in bringing about peace. We are a nation which has a high standing with most nations on this planet. We are in a position to put forward ideas and proposals which I am positive will be acceptable to many people. We have in our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a man whose reputation as a conciliator has won world recognition. If the cause of peace was taken up actively by our Government, using the United Nations as a forum, I am certain that our Prime Minister could do a great deal that would go towards breaking the impasse on disarmament and the headlong rush to oblivion that we are now moving towards.

As a first step towards the goal of peace, an institute of peace studies must be established. Its aim would be to provide a critical evaluation of a variety of proposals in peace and development areas, in response to requests from government agencies, parliamentarians and non-government organisations; to collect, publish and disseminate information and ideas in relation to peace; to have an educational role within the Australian nation by inviting discussion amongst educators, researchers, policy makers, government and non-government organisations. The funding of such an institute has been estimated at just over $1m per annum. It is indeed a very small price to pay.

The second step towards the goal of peace would be the establishment of a ministry of peace. A ministry of peace within the Government would provide an avenue for the expression of people's desires for peaceful conflict resolution. All people have the undeniable right to be assured that no armed defence is invoked until other means of achieving a non-violent resolution of conflict has been explored. A ministry of peace would be responsible for mediation, conciliation, arbitration, international aid, peacekeeping forces, civil service as an alternative to military service, arms reduction advice, peacetime occupation of the armed forces and studying the implementation of successful peace initiatives and the ultimate goal of universal peace. The planning and establishment of a ministry of peace must commence immediately. Time is running out very quickly. The world peace crisis transcends all other problems. We must bring to an end the madness which is engulfing our world. Albert Schweitzer said :
Example is not the main thing in influencing others, it is the only thing.

Within Australia, we have the leaders, we have the people, we have the resources to set an example now for the rest of the world. Let us act now. If we compare the planet earth-a beautiful green, blue and white jewel-with photographs of other planets, is it any wonder that it is written in the Bible that the Creator loved this world-my world, your world, our world-a world that can easily be turned into a dead radioactive waste by man's stupidity. We must act now.

I beg honourable members from both sides of the House to unite for the love of humanity and act to resolve this grave crisis now. To the people who are listening to this debate and those people who will read this speech, I say that they know in their hearts that what I have said is true. I ask them what they will do to help solve this crisis. I ask them to spend some time thinking about it and the consequences to them and their families and to remember also the generations to come. The future will be decided by them. I implore them to act now. Our world is relying on them. I conclude with this prayer for peace:
Lead me from death to life, from falsehood to truth; Lead me from despair to hope, from fear to trust; Lead me from hate to love, from war to peace; Let peace fill our heart, our world, our universe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Wakefield, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask that he be afforded the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I join my colleagues in this House in conveying to you my congratulations on your elevation to office. May I ask you to convey to Mr Speaker my congratulations on his elevation to office. I want you to know that these are not merely the obligatory words of courtesy but that I particularly appreciated the role of Mr Speaker and the Chairman of Committees in ensuring that both the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and I were very much a participating part of the recent new members' seminar.

SPEECH.PARA: I stand in this place acutely aware of the fact that the electors of Wakefield have placed on me both an honour and a responsibility. My predecessors in this seat have been both individualistic and colourful men who have served their parliaments and this nation with distinction. I make particular reference to Mr Geoff Giles, my immediate predecessor, who joined this Parliament in 1964 and who made a real contribution in rural matters on the national scene. You will know, Mr Deputy Speaker, of Mr Giles's participation as Deputy Chairman of Committees, as Deputy Government Whip and as the Opposition nominee for the position of Speaker.

Such is the fibre of the people of Wakefield, such is their inherent strength, that even in the face of flood, bushfire, frost and hail, Wakefield continues to be where the rest of the world would like to be. Even in drought, Wakefield is a significant part of the food bowl of our nation. Whether one dines on fast foods or fine cuisine, entree or main course, hors d'oeuvres or sweets, from the fine wines that complement the meal to the clothes adorning the diners, chances are that one of my constituents is a part of the national industry that makes that function possible.

Occupying 36,000 square kilometres, from the border with Victoria to the tip of Yorke Peninsula, and embracing not only the industrious wheat, barley and sheep areas of mid-northern South Australia and the peninsula but also the fertile Barossa Valley, Adelaide Hills and Riverland, Wakefield primary producers have one common necessity-an assured supply of good, clean water. All South Australians, especially my constituents, recognise the need for their share of our national resource, the River Murray. In spite of all the rhetoric that I have no doubt has been uttered in this chamber about Australia being a dry continent, too few people realise that if the run-off from rainfall precipitated over Australia were contained within the continent we would cover Australia with 5 centimetres of water. If the run-off from rainfall precipitated over the next driest continent, Africa, were contained within that continent it would be covered with 17 centimetres of water. Water conservation initiatives in the face of a disastrous drought are urgently needed.

I welcome the reference in the Governor-General's Speech to the commitment to considering a water research institute. But that is not enough. Consideration will not do. Far too much has already been said and far too little done. We do not want mere consideration of a water research institute; we want action on water quality. The $640m scheme proposed in January this year, if implemented, would provide the type of capital works we need to employ people. Just one section of that scheme, the installation of tube wells between locks 2 and 3 to intercept natural saline inflows, would take 60,000 tonnes of salt out of the river system every year.

The Governor-General's Speech outlines the Government's commitment to capital works as part of its job creation strategy. If we can in a bipartisan sense be committed to a new Parliament House and if the Government can find $115m to inject into Trans Australia Airlines, then I suggest that the capital works to ensure fresh water in the driest State of this nation would be a far better monument to this Parliament than the self-aggrandisement of a contemporary home. Before we launch into public funded, public managed capital job creation programs, we would do well to administer them with due regard to the experience of the past. If the Government is to be truly accountable it must be prepared to put proposed works up for tender, bring in contractors, and so engender a sense of responsibility, purpose and fulfilment among employees.

A sensitivity to the natural balance that small business gives the economy would be well advised. Sadly, my electorate has in it all too many examples of well-intentioned counter-productive government intervention. Let me illustrate that. It is popular to regard irrigation farmers as subsidised, unable to meet the capital cost of the reticulation schemes installed for them. This is arrant nonsense. I could take honourable members on to numerous farms, involve them in numerous schemes, where growers are pumping water out of the river through their own reticulation schemes, and their properties are in demand. It is true that even these enterprising growers do not contribute directly to the locks and barrages that have been provided so they can pump water. But those locks and barrages were not provided exclusively for irrigation. The honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) could tell the House that the locks and barrages that maintain water levels in the Murray River are essential to industry in his Iron Triangle, essential to give Adelaide the 300 litres that every member of each household consumes every day and essential if the river is to be a national playground. Government irrigation areas were set up with the best intentions in the world as job creation projects in the face of a depression but they continue to be uneconomic while private schemes alongside them flourish.

While I am on the subject of the Murray, the Governor-General's Speech made particular reference to our national heritage and to the protection of fauna and flora. Any government prepared to engineer the power it needs to intervene in an issue over which the States have sovereignty should be prepared to take positive steps to end the rape of the river system by upstream users. Only the agreement negotiated by the now honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) over a decade ago ensured anything like adequate water for South Australia during the drought. The River Murray Commission needs further powers to give teeth to its resolve to have both quality and quantity of water as part of the consideration for South Australians. The presence of governments of the same political persuasion in Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and federally, gives a unique opportunity for there to be consensus on River Murray management. But I advise the Government to act promptly; the monopoly will not last long.

Another illustration of the tragic paralysis that follows government intervention in areas of enterprise is the canned fruit industry. This labour intensive industry, besieged by our high cost structure and the preferential trade agreements of the European Economic Community, has just been decimated in South Australia by well-intentioned but counter-productive government intervention. The decision of the Dunstan Government to close the smaller of two co-operative canneries and expand the larger has been disastrous. The growers of canned fruit have been left reeling while enormous injections of government revenue have failed to provide relief. Mr Deputy Speaker, should I go on, illustrating the honourable member for Grey's clothing factory or illustrating the frozen food factory?

No one in this House would deny the Government its right and responsibility to dictate the terms in areas such as quarantine or defence. No one would deny the Government its responsibility to intervene to protect industries against dumping or unfair practice and no one would deny the Government its responsibility to protect the exploitable from being exploited. Unfortunately, even when governments act with good intentions they intrude on the individual's responsibility to achieve privately his own aspirations and destiny. This intrusion confers on the Government powers not even God allows himself. With the noblest of motives we are being exhorted to fund job creation programs. Bipartisan agreements can easily be reached in this House, for unemployment is the scourge of our nation. What in reality we offer the unemployed is not job creation but work experience. Only productivity creates permanent jobs. Only by increasing our output without increasing our expectation of reward will we increase productivity in the nation or in my business. The paradox of all this is that the more intrusion there is by government into the affairs of an ostensibly free society the more that society stagnates, forcing greater government intervention.

My electors-my constituents in the seat of Wakefield-are principally farmers who are forced to buy in the high cost structure of Australia and sell in the cold climate of overseas reality. They have been doing so for decades. Only increased productivity, as everyone knows, has kept them viable. Their viability is the nation's prosperity. The wages of my farmers are indexed-indexed by the weather, by the reality of overseas prices and by what the drought did to them. In spite of it having rained we will expect them to carry the nation's economic recovery. The lesson is uncomfortable but inescapable; productivity produces wealth.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I stand before you as the member for Wakefield, but I recognise, as does every honourable member in this chamber, that I am not here solely as the representative of that geographical area named after a founding father of the State. I am here also as a member of the Australian Parliament. Ours must be a national perspective. From this Parliament the nation is entitled to expect leadership and integrity. We do that nation-our people-a gross disservice when we create the impression that we can solve all its problems. If governments held the key to relieving the frustration of the world we would have entered Utopia long ago. Sometimes it seems we see ourselves as problem solvers. We project ourselves, on either side of the House, as having a philosophical potion to end the world's ills. Such a stand is criminal, for first we must recognise that we are an inseparable part of the world's ills.

If, as suggested last week, simply redistributing often presumed wealth was handing out happiness, we should by now be ecstatic-nay delirious with joy. Ironically it is often those humble souls who have little-those in Holy Orders- who radiate contentment. We invite our electors to see us as problem solvers. It is small wonder that they become disillusioned and cynical. At best we can be problem minimisers. Uncomfortably and inescapably the only resources we have are those we take-those generated by our taxpayers. What any government earns of its own is inconsequential. No matter how wise the Government, how well intentioned its intervention, all that it has to spend belongs to someone else. It is generated by people who have stood sweating in the sun, dipping sheep, painting buildings, working on building sites or construction teams or picking fruit. It is generated by people who have exercised some self-discipline in technology and by people who have been prepared to commit both their labour and their capital to some risky venture.

We politicians on the floor of this chamber and public servants all depend on those enterprising people for the revenue we spend. Our lifestyle is funded by fellow Australians. Every additional resource we acquire, every dollar of revenue raised, is a dollar earned by a constituent and given in trust to us. The disservice we do our constituents every time we intervene unnecessarily is further compounded when we remember that we take not only their revenue, their hard earned capital, but also their accountability. This would be excusable if, as a Parliament, we had a monopoly on wisdom, but this has not proved to be so- not even under coalition governments. Even governments with the most honourable of intentions cannot be wiser than men.

With great respect I suggest that the Thirty-third Parliament has two urgent tasks. First, it must minimise the demands it makes on its taxpayers. Essentially this will mean a reappraisal of our welfare system. No one would challenge the need for a welfare net or suggest that commitment to sensitive welfare programs is inappropriate. But we dare not endeavour to eliminate risk. To take no risk is the greatest risk of all. No society can hope to breed a spirit of achievement and independence, a commitment to excellence and the preservation of long held values while a welfare program exists which shields its beneficiaries from every risk they are likely to confront from birth to death. In 1971, four people worked for every person receiving support. Today only two people work for every person receiving support. I suggest that in that decade steps were taken to install an adequate welfare net.

In conclusion-by the way I was reminded to say 'in conclusion' and conclude and not 'lastly' and last-we need to hand back to State and local governments more of the responsibility and resources we have taken unto ourselves. This must be done unconditionally. Greater, even total, responsibility for health, education and welfare could be placed in the hands of State and local authorities. Of course it is risky. It is also the only way to allow individual Australians to have a direct input into the communities in which they live. Most of all, this decentralised authority increases the opportunity for each taxpayer to be accountable for the resources he earns and asks governments to spend. After all, freedom is political power divided into small fragments.
Debate (on motion by Mr Gear) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Mr John Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Bounty (Steel Products) Bill 1983 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
-Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Room Air Conditioners) Bill 1983 results from the acceptance by the previous Government on 27 October 1982 of a recommendation of the Temporary Assistance Authority. It provides for a bounty of up to $1.5m to be paid between 27 October last and 30 June 1983. The Bounty (Steel Products) Bill results from a decision of the Temporary Assistance Authority and was announced on 1 February 1983. The Bill endorses the action taken by the previous Government and, as such, we concur with both Bills which are before the House. I think it is worth saying at this time something about the troubled steel industry because a lot of capital has been made out of it. I am sure the former honourable member for Macarthur, who suffered at the hands of some of these actions, would welcome my quoting from a couple of newspaper articles. The editorial of an Illawarra newspaper stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On February 15, in his pre-election campaign, Mr Hawke told Australians in the bluntest terms that a Labor Government would maintain steel jobs.
. . . He pledged that an ALP Government, within 100 days of taking office, would prepare a 10-year development plan for the future of the steel industry.
The editorial continued:
Yesterday BHP sacked almost 600 steelworkers at Port Kembla and Newcastle-only 14 days after Mr Hawke took office.
An article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 16 February stated:
'BHP may be less than perfect,' Mr Hawke said. 'But it can hardly be blamed for the Government's inability to make a decision.
That is hardly prudent these days. The article continued:
He said a Labor Government would be committed to the maintenance of an Australian steel industry.
It would:
Review import quotas in order to increase BHP's share of the local market.
Provide import tariff quotas and bounties to boost the local market.
This is being done in this Bill-
View sympathetically BHP's request for extra tax benefits in return for its expanded investment program.

The result of that is that the Government has reneged on the Fraser Government's plan to grant a tax ability within a corporation to offset profits in one sector against losses in another. The article continued:
Establish a co-operative monitor of BHP's performance and programs.
That would be quite something-
In choosing job-creation schemes, give priority to those which require steel inputs.
Within the first 100 days of government--
As I said before-
devise with BHP a 10-year development plan for the industry.

Well, time is certainly running out. We have not heard much. We continue to hear of retrenchments within the steel industry. We continue to hear that the associated industries, particularly the coal industry, are in the same position as the steel industry.

Once again we have propositions put up during an election campaign and walked away from subsequently. We know full well that the general approach that the Government has taken is that it is all very well to walk around Australia in an election campaign and promise the people everything, but when it comes to performance we find that the promises are put off because the National Economic Summit Conference, as I heard one Minister say, instructed the Government to do so or is put off because it is too hard or because of the sheer incompetence of the Government to get around to the decision making process while it is chasing spies around the countryside. This is a bizarre performance. It is the sort of thing we would expect from a Government which is rapidly showing signs of a few cracks around the countryside.

In dealing with the two Bills before the House, I draw the nation's attention to the steel industry as a whole. The steel industry is one of the great industries of this nation. This country has unlimited resources in terms of iron ore and coal. With the appropriate management and identity of market, I am sure that the prosperity of the industry can be restored. However, it will not be restored without appropriate incentive to BHP and to other firms which may wish to operate in the industry. This is the only way in which the jobs of people employed in this industry will be protected in the longer term. In the short term, the propping up of the industry by the use of artificial quotas and import levies will do nothing to encourage the sort of investment that is necessary to ensure the future of this industry. The Opposition supports both of the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying to work out the point that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) was putting to the House. On the one hand, he said that we should be supporting the payment of bounties in respect of the steel industry. Then he seemed to launch into some kind of attack on the Government. In fact, the legislation before us does precisely that; it provides new further assistance to the steel industry. It was interesting to hear the honourable member talk about how much more supportive we have to be to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. One has only to look at the record of mismanagement of his own Government in relation to the steel industry and BHP to see that the previous Government did not know whether it was coming or going in relation to these matters.
—It was going.

—It was going all right. The jobs of BHP workers were lost and that loss started under the previous Government. We have a situation in which the honourable member for Ryan comes into this House and tries to tell us what we should be doing about the steel industry. I suggest that the honourable member and his colleagues ought to study matters concerning the industry for a few months before they have the impertinence to come before us in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: The only area in which the honourable member differed with the Government was in respect of his proposal that we should allow BHP to claim its losses in the steel industry against its profits in other areas. In other words, he wants to increase the overall profitability of BHP and increase the subsidy in an indirect way without any assurances whatsoever that that support would go into the steel industry. This is the kind of economic thinking that we are getting from the Opposition. It is no wonder that honourable members opposite have become the Opposition if that is the kind of approach which they suppose is going to solve the problems of the steel industry. To answer that point-and this was the only point of relevance that was raised by the honourable member-any support that we give to the steel industry will be direct support which will be conditional on action to increase efficiency and to ensure that the steel industry is modernised. I will come back to that topic a little later. However, before I do so, let me just say something about the Bill which, of course, the honourable member completely failed to talk about.

This Bill arises from the Temporary Assistance Authority's report of 23 December 1982 which recommended short term assistance to the local production of certain high alloy steel products. The previous Government announced on 1 February 1983 that it had accepted the Authority's recommendation for a bounty to be paid at the rate of 5 per cent of the value of sales, to a limit of $3m. The bounty is to apply from 1 January 1983 to 31 December 1983 or the date of implementation of the Government decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on the iron and steel industry, whichever occurs first.

Let me explain some of the background of this situation. High alloy steel is used in applications where strength, corrosive resistence, resistence to chemical attack or other special attributes are required. The Authority's recommendation covers flat stainless steel produced by Commonwealth Steel Co.- Comsteel-a subsidiary of BHP at Unanderra and bar products produced by Comsteel at Newcastle and by two smaller firms, Overall Forge and Atlas Steels. Production of the goods under reference is at present assisted by a duty of 25 per cent, phasing to 15 per cent by 1988. Comsteel requested tariff quotas for two years, limiting imports to 15 per cent of the market.

It should be pointed out that Comsteel accounts for over 95 per cent of the industry and is in a serious and worsening situation. It has been making losses on goods under reference of $0.37m in 1981-82 and $1.97m in July-November 1982, with sales, production and employment all falling significantly and continuously since 1979-80. The Temporary Assistance Authority considered that the worsening of Comsteel's position had not been due solely to imports but to a combination of factors, including a deterioration in domestic and international economic conditions. Nevertheless, the Authority recognised that there had been a severe price competition from imports and considered there would be a significant movement of resources out of the industry if temporary assistance were not granted. The extent of the problem can be illustrated when we consider the following: Firstly, Comsteel's share of the market has fallen from almost 80 per cent in 1979-80 to 45 per cent in the September quarter of 1982. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table illustrating this fall in the market share.

TALK.START.PARA: -Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted.

—Secondly, the major import sources have been Japan and the European Economic Community with what appears to be a major market struggle between the two with a consequential increase in imports overall in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the Authority took substantial notice of the Defence Department's view that the retention of high alloy steel production capacity is important to our national interest and security. I repeat, it is important to our national interest and security. That was one of the reasons the Authority, which is not well known for making determinations of this kind in regard to protection, decided in this case that it would give temporary assistance. The various reasons have been taken up in a scientific way. As I have already mentioned, they relate to the dramatic fall in the market share and to a situation in which there has been a great struggle between importers, resulting in increased imports. They also relate to the need for an Australian capacity to produce high alloy steel for our own defence purposes.

Consequently, the Temporary Assistance Authority recommended a bounty of 5c in the dollar on domestic sales, pending implementation of the forthcoming IAC decision, with a ceiling of $3m. However, it was the Authority's view that tariff quotas, which were requested by the industry and especially BHP, or increased tariffs, would be ineffective in view of estimates of substantial stocks already held by importers in Australia. It is estimated that at least six months stocks for sale are held by importers. In that situation it was decided that a bounty would be appropriate. Another reason was that going to tariffs could have had adverse effects for user industries.

In supporting these proposals I and the Government are not in any way committed to providing endless assistance to the steel industry in terms of pouring money down the drain. We expect results as a consequence of the money which the taxpayers are putting into these industries. We accept that in these circumstances special assistance is required but it should not be assumed that we will continually act to prop up BHP and its subsidiaries, irrespective of management practices of BHP and its treatment of the work force, especially its readiness to sack workers whenever a problem arises.

The Authority said in its report that it did not expect that this extra protection would retard efforts by BHP to restructure its operations to become more efficient. We certainly hope that that is so. We do not believe that, by granting tariffs and bounties, we are creating a situation where people can take the benefits without also taking action to restructure, to become more efficient in production, and to produce and sell more steel in Australia at a good price.

As I have mentioned, the Authority indicated that other factors were involved in Comsteel's loss of market share. I would not be surprised if one of these was the market practices of BHP, which is firmly convinced that it is maximising its sales by what appears to me to be, and what representations appear to me indicate are, dubious forms of sales practice. I refer to the situation in which BHP sells steel only to a select group of distributors, excluding many others who want to distribute it in Australia. Representations have been made to me on the matter and I have spoken about it to the management of BHP. I have also referred the matter to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). I am not satisfied that BHP's sales practices, as carried out at present, do maximise sales of Australian steel. The situation needs to be looked at in much greater detail.

In the meantime, I repeat the point that I made earlier. Labor is not slow to grant support and protection for Australian industry. That is fundamental to our philosophy and we will continue in that vein. However, we expect the protected companies to use this support in a positive way-to become more efficient, to have pricing policies which are reasonable, to increase the opportunities of the work force and to provide a better situation for the Australian market as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Perhaps I should respond to some of the remarks that have been made by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) about the steel industry and refer to the rather interesting table that the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) tried to have incorporated in Hansard. I admit that he had not shown the table to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) who resisted the attempt, as convention might have decreed. However, perhaps it might be reasonable if I were to read it into Hansard because it goes to the very heart of the reason for the introduction of this bounty bill. The table is related to local producers and gives the percentage rates of the imports market share of competitive market supplies. It shows that for high alloy bar products in 1979-80 the local producers market share was 77.6 per cent. By 1980-81 it had shrunk to 66.6 per cent, by 1981-82 to 60.2 per cent and by the September quarter of 1982 to 47.8 per cent. The corollary was that imports market share had risen from 22.4 per cent in 1979-80 to 52.2 per cent in September 1982. With regard to stainless steel flat products, the same decline in the local producers market share is very evident. In 1979-80 it amounted to 76 per cent. By September 1982 it had shrunk to 42.3 per cent. Of course, imports had risen in the same period from 24 per cent of the market to 57.7 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The result of all that was that local producers' market share of both high alloy bar products and stainless steel flat products had been reduced from 76.9 per cent in 1980 to 44.6 per cent in the September quarter of 1982, while imports market share had risen from 23.1 per cent in 1979-80 to 55.4 per cent in the September quarter of 1982. So those of us who are interested in the shrinking market shares of local manufacturers in the steel industry, in comparison with the imports share, will now be able to read those facts in Hansard, because I have read it in, despite the best efforts of the honourable member for Franklin to make sure that that advice was not available to honourable members and to interested readers of Hansard.

The honourable member for Ryan had some quite uncomplimentary remarks to make about this Government's handling of the steel industry. Indeed, the remarks of the honourable member for Burke were quite relevant to that aspect. It ill becomes any member of the Opposition to make jibes at the Government about the running down of manufacturing whether it be the steel industry or any other part of the manufacturing industry. Remember that the Australian Labor Party has ruled for only three of the last 33 years. That means that if any blame is to be apportioned, 11 times as much should be apportioned to the Opposition as to the Government. For the last seven years, the former Government presided over the running down, to an extraordinary extent, of what was a very viable manufacturing industry when it came to office in 1975. Apart from manufacturing, if one wanted to go into the full record of the former Government's absolute destruction of the Australian economy one could do so, but for the moment I will spare it that ignominy and simply restrict my remarks to the steel industry.

The Fraser Government had no long term plans for the steel industry. It was just as happy for it to disappear-as it rapidly was until the advent of the Hawke Government. This Government is firmly committed to maintaining a viable, internationally competitive steel industry, not just because of its importance to the Australian economy or its capacity to employ people, but for a few other reasons that the honourable gentlemen on the other side of the House may not yet have recognised. The fact that the steel industry is localised in certain areas- in Newcastle, Port Kembla and Whyalla-and the economies of those cities are, to a great extent, intertwined with the steel industry has escaped them. The rundown in the steel industry has led to enormous difficulties and dislocations on both the employment and social sides of people's lives in those places. In Wollongong unemployment rates are reaching 40 per cent. It never struck the gentlemen of the Opposition when they were in government to what extent they were destroying the social fabric of those cities by letting the steel industry wind down. As I said, this Government will not see that happen, for one other very important reason, as the honourable member for Burke so eloquently pointed out. The importance of the steel industry to our national security and defence arrangements is paramount. For those very important reasons, we will be taking steps very shortly-steps that the previous Government did not take in its seven years of mismanagement of the nation's economy.

The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button), whom I have the honour to represent in this House, has been having discussions with the industry and the unions over the last month and he will be continuing those discussions over the next few weeks. As a Government, we are very aware of the need to announce a long term policy for the steel industry as soon as possible to provide job security for employees in the industry and some degree of security for the industry to invest in its future. We are moving very quickly to finalise our steel development plan by the end of June.

One of the basic mistakes of the Fraser Government in its seven years of office -not just in the steel industry but in the breadth and width of its dealings with industry-was its failure at any time to develop a long range plan. All its decisions were ad hoc. The decisions it made overnight affected so many industries so vitally; yet it never had the wit to realise that the main thing that an industry looks for from a government is some long range plan it can work to in its forward planning in terms of economy, scale and employment. It wants a government in whom it has some confidence. That will not be the pattern followed by the Hawke Government.

The steel industry can look forward with confidence to the end of June, when our steel development plan will be announced. It will be a forward-thinking and long range plan that will restore some viability to the industry. We expect that all parties involved will make a contribution to the discussions on the development of that plan. The Federal Government is only one of the network of bodies that need to be involved in this forward planning. The Government has already met with representatives of the industry and the steel unions and it will be intensifying these discussions within the next few weeks. Matters presently being discussed with the industry and the unions include future demand prospects, investment, technology, work force requirements, productivity, work practices and manning levels. Meetings will also be arranged with State governments which have basic iron and steel operations.

The major inputs in this Government's deliberations on the long term steel policy will be the one-to-one meetings that we are having with the industry and the unions, and which we will eventually have with the State governments; the Industries Assistance Commission's final report on the steel industry; and the reports of the Steel Industry Advisory Council and an inter-departmental committee. Our prime objective will be to create the environment for Australian industry to return to its once highly efficient competitive position in the world's steel industry.

We firmly believe-I hope that there will be some sort of bipartisanship on this particular point-that this is the best way to create job security for the industry's employees and to create some security for investors in industry, particularly for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Australia's biggest company, as it has a monopoly in this area. Therefore, it strikes me as being very odd that members of the Opposition-in the first few weeks of dealing with a government that promises so much in terms of reconciliation and reconstruction of not only the economy but also the total fabric of Australian society-could cynically pour buckets on this Government over the steel industry that they allowed to deteriorate almost to the state of bankruptcy and oblivion. We are equal to the task now that we are in Government. We will take up the challenge to restructure the steel industry, to make it viable, profitable and the source of high employment which it should be. Our purpose is not only to restore people 's jobs, but also to promote a steel industry that is very vital to our national security.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will you do it?

—If the honourable member for Higgins were not so thick and so busy running around with toy koalas and if he took a more responsible attitude to the fact that his Government left a legacy of 800,000 unemployed in this country and a deficit of $10 billion he might be more aware of what I am talking about. While he is poking fun at me about koalas, I am worried about the fact that a little promotion of the tourist industry can provide 100,000 extra jobs. It will never be promoted by koalas, but by people with vision and understanding -something that honourable members opposite never had. The fact that the honourable member is running around with toy koalas under his arm, trivialising important things such as the opportunity of getting a real growth industry off the deck, is a fair testimony to the sort of government that those opposite provided for seven years. The country will not get that from us. It will get leadership and co-ordination-
—I wanted to know how you are going to restructure the steel industry .
—I have been telling the honourable member for 10 minutes. If he were not so thick he might have understood.
—You did not explain.

—I will explain in monosyllables next time so that the honourable member will be able to understand. Any word bigger than four letters he has difficulty with. It is very obvious that the problems the steel industry faces are those created by the Fraser Government, largely as a result of its inactivity, mismanagement and lack of any sort of vision. That vision will be forthcoming from this Government. Honourable members can rest assured that at the end of our first term of office the steel industry will be viable again because we will deal with all the factors involved. I hope that I do not again hear the honourable member for Ryan ranting and raving in this place about the steel industry, because nobody will listen to him.
