TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 14, page 11, line 17, omit paragraph (1) (c), substitute the following paragraph and words:
'(c) officers included in a specified class of officers, to be an authorized officer, or authorized officers, for the purposes of this Act.'.

The purpose of this amendment is to correct a minor printing error in clause 14 of the Bill. It was found in the final print, after the Bounty (Steel Products) Bill was introduced. The clause to be amended empowers the Minister to appoint an authorised officer or authorised officers upon whom certain administrative functions are to be conferred. Such a provision is standard in bounty legislation. The responsibility of these authorised officers would be to have the right to enter a place of industry and to inspect the books to make sure that the bounty that is being paid in that case was being properly earned by the company involved. It is a very uncomplicated amendment. I am sure that the Opposition will accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment that has been moved by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown). As the Minister has indicated, the purpose of the amendment is simply to correct a minor printing error. It is, of course, important in connection with any type of legislation that errors of that kind which sometimes inadvertently find their way into legislation should be identified and corrected before they become a matter of some confusion and some dispute, perhaps in the interpretation and the application of the particular provisions of the legislation. It is important in connection with the Bounty (Steel Products) Bill 1983 because many of the matters that have had attention drawn to them by honourable members who spoke during the debate on the second reading of the legislation. The importance of clarity and clear definition is indicated by the general nature of this proposition which is currently being considered.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister referred to the fact that the steel industry, of course, is one of the major industries in Australia. It is necessary for any government which happens to be charged with the responsibility of providing administration and determining policies in relation to Australian industry to be cognisant of that fact. But the whole question is not simply a question of the relationship of government policy to the steel industry at the present time. What Australia is concerned about doing is identifying the nature of the secondary industrial structure in particular which Australia, as a nation, would like to see in place . Also when we are making decisions along those lines it is necessary for governments to determine the nature of the industrial protection which will be provided.

Of course, providing a bounty to the steel industry for the steel products which have been indicated in this particular piece of legislation is extremely important. It was indicated during the second reading speech of the Minister that these steels are essential for a very wide range of direct defence applications and they also underpin general support capabilities for defence activities. When we realise the extent to which questions of this kind impinge on our defence capability and on the capacity of Australian industry to provide the special types of steels which are necessary for Australia's defence capacity , the Minister's care in making sure that the precise details of the legislation were appropriate is borne out to us more clearly.

It was indicated as well that the bounty was recommended by the Temporary Assistance Authority in its report No. 57 of 23 December 1982. That report was entitled: 'Certain High Alloy Steel Products'. The previous Government had earlier announced on 1 February this year that it had accepted the Temporary Assistance Authority's recommendation. This Government was prepared to accept that same recommendation. Of course, this particular Bill results from the Government's decision in this respect.

The Minister also referred to the fact that at the present time, in the immediate past and in the future very important discussions will be taking place . Very important discussions have been taking place within the Steel Industry Advisory Council. I have indicated previously that I have very serious reservations about the industry advisory councils which had existed and operated under the previous Government and the usefulness and the effectiveness with which those industry councils were pursuing their particular responsibilities. I have been privileged to be a participant in the discussions that have taken place within the Steel Industry Advisory Council. I feel that those discussions have been extremely fruitful not only in identifying the types of problems that exist within the steel industry but also to make it possible for major interests which are involved in the steel industry to come together collectively around a single table, facing each other, and present their assessment of the problems as they see them and to give some indication of the type of solutions that they consider should be put in place.

This particular Bill-its clarity has been guaranteed as a result of the amendment which has just been moved by the Minister-is of critical importance. The steel development plan which I am sure will be completed by the end of June means that at least we will be providing a more important indication of the direction this Government will take in relation to the steel industry. It has been a very important question to have resolved.

We are all aware of the fact that the steel industry needs assistance. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in particular, in its submission to the Industries Assistance Commission, made three particular applications. The first one was that it be guaranteed 85 per cent of the domestic market on a volume basis rather than a value basis. The second proposition was that it be given the opportunity to participate in a type of group tax arrangement between the various divisions of BHP. The third proposition which BHP put to the IAC was that it be allowed to write off in the first year of any investment the full amount of that depreciation. They are important considerations. The question of bounty assistance to the steel industry is part of that total picture.

I have very serious reservations about the future of the Australian steel industry but certainly this Government now has put into place very effective machinery to make sure that at least the types of problem that exist are dealt with more effectively than was the case before. I accede to the concern which was expressed by at least one member of the Opposition to apply more effectively the machinery which had been in place previously. There is no doubt that as a result of all of those considerations that have been given to this extraordinarily important industry in Australia some sensible and constructive decisions will be arrived at. It would be absurd if Australia, of all developed countries, were to be the only country to wind up its steel industry. It is a proposition which the private owners of the steel industry, the Government or the Australian community should never contemplate. It is necessary for wide and deep consideration to be given to some of these issues. The particular Bill with which we are dealing at the present time and the amendment which has been moved so ably by an extremely competent and successful Minister of the Hawke Labor Government should meet with the approval of the whole Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment and congratulate the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) for the way in which he, with the one or two notable exceptions, has been carrying out his duties. I agree in substance with a lot of the remarks made by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown). My remarks will be brief. I wanted to place on record the fact that, at the time the last Government was considering the problems of the steel industry and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in particular, the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, was absent due to illness and I, along with the then Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Fife, was responsible essentially for presenting the case to Cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: There will always be disputes when governments have to make decisions on the question of balancing competing interests, but I take heart, and express this view personally, at what appears to be on the part of this Government a genuine commitment to the Australian steel industry. Let me spell it out bluntly: That means increased protection. I do not in any way pre-empt my colleague sitting alongside me or my party, but I simply say that the advice of economic experts, as to what is necessary to protect and maintain the Australian steel industry, in my view has fallen far short of what it should have been. I invite the Minister at the table, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), through his colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce in the Senate, to clear one bogey which will hang over the head of this Government unless it is immediately-I repeat immediately-put to death and that is the continuing rumours that this Government is contemplating a repeat of its 1973 performance of a 25 per cent across the board cut in tariffs. I have to say that ghosts do come back from the past and Banquo's ghost is coming back to haunt the Hawke Government.

I invite the Minister to take the bit in his teeth here and now and give a guarantee that there will be no across the board tariff cuts by the Hawke Government during its present term of office. TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling on the honourable member for Tangney I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask that the House extend to him the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I join my colleagues in congratulating you, and through you Mr Speaker, on your election to office. My presence here today was made possible by the electors of Tangney who through me expressed confidence in the policies of the Australian Labor Party for national recovery through reconciliation and reconstruction. I thank them for their trust , and assure them I will work to the utmost of my ability for their benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: I must pay special thanks to a very dedicated campaign committee and supporters who helped me achieve the tenth biggest swing recorded in the March election, and especially to my campaign manager Garry Kelly. It would not be fair if I did not also thank my predecessor, Mr Peter Shack, who took a keen interest in his electorate duties. It was unfortunate that he supported a party which did not show the same concern for individuals.

Tangney is a swinging electorate. Its member has always sat on this side of the House. What this Parliament does about the problems of unemployment, poverty, social disadvantage, electoral disadvantage, education, the role of women and nuclear disarmament will determine how the people of Tangney will vote in the future. The Tangney electorate is mainly suburban and is south-east of Perth. Its residential areas range from strips of million dollar, river front homes backed by expensive suburbs to some of the cheapest housing in the city. There is a State Housing Commission area developed for World War II returned servicemen, and another of high density units occupied mainly by disadvantaged people. Contrasting with these divergent residential areas, Tangney takes in a significant rural sector in Canning Vale. This includes a specially zoned kennel area where many of the State's top dog breeders live.

Tangney includes the three industrial areas of Myaree, Welshpool and Canning Vale which offer a wide range of employment opportunities. Within Tangney we have the State's only brewery, with its lead brand Swan Lager achieving significant international sales. Tangney is also the proposed site for the National Police Training Academy.

Due to the efforts of local government, church and other groups, Tangney has become a major retirement area offering specialised accommodation and care at complexes including Tuscan Street Retirement Village, Swan Cottage Homes, Rowethorpe Settlement and Sherwin Lodge, plus Weeronga Homes and the Air Force Association Estate just on its borders. Tangney is well endowed with educational institutions and this pleases me because I firmly believe that the future prosperity of our nation will reflect the commitment we show now to training and increasingly the retraining of our workforce. We could learn a lesson from the Japanese experience. Faced with a lack of physical resources they were forced to import these but made up by improving use of their human resources. By contrast in Australia we export our wealth of material resources and import our skills. As a former technical and further education trades lecturer I have a keen interest in expansion of vocational education. For too long we have allowed our vocational institutions to become underutilised while we have chosen the soft option of importing skills.

The results are evident in our unemployment figures and the general state of our economy. In the good times of full employment we may have got away with such an approach. Today, to restrict the contribution of TAFE colleges to job creation by not giving them the resources they need would be a waste of our opportunities. I am not talking about the cultural luxury of an academic education, or even invoking some principle of the right to be educated; I am emphasising the vital link between vocational education and employment and between vocational education and national economic health. Austria's Chancellor Bruno Kreisky recognised this when he said:

We have developed more professional schools during the past decade than in all our previous history. These educate youths for the skilled labour market. That's why General Motors is bringing a plant here-because of our skilled labour pool. All this reduces the dangers of unemployed youngsters.

Austria has achieved a remarkable economic recovery since Soviet and Allied occupying troops withdrew in 1955. Unemployment then was 5.4 per cent, now it is 3.5 per cent, and inflation is only 4.1 per cent.

The successful economies of the future will be those that make the best use of new technology-and that requires trained people. To gain a long term economic recovery we must devote more of our resources to vocational education, not take the razor to it as did the previous Government, acting like a short sighted barber cutting his customer's neck because he could not afford to pay for a full shave. In Tangney we have the vital educational resources of the Western Australian Institute of Technology, the Bentley and Thornlie Technical Colleges and the Bentley Senior College. All are vocationally oriented institutions. WAIT in particular has the potential to create new employment opportunities by its Technology Park, soon to be put into operation. I hope this Parliament will increase spending in such vital areas, for unemployment in Tangney is a critical problem, as it is throughout Australia. From December 1981 to December 1982 the number of unemployment benefit recipients in Tangney rose by 75 per cent and in some areas by over 100 per cent, while nationally unemployment rose by the lesser but still staggering amount of 56 per cent.

The legacy of seven years of Liberal neglect of the unemployed in Tangney is a heart rending group of normally productive members of society who cannot pay their home mortgages and hire purchase commitments out of their meagre dole payments, and are faced with the prospect of losing all that they have worked for as their savings are exhausted. All this has been in the name of uncaring monetarist policies. Chancellor Kreisky had a more compassionate and more practical point of view when he said:

I am a relatively old man who was deeply impressed in youth by massive unemployment and its political consequences. I always resolved not to allow unemployment to grow again. It is more expensive to have 100,000 unemployed than to keep them working.

In 1974 we, as a Socialist Government, began a series of measures which private enterprise didn't like. Thus the Government went into the market and helped people build houses. At the same time we concentrated on developing State resources.

An aspect of unemployment that I feel does not receive the attention it deserves is the consequent loss of experiential education. This is a significant loss to the collective level of skills held by the Australian work force, and I urge more attention to work experience projects for unemployed youth, in the short term.

Those collecting unemployment benefits are not, however, the only people living in poverty because of the insensitive economic incompetence of the previous Government. For the hundreds of thousands of Australians dependent on social security benefits, the last seven years have seen a steady decline in their real income to a level which has forced many of them below the poverty line, crushed by the weight of Government indifference to their suffering. This is the Liberal legacy throughout Australia, and it was directly responsible for the people's outright rejection of the Government that foisted it on them. Fortunately, we are not alone in facing the major task before us. The great Australian people are with us. This was well demonstrated at the recent National Economic Summit Conference when groups from many walks of Australian society with quite different and often conflicting interests met in a mood of co-operation in pursuit of national recovery. That was the first step forwards national reconciliation. This process will continue.

In Tangney I am proud to say that there are many community groups achieving positive things by their own effort. Too often they are not given the recognition they deserve. I must at least pay credit to Communicare, a large volunteer-based welfare group giving emergency and on-going help in the hardest hit areas of Tangney, backed by several local churches and service groups and only recently by small Government grants; to Workforce 80, which is a community- based employment service seeking out casual jobs for the unemployed; to the City of Melville Citizens' Emergency Relief Fund, which is probably unique in its endeavours to establish a $100,000 investment fund to earn interest for distribution to people in distress with donations and interest-free loans coming from local business, service clubs and individuals; to the Gosnells Information Centre and the just opened Law Centre; to the Vaudevillians Club, which is devoted to regular charity performances; to the Queen Park and Melville Toy Libraries; and to the many service, youth, parent, church and self-help groups which have helped build a unique community.

Sporting and cultural groups have also made a big contribution to the quality of life in Tangney, continuing a self-help tradition that has been backed by local councils which are very sensitive to the needs of their citizens. I mention the Willetton Sports Club, the Melville Community Arts Association, the Rossmoyne Arts Group and the Canning Agricultural Society as examples of these. Many people in Tangney are working, voluntarily, for the good of all. They are deserving at the very least of praise and, where possible, of financial support from this Parliament.

A problem which no amount of local effort can alleviate, however, is that of rising interest rates. It is a problem of great significance in my electorate, where many people are struggling to buy and to keep their homes. For people on an average income the home is the single greatest investment they will ever make . It is their only chance to get into the heady, tax-free world of capital gains , in which many wealthy members of our society seem to move all the time. It is their security in old age. Small wonder, then, that home loan interest rates are such an emotive subject for most people. The electorate uses interest rates as a measure of a government's success, and its concern. In 1975 savings bank loans for new housing could be obtained at rates as low as 8.75 per cent. By 1976 that had crept to 9.25 per cent, and by 1980 to 10 per cent. By 1981 it was up to 11. 5 per cent, and in 1982 it reached its peak at 13.5 per cent. Our task must be to continue to accelerate the drop in home loan interest rates begun this year, and undo the damage of a seven-year assault on the average family.

While discussing interest rates just now I touched on another topic which concerns me immensely-tax evasion. I recall the words of Professor Russell Mathews, consultant on taxation to the previous Government, when he said in 1981 :
The essential problem is not to make the rich pay higher rates of tax than the poor. It is to make the rich pay any income tax at all.

Of employed members of the Tangney work force 86 per cent are wage and salary earners. Pay-as-you-earn tax deductions leave them little scope for defrauding the Australian people, but the same restraints are not applied to paper shuffling millionaires who are in no way productive, but, who bludge on the benefits of our society, by avoiding to pay their share. It seems that the comradeship that characterised Australia when we faced external threat during the World Wars has been replaced by an 'I'm all right Jack' and 'Up yours' attitude. This is a threat to the fabric of Australian society today. It is an internal threat from the socially irresponsible tax cheats whose desires to accumulate more wealth than they need condemn two million Australians to living below the poverty line.

Last year Eric Risstrom of the Taxpayers Association estimated the loss of revenue through tax evasion and avoidance at $7 billion. Ponder for a moment what help we could bring to millions with that money; what hope we would have for the prompting of an economic recovery; and how closely that amount parallels the deficit we face next year. I fully support the moves of this Government to use retrospective legislation and whatever other methods are necessary to recover from the tax bludgers what is not rightfully or morally theirs. The implementation of a fairer taxation system that provides revenue based on ability to pay and does not rely on unfair and inflationary indirect taxes is one part of what I believe the Australian Labor Party stands for. This goal is subsumed by the urgent need for a more equitable distribution of national income . That is what the Labor Party is all about and I believe our success as a Government will be measured in part by the degree to which we accomplish that redistribution. A fundamental difference between this Government and the conservatives is, I believe, one of approach to measuring costs borne by the community. The narrow view of those opposite is that they are measured in dollars and cents.

The broader view of this side of the House is that the social costs are the most important. They manifest themselves in the alienation from society of the unemployed, their loss of self-esteem, the anxieties of the disadvantaged and family breakdowns exacerbated by uncaring economic and social policies, to name a few. Personal suffering cannot be measured in monetary terms, but we must consider the social costs first if we are to pursue the true object of government, and that is the social benefit to the community. The two sides of the House also differ in their commitment to basic fairness, a fact most graphically illustrated at the recent Constitutional Convention when the Liberal Party joined with its cohorts, the Queensland Nationals, in an attempt to destroy agreement by unfairly stacking their delegations. In the minds of the Opposition and perhaps in their fondest dreams shades of the disgraceful tactics of 1975 linger on. I would remind honourable members who sit on the other side that they are no longer in government. The people of Australia have rejected that confrontationlist approach. If those honourable members have any care for the will of the people they purport to serve, at least they should recognise the wishes so clearly expressed at the national elections and the State elections that preceded them.

Differing concerns for fairness are also apparent in the issue of electoral reform. In my State of Western Australia, the right of electors to choose fairly has been destroyed by the outrageous gerrymander created and maintained by the Liberal Party. There is a blatant absence of democracy in the Western Australian Parliament. The size of electorates for the State's lower House varies from 3, 000 to 18,000 voters, a malapportionment factor of six. Politically inspired manipulation of the boundaries, which in large part are set by the Parliament, has ensured that this gross imbalance greatly favours the conservative parties. In Tangney we have the worst example of gerrymander in the State seat of Clontarf.

The electoral injustice in the lower House, however, pales into insignificance when we consider the Legislative Council, the so called upper House. Electorates for upper House seats vary from 6,000 to 86,000 voters-a weighting for some Liberal and Country Party voting areas of up to 1,500 per cent. The weighting and the gerrymander is so great that in the entire 95-year history of responsible government in Western Australia the Labor Party has not once gained control of the upper House, despite being in government for a total of 35 years. At the recent State election Labor achieved 54 per cent of the popular vote, but gained only eight of the 18 Council seats; a mere 44 per cent.

Mr Deputy Speaker, in Western Australia the conservatives preside over the most undemocratic House of Parliament in Australia, a national disgrace which will reflect on this Parliament if it is allowed to continue. The only body which can reform the Western Australian Parliament is the Western Australian Parliament. There is no provision for referendum or other appeal to the people without parliament's-and that means Liberal-consent. The impetus for reform may have to come from this Parliament. Throughout its history the Western Australian Legislative Council has always vetoed Labor proposals for reform, while rubber- stamping Liberal decisions on re-arrangement of electoral boundaries. I speak on behalf of all fair minded citizens in wishing Brian Burke every success when he moves to bring the voting procedures for the Western Australian Parliament to embrace the one vote one value principle.

Before I close my maiden speech, Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to refer to a trend which I hope will introduce a new sense of reason and fairness to our nation's parliaments; that is the growing involvement of women in politics. In the past Australia has been the poorer for their absence. In the Western Australian State elections five new women, all of them Labor, were elected, equal to the total number in the previous 95 years. Federally, Wendy Fatin won the seat of Canning, adjoining Tangney, with the third largest swing in the nation. We look forward to Heather O'Connor joining their number on 28 May. This bodes well for the process of national reconstruction. To regain our economic growth we need all the human resources of talent, skill, enthusiasm and determination we have, and women possess slightly more than 50 per cent of our national stock of human resources. To under-utilise them in any field from parenting to politics is to waste an essential opportunity. Certainly I am proud to represent an electorate named after the first woman member of the Senate, Dame Dorothy Margaret Tangney, a Senator for Western Australia for 25 years from 1943 to 1968-a very great lady of Australian politics and of the Australian Labor Party.

In closing, I want to make brief reference to what is probably the greatest challenge facing all nations today, that is averting the threat of nuclear war. Today the human race holds not only its own destiny in its hands but also its very survival in delicate balance. I believe that the road to peace is not paved with ever more powerful or more numerous nuclear weapons; nor is it built on notions of limited war or winnable nuclear exchanges. These concepts are an affront to the intelligence. The road to peace and security of continued existence is in nuclear disarmament. This Parliament should use its influence to promote that aim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I congratulate the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear) for a good maiden speech. May I also take the opportunity to congratulate the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) who spoke a little while ago. I think we on this side of the House could take a very close look at the way in which the honourable member for Wakefield laid down a creed which could well be followed for Liberal philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government was elected to office on the promise that it would end, as it put it, the politics of confrontation and replace them with the politics of consensus. This is an ideal that should be applauded. The promise was translated into one of the objectives of the Government and it was expressed in the Governor-General's Speech as follows:
My new Government has pledged itself to the pursuit of national reconciliation, national recovery and national reconstructiion.

The spirit of co-operation which marked the National Economic Summit Conference last week has, my advisers believe, laid good foundations for a renewed national effort to enable Australia and its people to surmount the present grave crisis and indeed emerge from it a more united, stronger, and better nation.
The comprehensive program I have outlined is designed to further the great national goals of reconciliation, recovery and reconstruction.

How has the Government measured up to keeping this promise? In the case of its policies, its actions and its attitudes over the South West Tasmania dam issue, the answer has to be not at all. In fact, if one were a Tasmanian, one would be entitled to believe that both the Government's rhetoric during the election campaign and the objectives which were framed through the Governor-General's Speech were nothing more than a cynical fraud. In fact, if one looks at the jackboot actions of the Government and the way in which it has put the boot into Tasmania, one sees that its attempts at national reconciliation and unity are nothing more than humbug.

Let us look at the Government's sorry record. We can look at it in three distinct areas. First of all, the Government has failed to carry out any real or meaningful negotiations with the Tasmanian Government; secondly, a succession of ministerial actions and blunders reveal that there never was a fair dinkum desire to have realistic negotiations at all; and thirdly, the fierce anti- Tasmanian feelings exposed in the tirades of a succession of Government speakers in this House meant that there never was any real hope of negotiations taking place at all.

Let us look at these three things one by one. The Goverment pleads that it has attempted to negotiate with the Tasmanian Government. What rot! What rubbish! The truth is this: Not one Minister has been to Tasmania or has sought to be briefed by the Tasmanian Government or the Hydro-Electric Commission. Not one Minister has spoken to his counterpart in the Tasmanian ministry or has tried to understand the Tasmanian view at all. Not one Minister has been there to talk to the Tasmanian Government or its statutory authorities. Worse than that, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been invited five times to come to Tasmania to speak to the Premier, to visit the area, to try to understand the Premier's view on the matter and to understand what the issue is all about. He has not accepted one of those five invitations.

A number of letters have been sent to the Premier by Mr Hawke. They were obviously sent to create a public relations atmosphere for the Government to be able to plead that it was trying to negotiate. But these letters were nothing more than a sham, because in every case the bottom line was along these lines: Sure we will negotiate; sure we will try to see our way round this problem but we will do that only when you stop building the dam. Mr Hawke has said that he would come to Tasmania and talk to the Tasmanian Government, but first of all it must stop the dam. That is some attempt at negotiation, some consensus, some attempt at national unity and some attempt at national reconciliation.

Let us move on to the second point I made, the disgraceful actions of a succession of blundering Ministers. First of all, Senator 'It seemed like a good idea' Evans. Let there be no mistake about it. When Biggles sent off the Royal Australian Air Force to spy on Tasmania, he did it deliberately, he did it without regard to any attempt at reconciliation; he did it without regard to the fact that he was really setting Australians against Australians, that he was using the RAAF in a mean and disgraceful way. If he had gone to the Tasmanian Government and said 'I would like to send my officers into the South West. We want to know what you are doing. We want to know what you are up to in your construction plans and we want to record the actions that you have taken' the Tasmanian Government would have allowed him to come. Instead he sent RAAF aircraft and pilots into the Tasmanian area to spy on the Tasmanian people. Surely nobody can pretend that this was an act of reconciliation, that this was an act of consensus or that this was an act that was designed to bring Australia together. Of course it was not.

The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes)-known as 'Drongo' to some of the commentators in the Gallery who have observed what has been happening-just went along with the Attorney-General's actions. He has pleaded that he did not quite understand what was involved. This is a senior Minister in a government which pretends to be committed to trying to see its way round this issue in a spirit of reconciliation. Does anybody honestly believe that the Minister did not know what he was doing when he acceded to the disgraceful request of the Attorney- General? Again there can be only one answer to that question. Of course he knew and he did it without regard to the effect at all, because the Hawke Government has only one aim in mind, regardless of what the Tasmanian Government wants to do, regardless of what the Tasmanians have asked it to do, and that is to stop the dam.

We move on to the next Minister in this disgraceful charade, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). Even before attempts at negotiation had begun with the Tasmanian Government by the Hawke Government, what was Mr Jones saying in Tasmania?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is not referring in the correct manner to honourable members. He has called Mr Barry Jones 'Mr Jones'. He has used the word 'Drongo' and he has used the word 'Biggles' in referring to Ministers. I ask that you request him to use the proper terminology.
—The point of order is noted. I would ask the honourable member for Bass to take note of the usual courtesies.

—Yes, I will, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of course I am only following a pattern that was laid down by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) in the very first hours of the Thirty-third Parliament being called together in this place. So let there be no mistake about who is setting the practice in the House. So, as I was saying, we move to the Minister for Science and Technology. At the very time that these charlatans on the other side were pretending to negotiate with Tasmania--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I take offence at the honourable member for Bass referring to members on this side as charlatans. I ask him to withdraw.
—I ask the honourable member for Bass not to exacerbate the problem. He should ensure that he addresses the House in the appropriate manner.

—The Minister for Science and Technology, at the very time that the Government was pretending to negotiate with Tasmania, was in Tasmania himself, really stirring up the pot. What was he saying? He was saying that when his party got into office he, if he was a Minister, would come to Tasmania and bring Australian Federal Police officers with him. He said he would take them into the area of the proposed dam and challenge the Tasmanian Government and its police force to remove him. What an act of reconciliation! Despite a need to ensure an appropriate atmosphere in order to try to see a way through this problem the Minister was set on a deliberate course to make sure that no such atmosphere could ever exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we come to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen). He is a man who is supposed to have responsibility for the carriage of this very delicate negotiation. The debate in this House last week revealed one thing very clearly-that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has no idea whatsoever about the details of his Government's policy on declaring, proclaiming or acquiring the South West National Park area or a buffer zone. He has absolutely no idea at all. He was asked a series of questions about how much of the area would be proclaimed, how much might be acquired and whether it would be a park or a buffer zone. He was asked a series of questions about what would be involved in compensation for Tasmania. He was asked whether we would be compensated for lost future dam potential, the stands of timber, the minerals or Hydro-Electric Commission work on services of which contractors would be deprived? He could not answer one question. Although the debate went on for several hours and he had every opportunity to answer, he did not.

We must ask: Why did he not answer those questions? Probably it was because of ignorance but in effect he let the cat out of the bag. He made it absolutely crystal clear to everybody that there was no point in knowing the detail of the Government's policy because he knew that the Government had only one policy-to stop the dam at all costs. If the Government had a negotiating position he would have known the details that my colleagues and I asked for. But he did not have one answer. I state again: If the Government seriously had a negotiating position, the Minister responsible for the negotiations would have had the details at his fingertips. He did not know one single fact. The reason he did not know was that he knew that he did not have to, that the Government was not going to negotiate; the Government was only intent on stopping the dam.

Now we come to the third point that I made about Government attitudes. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who has been taking points of order, might like to take a note of some of the adjectives and nouns that were used in relation to not only my colleagues beside me now-the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman)- but Tasmanians as a whole. They are not just Tasmanians; they happen to be Australians. Instead of taking irrelevant points of order just to waste a bit of time he might care to go to Hansard and check what his miserable colleagues had to say about Tasmanians. A list of insults has been compiled from the speeches of practically every Labor member who spoke on the matter. Every Labor speaker loaded his debate with insults. They left no room at all for an acknowledgement that many of us have honest views about this matter. The level of mockery and ridicule which speaker after speaker on the Government side levelled at Tasmanians was disgraceful. I hope the honourable member for McMillan takes note of the list. Tasmanians were called maggots, vandals, treacherous, Noddies--

TALK.START.PARA: —You said it.

—There it is again. Let all Tasmanians listening note the list, which once again confirms the Government's attitude to Tasmania. If the Government really believes it is creating a climate in which the Tasmanian Government will talk to it, negotiate with it, why do its supporters create this climate of ridicule and insult? The list goes on. Tasmanians were called Constable Plods, rapacious, small minded, cheap, grubby and cowards. I did not notice any fair- minded or objective Government supporters taking points of order during the speeches that included those sorts of insults.
—Maybe they are representative.
—No, that is where you are wrong.
—Order! The honourable member will ignore interjections and direct his comments through the Chair.

—They not only got stuck into Tasmanians as a group but they also had to use the poor excuse that the Tasmanian Press was the worst in Australia, it was not fair, it was not balanced and it was subject to the biggest monopoly in the country. They said it was the unfairest in the country. An analysis of all those speeches on 4 and 5 May reveals one common thread-that any Tasmanian who happens to have a pro-dam view is a criminal and that he is bewitched by the HEC . The Government attributes absolutely no merit to anyone who does not accord with its view, which almost entirely is taken from the publications of the Tasmanian Wilderness Society. Some consensus! Some effort to understand the other bloke's point of view! Some resolve to achieve the grand and noble aims which the Prime Minister so often likes to talk about!
—Give the other blokes a go. Come on.

—If the Minister for Territories and Local Government had not set such a stupid course for his Government-he is one of the prime people responsible-I might have sat down to let one of the members from his side have a go. But, because the Government is determined to cause disunity, far from conciliation, I am not going to.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, who really is responsible for this woeful and sad record? In the normal course the Prime Minister should have accepted some responsibility for it , but in this case he accepted all the responsibility. On election night, the very night that he was elected and was making speeches to the country, he singled out Tasmania. He assured Tasmania that he understood the effect of the vote in Tasmania and promised that he would make a special effort to try to bring Tasmanians back into the fold. He promised that there would be a special effort. Some effort! On 8 March his second news conference in as many days was reported in the Hobart Mercury and many other publications. He was reported as saying that the dam would not be built but that he hoped it could be stopped through negotiations rather than a legal challenge through the High Court of Australia. He said:

I regard the question of Tasmania as so important that I will personally be assuming prime responsibility for the discussions with Tasmania. I think it is of such importance I shall accept that responsibility and I will act in association with relevant Ministers.

There it is. Mr Hawke, by his own words of 8 March, accepts the bungling and the actions of his Ministers and all those honourable members on the Government side who have spent time in the chamber on a tirade against Tasmanians, their fellow Australians. The Prime Minister has ignored the pious election night statement that he made. He has ignored his declaration of full responsibility for the negotiations with Tasmania. Certainly, he has ignored the noble sentiments that were set out in the Governor-General's Speech.

Constitutionally the Tasmanians have the right to build their dam. They have given to the Premier of Tasmania a clear mandate to build the dam. I ask only that the Hawke Government really believe in national reconciliation and unity. If it does, it will allow the Tasmanians to get on with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Bendigo, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I call upon the House to extend to him the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to acknowledge the very high honour bestowed upon me by the electors of Bendigo, and publicly thank the substantial number of our party members and supporters who contributed so greatly to our decisive victory on 5 March. The policies we put before the people in the recent Federal election, entailing a program of economic growth and reconstruction, social reform and a vision of a more united and equal society, were overwhelmingly endorsed, not just by the people of Bendigo but by all Australians. The people of my electorate resoundingly rejected the anti- Bendigo policies of the previous Government, and chose instead to elect a government committed to getting Bendigo back to work.

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time since Federation, Bendigo now enjoys a State Labor member of Parliament, a Federal Labor Member of Parliament, and at the same time a State Labor Government and Federal Labor Government. For the first time since Federation, Bendigo can be assured of a total and genuine commitment to the needs and interests of the electorate. Already, the Government has begun the process of getting Bendigo back to work. Already, our Government has shown its commitment to restore the Bendigo economy, generate local job opportunities and plan co-operatively and imaginatively for the future. The Bendigo Ordnance Factory, which was destructively attacked by the previous Government and its razor gang, has already been strengthened and supported by our Government. Not only have we rejected for all time the proposition that the factory be stripped down and sold to private enterprise, but projects worth more than $3m were announced two weeks ago by the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Howe), with further projects to be announced in the latter half of this year.

An amount of $14m has been allocated to upgrade and refurbish completely the armoured centre at Puckapunyal Army Base. The work will be completed by 1985 and will generate 500 direct and indirect jobs, with a peak on-site work force of 175 during 1984. Discussions between the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and the Bendigo College of Advanced Education have already taken place regarding the reinstatement and future development of the engineering course axed under the previous Government's razor gang. After lying idle for seven months because of funding conflicts between the previous Government and the Victorian State Government, the 60-bed Stellar Anderson wing of the Bendigo Home and Hospital for the Aged will now be opened, following constructive and co-operative discussions between our Government and the Victorian State Government. Importantly also, our Government has already confirmed its rejection of the Davidson Inquiry recommendations to dispense with cross-subsidisation of telephone charges and costs. Such a policy proposed for implementation by the previous Government would have doubled STD phone charges, increased rentals-by up to $900 for many of my constituents-and effectively destroyed our rural towns and decentralised industries.

Before I comment on particular aspects of the Governor-General's Speech, it is important to emphasise the dual commitment of our Government to both economic growth and social reform. That dual commitment contrasts rather markedly with the policies of the previous Government, which achieved neither growth nor reform. Indeed, during the past seven years, Australians have witnessed a concerted and deliberate effort by the previous Government to stifle, postpone and in some cases reverse reforms achieved by past governments particularly Labor governments. Not only have social, parliamentary and legal reforms been postponed in the name of economic recession, but also deep and unnecessary divisions have been created in Australian society. Australians will not forget the overt and calculated efforts of the previous Government to reduce health standards and to create divisions between those who are healthy and those who are sick, and between those who could afford health insurance and those who could not.

Australians will not forget the deliberate policy of the previous Government to undermine and divide our education system, not just by subverting the independence of the Schools Commission, not just by concerted attacks on the standards of our government schools, but also by providing the greatest percentage increase in funding to the wealthiest private schools at the expense of needy non-government schools and our government school sector. Australians will not forget the massive shift in the economic burden from those most able to pay to those least able to pay, or the unnecessary divisions created between those who actually pay tax and those who avoid tax. Only under the previous Government was the failure of that Government to provide work for almost 30 per cent of our young people used as a means of attacking our youth as dole-bludgers , denying their adult right to a basic level of income security, and propagandising against the right of women, particularly married women, to work.

The people of Australia overwhelmingly endorsed our policies of economic recovery and our policies of social, economic, legal and parliamentary reform. The implementation of our reforms in relation to universal health care, widened access to and participation in the arts, the protection of Australia's national and cultural heritage, including South West Tasmania, the introduction of the principle of one vote, one value, the broadening of the Freedom of Information Act, the establishment of a royal commission into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on veterans of the Vietman war, the introduction of legislation dealing with discrimination on the basis of sex, and our firm commitment to genuine equality of educational opportunity, are all overdue reforms, and will be to the benefit of all electors in my electorate of Bendigo, as they will be to all Australian people.

I now turn to consider specific aspects of the Governor-General's Speech and the programs of our Government. I welcome the establishment of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, representing governments, business, unions, farmers and community groups, to advise on economic developments and provide a forum for community consultation on national economic and social strategies. With the exception of honourable members on the opposite side of the House, all Australians recognise the need for constructive consultation and co-operation as part of the urgent task of restoring employment opportunities and removing the acute deprivation caused by present massive unemployment. I welcome also this Government's commitment to a community works program including jobs on local roads.

Throughout my electorate more than 4,000 persons are registered as unemployed. While very good progress is being made by the Victorian Government under its capital works program and employment initiatives program, there are still more than 50 excellent jobs programs submitted by councils and community groups throughout my electorate to the State Government, which remain unfunded, and thousands still without jobs. The municipal councils of my electorate are delighted by the Government's jobs on local roads program. Under the policies of the previous Federal and State Liberal governments, substantial sums of road funds were channelled into vast freeway developments in metropolitan cities at the expense of rural and arterial roads. Many councils have simply been unable to maintain local roads in a safe and serviceable condition, and in at least one Victorian rural shire the local council has been forced to take the extraordinary action of actually ripping up its local bitumenised roads because of these serious and long term funding shortages.

Far more disturbing, however, than the loss of country roads due to lack of funds has been the misery of homelessness that I have witnessed in my electorate . Adequate shelter is a fundamental human right yet in my electorate of Bendigo homeless unemployed young people sleep in country railway stations and abandoned cars, low income families wait over two years for housing commission accommodation, and over 300 elderly people await local government sponsorship to obtain an elderly person's home unit. Such is the poverty of the previous Liberal State and Federal housing policies.

It is the young unemployed and the single unemployed who are most vulnerable in times of housing shortage. St Luke's family care in Bendigo last year gave assistance to over 100 homeless young people, estimated as just a fraction of total youth homeslessness in the region, and the Bendigo Urban Emergency Accommodation Resource Centre dealt with 4,700 requests last year for emergency accommodation. One thousand of the requests came from single persons and 750 could not be met by the Centre. The very least that this Government can offer, to raise the standard of living of the individuals trapped in these circumstances, is adequate shelter. I commend our Government's intention to increase the public housing stock and I look forward to a renewed and increased commitment to vital youth housing services. Augmented by measures designed to bridge the deposit gap for home-buyers, I believe this Government will significantly redress existing housing problems, whilst directly creating jobs in the construction industry, and indirectly, in many occupations, through the economic stimulus provided by house construction.

My speech would be incomplete without reference to the educational needs of the electorate of Bendigo. At all levels of education-primary, secondary, technical and tertiary-additional funding from the Government is required to honour our commitment to the principle of genuine equality of educational opportunity and the elimination of disadvantage or discrimination. The very comprehensive and much lauded 1982 Australian Teachers Federation survey of conditions in schools highlighted that in the electorate of Bendigo there are more large secondary school classes than in Victoria as a whole, and a massive 40 per cent of all primary grade sizes exceeds 30 students. Our primary school teachers have less preparation time than in other schools in the State, and immediate maintenance is required in 31 per cent of classrooms. Staffing and capital needs in non- government schools in my electorate are also very evident and 99 per cent of these schools will be more equitably assisted under our policy of stricter needs funding than under the policies of the previous Government.

Serious funding difficulties also exist in relation to the Bendigo Technical and Further Education College and the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. This year more than 100 qualified students have been turned away from our Bendigo TAFE courses and an even greater number have been excluded from our BCAE course because of restrictive quotas. As a nation with one of the lowest tertiary education participation rates in the industrialised world, and a youth unemployment rate of 30 per cent, the exclusion of qualified and enthusiastic students is senseless and must be halted. Increased access to, and enhanced quality of, tertiary education will be a vital factor in the economic and social reconstruction of Australia.

The rural sector is of fundamental importance to the economic base of my electorate both in employment and income, and equally fundamental to Australia's export earning capacity. As one with a family background in farming, I have been astounded by the frequent and often hysterical outbursts of the Opposition in relation to this Government's attitudes and policies for the rural sector.

Our farmers and our people who live in rural areas demand no more from government than other sections of our community-the right to income stability and security and a fair and reasonable provision of transport, health and educational services. Yet by 1981, after some six years of the high interest rate and otherwise vacuous rural policies of the previous Government, profitability on farms had fallen to its lowest levels, and the ratio of farm debt to income had never been higher. Some 12,500 of our primary producers throughout Australia are now estimated to be living substantially below the poverty line. Honourable members opposite would do well to acknowledge that the only two policies guaranteeing any income stability or security at all to our farmers-the wheat price stabilisation scheme and the wool scheme-were both introduced by Federal Labor governments.

Like the farmers in my electorate, I look forward to the introduction of the National Soil Conservation Program, to the new wheat marketing plan to apply from 1984-85, to commencement of work on the Wimmera-Mallee pipeline project, and to a concerted and vigorous attack by the Commonwealth in conjunction with the States to arrest the very serious salting problem destroying so much of our agricultural land throughout my electorate and Australia.

I should emphasise that in addition to our policies for the rural sector our government is firmly committed to the development of strong, competitive secondary industries. Our program provides for short term protection, support for industrial reconstruction and development of new industries, and the introduction of incentive measures to stimulate industrial research and development.

As indicated in the Governor-General's Speech, it is the intention of our Government to introduce a 'buy Australian' Act into the Federal Parliament. It is important that all Australians recognise that not all of our secondary industries can be internationally competitive on a cost basis. In my electorate of Bendigo, clothing manufacturers Stafford Ellinson produce a fine range of garments distributed throughout Australia and provide employment for more than 200 people. Stafford Ellinson is more than competitive internationally on the basis of output per person but cannot compete on a cost basis with low wage exporting nations. Who in this House would suggest that the Australian people employed in Stafford Ellinson should have their wages reduced to 50c per hour? Who also would argue for the abolition of protection for our clothing industries , with its consequent loss of jobs and subsequent social tragedy?

My final comments relate to the field of communications. In this national public broadcasting week, our Government has expressed support for public broadcasting networks which provide information and access to diverse groups and individuals, and which strengthen our local communities. Just two weeks ago I was pleased to attend the first anniversary celebrations of my electorate's first community radio station-3CCC-FM. The people of my electorate are proud of the achievements of 3CCC. Broad community access is provided throughout central Victoria, more than 110 volunteers contribute to programming, and more than 1000 of my constituents in the electorate of Bendigo are paid subscribers. Station 3CCC enjoys the distinction of being the radio station with the highest percentage of Australian music content, and broadcasts via the strongest signal of any non-metropolitan FM radio station in Australia. I am confident the contribution of our Government in this year of communications will support and encourage community radio stations such as 3CCC, as well as guaranteeing the commercial media networks in my electorate-particularly regional television- freedom from encroachment by metropolitan and overseas interests.

In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is with great honour that I stand to support and endorse the program of our Government, which I believe to be one of compassion, economic restoration and growth, and social and legal reform. It is, I believe, a program of vision and optimism for the people of my electorate of Bendigo, and for all Australians.
Sitting suspended from 6.36 to 8.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I congratulate you on your appointment . I assure you that you have the respect of this Parliament and I know that you will serve it with dignity. I also wish other office holders in this place well in the performance of their duties.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first opportunity that I have had to speak generally in this House in my new role as shadow minister for sport and recreation. I would like to make some comment on that new role and what I consider ought to be the priorities for sport in this country. However, before doing so, I feel that I must make some comment on the Government's performance since coming to office.

I am sure that I am not the first to complain, and I know that I will not be the last, about the Government's performance. I am becoming heartily sick of its use of that very tired and old chestnut of blaming the previous Government for just about everything. Since the Australian Labor Party came to office on 5 March, we have had a line of broken promises and sidestepped issues. Everything with perhaps the exception of the weather has been blamed on the apparent excesses of the previous Government. In a little over two months, just about every major undertaking given by the Australian Labor Party, and on which it was voted into office, has gone by the board. That surely must be some sort of record. Never before has so much been promised by so many and broken so quickly.
Let me give some examples. The people of Australia were promised less tax in Mr Hawke's policy speech of 16 February, in the course of which he said:
Immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australian taxpayers.

Instead we have threats of more tax. Already we see proposed the introduction of a 20 per cent sales tax on retreaded tyres. This is despite a pre-election promise which recognised the disruptive potential of such a tax upon the economy of the road transport industry and upon, particularly, employment prospects for small business in many rural towns and cities.
The people of Australia were promised petrol price cuts of 3 cents a litre. Mr Hawke said in his policy speech:

Labor will reduce the price of petrol by cancelling the January 1 oil price increase of $3.23 per barrel. This will have the effect of reducing the price of petrol by the order of three cents a litre.

This was the promise. The reality was a reduction of 1.5 cents a litre. In fact, because of State government policies in Victoria and New South Wales, motorists in those States will derive no benefit at all. We now face a proposal that motor car registration and third party insurance may be collected by way of a petrol levy. Such a levy would see a rise of at least 11 cents a litre occur in the price of petrol. Such a burden would fall heavily upon country people, who must travel long distances, and very heavily on low income earners and pensioners who generally own smaller and older cars. The question, what effect would such a significant rise in petrol prices have on the tourist industry, should be asked.

The people of Australia were promised a united country. The Australian Labor Party preached consensus. 'Hawke: Bringing Australia Together' was the catchcry. But what did we get? On coming back to this Parliament we witnessed a High Court challenge lodged against Tasmania by the Government within days of coming to office. Consensus and harmony-tell that to farmers whose shearing sheds have been destroyed, whose workers have been attacked and whose lives and those of their families have been threatened by members of the Australian Workers Union, who cannot be brought under control, who have refused to allow shearers to earn their living and who are terrorising fellow Australians with guerrilla warfare tactics.

But that is not the only example of neglect of rural people. Items as fundamental as water programs and conservation measures are also to be given the chop or, to be more accurate, have not been thought about at all. It is not a coincidence that electorates along the Murray River-Mallee, Riverina and Murray- all returned National Party members with an increased majority. The demands of people along the Murray River are not excessive. They do not want $200m grants such as Qantas Airways Ltd and Trans Australia Airlines have had to help them with their tax problems. They do not want $46,000-odd spent on food and drink for them. That was the cost of entertaining the Economic Summiteers.

In the last two months, we have heard of all the things that the Government will not now be doing. What the people of Australia would like to hear, especially those in my electorate of Mallee, is what is going to be done to help them earn their living, particularly now when rural Australia is facing very troubled times. Farm costs-wages, fuel, chemicals and fertilisers-have all been rising steadily and have now got out of hand.

Recovery from the drought is certainly under way throughout most of Australia but its effects will be felt for many years and it is absolutely essential that existing drought arrangements should continue. The measures in that regard which were introduced by the former Government were appropriate and generous and will contribute to the emergence of primary industry from the disastrous drought with an ability to improve productivity. Therefore, it is important that those concessions, which allow primary producers to write off in full in the year of expenditure the cost of providing dams, bores and water reticulation facilities, as a means of protecting themselves against drought, should be continued in their present form by the Government.

The previous Government had plenty of successes in relation to agriculture and assisting country people generally. It supported the beef industry and introduced the household support scheme. It provided many millions of dollars for drought relief and disease eradication. I might also refer to the continuing superphosphate and nitrogenous fertiliser bounties, the continuance and expansion of the wool floor price scheme, and the provision of research and promotion, better communications and the bicentennial road and water programs. It was also responsible for the introduction of tax averaging for primary producers. Moreover, the previous Government set the lead in abolishing probate and gift duty. It established the Primary Industry Bank and reintroduced the fuel freight subsidy that had been abolished by the Whitlam Government.

At this time, I wish to congratulate all those who are new members of the Parliament and to mention particularly the two new members from my side of the chamber, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), both of whom have delivered their maiden speeches and have espoused a philosophy that has contributed greatly to the development of this country. May I also congratulate my other neighbouring colleague, the new honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). I look forward to working with him for the benefit of north west Victoria. I welcome the support that he gave in his speech to the establishment of the Wimmera-Mallee pipeline scheme. However, it was most uncharitable of him to suggest that the former Government intended to bring into effect the Davidson report--

TALK.START.PARA: —You did.

—We did not; we rejected it before the last elections. Also, I challenge the honourable member to cite any member of this Parliament who has ever called unemployed youth or other unemployed in the community dole bludgers, or has denied the right of married women to work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Murray and Darling water systems account for 46 per cent of Australia's agricultural production, 15 per cent of its wood products and six per cent of its minerals. The resources of the Murray-Darling have been estimated to support directly and indirectly some two million people and the value of its primary and secondary production is estimated to be in excess of $7,000m annually. The Murray River is regarded as the most important waterway in Australia. It also has storage, and severe salinity, problems. Its water flow has a high variability, with the result that in dry years and during droughts, such as we have had and are still experiencing, dams are down to as low as 10 per cent of capacity.

Salinity levels vary greatly. I do not have to tell the House what effect salinity has on agriculture. It has been described in thousands of articles by hundreds of rural experts as the number one enemy of Australian agriculture. I cannot stress too much how important salinity control measures and water quality control measures are to the future of agriculture in Australia. I should not have to explain the necessity of research into salinity and of the establishment of projects that will reduce the salt burden in rivers such as the Murray. I should not have to explain, but it seems that Government members and some Ministers have still not got the message about salt. I have only to quote the former Opposition spokesman on primary industry, the then shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Senator Walsh. Only a few days ago in the Senate, he said:
. . . 170 tonnes of salt is a very minor addition to the existing load . . .

He was referring to the salinity load of the Murray River. He was, of course, commenting on the decision of the Victorian Environment Protection Authority to grant a licence to a firm of wool merchants who wished to discharge effluent-170 tonnes of salt-into the River Murray from its plant in Albury. He should tell that to the farmers, to the two million or so people who are supported directly and indirectly by the Murray River. Add that attitude to the Government's absolute silence on the future of the $640m water resources program announced by the former coalition Government and we have a government totally lacking in any real concern for, and willingness to give priority to, the needs of agriculture. We have heard no concrete proposals for the management of the Murray from this Government. We have heard vague rumblings from the stand-in Minister, Senator Walsh, that he thinks there will be legislation, not in this session but probably in the Budget Session; not definitely in the Budget Session, but probably. We are able to get legislation passed that will give $200m grants to Qantas Airways Ltd and Trans Australia Airlines, lift election blackouts, even provide bounty payments for air conditioners, but we cannot organise legislation that will get moving on some very real issues facing Australia. One wonders that the priorities of this Government are.

I place before this Government a matter of national importance and priority. A problem of great concern is the 90,000 megalitre loss of water each year in the northern Mallee region of Victoria through evaporation and seepage. I have made constant calls to the present Government to honour the commitment made by the previous Government to provide funds immediately for stage one of the Wimmera- Mallee pipeline. The existing Wimmera-Mallee water supply system is the largest of its kind in the world. The water supply is derived from storages in the Grampians, from the river flows and diversions of southern flowing streams. Distribution of the water over an area of 28,500 square kilometres-almost one- seventh of Victoria-is by means of 16,000-kilometre earthen channels. Water deliveries are made to some 22,000 farms and to 51 towns annually during the winter and spring months. The future development of the system is such that it is certainly not likely to be economically justifiable to construct any major new storages as it is considered that the Grampians are now fully harvested for water supply. It has been indicated and anticipated, therefore, that in future the channel system, particularly in the northern areas where the soils are sandy , must be replaced by pipelines. these pipelines will provide water from the Murray River. This would relieve the Grampians catchment of a large proportion of its supply load. Thus this scarce and most valuable of our natural resources- water-can be harvested, conserved and used to the advantage of at least one- seventh of the State of Victoria which is deficient in rainfall and lacks natural reliable streams. We simply cannot affort the luxury of wasting our most precious natural resource to this extent.

The pipelining of the first stage of the Wimmera-Mallee scheme is equivalent to the construction of another major reservoir in the Grampians system. This would service increased water demands for Victoria, inasmuch as it will greatly assist in safeguarding our existing resources. There is no doubt that the implementing of the pipeline scheme would result in increased productivity which would benefit all Victoria. As the scheme will be of benefit to both State and nation it was considered by the former Government that all capital works, except on- farm costs, must be totally government funded in a similar manner to the Millewa scheme in the northern end of the Mallee. It would not be possible, nor should it be necessary, for land holders to repay capital work costs as they will be incurring considerable expense in providing their own on-farm storage and the necessary reticulation schemes. It is suggested, therefore, that long term finance at concessional rates be made available to farmers to finance their on- farm works and to the municipalities in the area to meet urban supply costs. The inability of farmers to finance such costs without assistance of this nature would in many cases place extreme hardship on them, especially following the present drought. There must also be ample provision made in the scheme to ensure that the capacity exists to provide water for increased demands that could occur in major towns throughout the area.

Another aspect that also needs to be evaluated in any economic considerations being put forward is that of the problem of increasing salinity in the Wimmera- Mallee area. At present hundreds of hectares are out of production because of the seepage from the channel. This seepage can occur up to one kilometre from the channel and it results in the formation of large numbers of salt pans which are totally unproductive. Victoria and Australian urgently need schemes such as this to proceed to boost our economy. The cost today will no doubt be the lowest that we will ever experience. I would welcome an announcement, therefore, that the Federal Government will give priority to the piping of the present Wimmera- Mallee channel system. I ask the Labor Government to state that it will inherit the $640m water resources program established by the Liberal-National Party Government in the same way that it intends to inherit our education and social service programs.

Prior to the election the ALP launched a very weighty document on sport and recreation. While it had a commendable number of words, it said very little that was not already known or accepted. But I am concerned that much of what was relevant and pertinent-I refer here to specific Budget allocations-may be pushed aside, as with so many other pre-election promises, on the pretext of the inherited Budget blowout. Fortunately, to my knowledge, the National Economic Summit Conference did not discuss sport and therefore any reneging of promises in the sport area cannot be justified on any consensus at the Summit. I am concerned that funding for sport will be one of the first things to go. The grand schemes and words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that he would spend $ 50m a year on sport to double immediately the direct allocation of funds to sporting bodies is unlikely to come to fruition if the Government's performance to date is any criterion. I accept that all governments must exercise restraint and should attempt to balance their books, but I urge that the ALP's commitment to the sportsmen and women of this country be not abandoned. In the last 10 years Australia has come a long way, and at a Federal level much has been done.

The Australian Institute of Sport was certainly born of an ALP suggestion on a report commissioned by the late Frank Stewart. But it was under the previous coalition Government that this magnificent complex and training institution came to fruition. In the last few years many millions of dollars have been spent at the AIS. I hope that now that the majority of buildings and facilities have been constructed this Federal Government does not decide to forget about sport and its responsibility to the future world champions, the junior sportsmen of Australia. Already the Government has moved away from expanding the number of sports catered for by the AIS. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism ( Mr John Brown) just this week, in answer to a question I asked, told the House than the number of sports catered for at the Institute would not be increased in the immediate future; that the Government did not favour at this time the AIS's moving into cycling and rowing. What a time to take such a decision! We have the 1984 Olympic Games just around the corner, yet the Minister says it is too early to contemplate national assistance for sports such as cycling and rowing. Tell that to our oarsmen, to our cyclists who have no national training facility and who will not have one for some time.

I accept and believe it is essential that our athletes who attend the AIS should expect adequate accommodation, education and employment opportunities. This Government will receive my support in its endeavours to create a just society and reduce the crisis in unemployment. However, I will continue to argue that only by restored growth and incentive to those who are productive and prepared to use their talents to increase this productivity can this be achieved .

TALK.START.PARA: —In calling the honourable member for Moore I remind honourable members that this is his maiden speech. I hope he will be extended the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in accordance with convention I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your election to the most honoured position in this House. I also congratulate the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees on his election to that office. I would also like to offer my congratulations to the other new members of this House on both sides who, I think, have shown themselves to be a force to be reckoned with in this Parliament. I would also like to offer my best wishes to those new honourable members who are still to make their maiden speeches, because I know with what trepidation I stand here as I make this maiden speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The electors of Moore have given me the honour and privilege of representing them in Federal Parliament, for which I sincerely thank them. I would like to pay tribute to the previous member for Moore, Mr John Hyde. I do so because whilst on the political spectrum Mr Hyde and I were poles apart he had that rare quality in politics which demands admiration-an honesty which allowed him even to attack his own party leadership on matters of principle.
