The seat of Moore has transferred its political allegiance in recent years, firstly from the National Country Party to the Liberal Party and now, for the first time, the voters of Moore have given their confidence to the Australian Labor Party. The electors of Moore in fact elected me to this House with the largest swing in Australia. That is an impressive condemnation of the policies of the previous Government and a definite endorsement of the aims and goals that the Australian Labor Party presented to them. Clearly, the electors of Moore have expressed their opinion about the direction they wish this country to follow.

In population, Moore is the largest seat in Western Australia with over 85,000 electors and an annual growth rate of 5,000 electors. The main rate of growth is in the Shire of Wanneroo but both the Shire of Swan and the Shire of Mundaring have shown increased enrolments. It is a seat which will need to be redistributed before the next election, as within its boundaries the northern suburbs of Perth expand to incorporate 40 per cent of the total growth of the city's metropolitan area. The very nature of the seat is changing, and what was originally a rural area has now become an outer metropolitan electorate with a rural hinterland. The largest local government authority in the seat of Moore is the shire council of Wanneroo. When I first moved into the shire 12 years ago there were fewer than 7,000 persons in that area. In 1983 the shire has a population of 108,000 people. Population growth of this magnitude can produce significant social and economic problems.

Moore is not an industrial centre. Fishing, agriculture and viticulture contribute to the regional economy, as does the enterprise of numerous small businessmen. However, the majority of the electorate work force commute to work, many of them travelling great distances to the central business district of the city of Perth. This daily travel, combined with the rapid growth rate of the area, has resulted in enormous strains on the road system, on public transport and, indeed, on the commuters themselves. These problems confront all outer metropolitan areas and highlight the need for greater concentration on the issue of decentralisation. The Shire of Wanneroo has encouraged the development of service-type and light industry but it needs the support of both the Federal and the State governments if decentralisation is to become a reality and not just another catch-cry. To illustrate the point, a former State government established the Joondalup Development Corporation to plan the development of a sub-regional centre within the Shire of Wanneroo. Unfortunately, the Corporation is now moribund through lack of public funds, a victim of the previous State Government's disastrous economic priorities. Over the last few years the electors of Moore have become disenchanted with governments which seem more concerned with featherbedding the rich and privileged in our society than confronting the real problems of the ordinary citizens of Australia. The ordinary citizens of Australia had a government-which fortunately has been defeated-which was bankrupt in ideas, policies and leadership. The inevitable result of such a government has been to lead this country to the verge of economic stagnation. The problems faced by the electors in Moore are a mirror image of the problems faced by the wider electorate of Australia over the past several years. The issues of housing-coupled with high interest rates- unemployment, cutbacks in education funding, the high cost of living, the decline in living standards and inadequate social welfare payments are the issues confronting not only the electors of Moore but the electors of Australia. These are the issues about which the people of Australia made their decision on 5 March.

Within the electorate of Moore there is a high level of home ownership. Eighty per cent of people living in the electorate own or are buying their own homes. Among this community are many who have suffered financial and social hardship as the result of rising interest rates and the accompanying increase in mortgage repayments over the last few years. Although on the surface the seat of Moore appears affluent, with new homes and new suburbs, within these new suburbs are families struggling to cope with high mortgage repayments, families that by necessity make do with basic furniture and no winter drapes or floor coverings, families whose weekly income is carefully budgeted to meet basic requirements while they struggle to meet the great Australian dream-to own their own homes. A lowering of interest rates will have beneficial effects not only on the people battling to buy their own homes, but also on the building industry and the community at large. In the meantime, however, those with housing problems may also be confronted with the added burden of unemployment.

In the electorate of Moore there is a growing incidence of chronic unemployment for those over 25 years of age which is additional to the high rate of youth unemployment. The latest figures from the only Commonwealth Employment Service office in the electorate-a lamentable situation as this requires the unemployed to travel great distances to register for work-indicate that there were 3,664 persons registered as seeking work; 32 unemployed people were competing for each job vacancy. These figures fail to express the full extent of the wastage of human resources in the elctorate. Firstly, many persons do not register to obtain employment. This includes women, many of whose expectations of obtaining work are severely restricted by the present economic climate, and those seeking part time employment as well as the young school leaver. Secondly, in an electorate the size of Moore it is easier for many of the unemployed to register for work at CES offices situated outside the electorate; so we do not know the true level of unemployment in the electorate of Moore. On the figures that we have, we know that 27 per cent of the unemployed are 19 years of age or younger and 55 per cent are over 25 years old.

I would like to pay a tribute to the Wanneroo Community Youth Support Scheme. The two project officers in that organisation have worked tirelessly on behalf of unemployed youth and deserve greater community support for their efforts. I would like to say to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that the CYSS Scheme is one initiative which must not only continue but also be expanded alongside other initiatives to tackle this immense problem of unemployment.

The former Government's attitude to CYSS was negative. It would have liked to disband the Scheme. Its attitude showed a deplorable contempt for the real problems of the unemployed. I am pleased that this Government places the highest priority on job creation schemes and will take action to alleviate the social disruption caused by unemployment.

I am particularly concerned that the growth of the population and consequential urbanisation, often without adequate planning or community facilities, combined with rising levels of unemployment are reflected in increasing crime in this country. Experts differ, as only experts can, on the impact of urbanisation and unemployment on crime rates. I might add that having worked in the criminal justice system for over 20 years I too claim to have some expertise in this area .

The overrepresentation of persons of Aboriginal descent in criminal statistics in this country is a tragedy. Figures from the Australian Institute of Criminology show that, whereas 2 per cent of the Australian population are Aboriginal, they represent over 30 per cent of the prison population. A survey in Western Australia in 1981 on the rate of imprisonment in that State showed that, as at 30 June 1980, 1,359 persons were sentenced to imprisonment, and of those 439 were Aboriginal. Let us illustrate those figures in another way. During 1980 Western Australia imprisoned Aboriginals at the rate of 1,300 per 100,000 as against 80 per 100,000 for other races. These figures clearly indicate that if one is an Aboriginal, one is much more likely to be arrested than a member of any other racial group and, having been arrested, is much more likely to be sentenced to a term of imprisonment.

There is another issue involved here-the overuse of incarceration as a sentencing option. In fairness, overall Australian imprisonment rates compare favourably with those of other countries. However, within Australia there are wide variations between States. According to recent figures supplied by the Australian Insititute of Criminology, the Northern Territory has the highest rate of imprisonment in this country followed by Western Australia, both of which have large Aboriginal populations. Imprisonment is an expensive luxury and only those who are a danger or a risk to the community should be locked away at the expense of the public. There is, therefore, a need to look at alternatives to imprisonment, such as the fine, the bond, probation and community service orders, particularly for Aboriginal offenders.

As the President of the Civil Rehabilitation Council of Western Australia, I am very much aware of the effect of imprisonment on the family. It is often the spouse and children who suffer most from the imprisonment of the offender. They suffer in two ways: Firstly, in the loss of income through the imprisonment of the breadwinner and, secondly, through the social stigma suffered by the family. For both mother and children these effects can be traumatic.

As a federation we do not have a criminal justice system. We have a number of systems based on the States and Territories as well as that of the Commonwealth. This has created a lack of consistency in sentencing policies which is reflected in the sentencing disparities noted earlier. I am well aware that the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) is concerned with the problem and it is the Government's policy to implement reforms recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission.

I now turn my attention to aspects of the Governor-General's Speech on the occasion of the opening of the Thirty-third Parliament. It is clear that this Government faces the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. What is also clear is that this Government has shown a willingness, as instanced by the National Economic Summit Conference, to seek the co-operation of all sections, to meet the social and economic challenges ahead. The Government-and in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-is to be commended for its initiative in this area. I note and welcome the Government's intention to proceed to fulfil its promise to introduce Medicare. It is hoped to introduce the scheme on 1 January 1984. In an electorate with a high percentage of its population under 14 years the Government's proposed initiatives in education are to be commended, particularly its goal of providing equal opportunities for all Australian children. I also welcome the Government's intention to end the present fragmentation of policies and funding for the aged through the creation of an office of aged care.

The Government is also to be commended for its intention to establish a royal commission to inquire into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on veterans of the Vietnam War. It is now 10 years since the last of the 45,000 servicemen who fought in Vietnam on our behalf returned to Australia. It is a tragedy that almost all of these servicemen had some trouble readjusting to civilian life. Many succeeded, but many did not. The conflict in Vietnam was the first in the history of warfare in which huge quantities of toxic chemicals were sprayed from the air to defoliate the forest, destroy crops, kill pests and kill human beings . One possible result of the veterans' exposure to these toxic chemicals is a condition known as the toxic brain dysfunction. I trust that the royal commission set up by this Government will closely examine the medical evidence on this issue.

I also welcome the Government's intention to introduce legislation dealing with discrimination on the basis of sex or marital status. The intention to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women is also to be welcomed. It has become evident already that the Thirty-third Parliament has benefited from the increased participation of women in its deliberations.

I want to say, in conclusion, that I am an optimist who believes in the future of mankind, and I have a belief in Australia. I believe that under this Government we have the potential to make Australia great again. I should like to finish with these words:
These things shall be! A loftier race
Than e'er the world hath known shall rise,
With flame of freedom in their souls,
And light of knowledge in their eyes.
Nation with nation, land with land,
Unarmed shall live as comrades free;
In every heart and brain shall throb
The pulse of one fraternity.
Thank you, Mr Speaker. I thank the House for its attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I warmly congratulate the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) on an excellent maiden speech in this Parliament. He follows in the footsteps of a very worthy member of the Parliament. I congratulate the honourable member on his contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my great pleasure, Mr Speaker, to congratulate you on your appointment to the highest office the Parliament can offer to any of its members. In so doing I am joined by your Presiding Officer colleague, the honourable member for Queenborough in the Legislative Council of the Parliament of Tasmania, and the honourable member for Huon. I wish you, Mr Speaker, every success, as indeed I wish your Deputy Speaker and the Deputy Chairmen of Committees success as they commence their duties during the current Parliament.

I am indeed honoured to stand here again, having been returned as the Federal member for Denison in the House of Representatives. I would clearly be failing in my duty if I did not place on public record my very great gratitude to an electorate which is a great electorate to represent and which has shown me tremendous loyalty over the past eight years. In 1975, 1977, 1980 and 1983 the electors of Denison have seen fit to send me to Canberra as their representative . I know I speak on behalf of my colleagues in the House of Representatives from Tasmania when I say that I greatly appreciate this honour and that I shall do everything in my power to justify the confidence which has been shown in me by the electors of Denison.

For the benefit of people all around Australia listening to the proceedings, I should mention that this is the debate on the Address-in-Reply, and it is appropriate to remind ourselves and the people of Australia that this is one of but two debates in the parliamentary year in which any member can speak on virtually any subject without restriction. The address to which we are replying is the Speech by His Excellency the Governor-General of Australia, Sir Ninian Stephen, delivered on the opening day of the session. When we criticise anything that is in that Speech, I think that people listening will appreciate that we are not criticising His Excellency, because the Speech is written for His Excellency by the Government of the day. But it is appropriate that we just ponder the words of the Address-in-Reply, the motion before the Chair tonight, which I wholeheartedly support. They are:
May it please Your Excellency:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

In the eight years during which I have been a member of this place, that is the first time that I have heard those words of the motion read during the debate, and it reminds me to congratulate both the mover and the seconder of the motion before the Chair. But it also involves a question as to the content of that motion expressing our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign. Whatever else the people of Australia intended on 5 March, as a result of their votes Australia now has a centralist, socialist, republican government in office. I guess that tonight, and particularly after the performance of the last week or so, there will be tens of thousands of people around Australia scratching their heads and saying: 'Why did we do it?'.

On the performance to date I have no hesitation in saying that the words of the Government's Attorney-General, Senator 'Biggles' Evans, are very apt when he relies on the streaker's defence and says: 'It seemed like a good idea at the time'. After the performance of this week I have to say that there are many people right around Australia saying: 'If this is what this Government is like after seven weeks, what on earth will it be like after three years?' In the light of that, I now predict that when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) goes to the people of Australia asking for referendum support for a fixed term of Parliament of three years, he will suffer a very substantial defeat.

Why do I say that we have a centralist government? The plain fact of the matter is that the Labor Party has always been committed to centralising power in Canberra. It does not believe in the federal system. It does not believe in States rights. It regards the Senate as an unnecessary obstruction to the path of the socialist policies it wishes to implement. I can put it no more fundamentally than did the Prime Minister. If one cares to go back to the Boyer lectures of 1979-these were not extempore words; they were carefully prepared words with meaning and impact-one finds what the now Prime Minister of Australia had to say. He said:

I believe the logical implication of this analysis is that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is, the States-which no longer serve their original purpose, and act--
Honourable members should listen to these words--

as a positive impediment in achieving good government in our current community. This would give us, like the great majority of other countries, one Parliament with powers available to the government to match the responsibilities upon it of protecting and advancing the interests of Australian citizens.

I hear someone say 'hear, hear!' I hear words of support for that proposition. I would like people in Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia to listen . I do not refer to people in Tasmania, of course, because they had the good sense to return five Liberal members for the fourth time running. The way the Labor Government is performing at the moment it will be a decade or more before we will see a Labor member for the House of Representatives from Tasmania. I now wonder what the electors of Western Australia will feel when they discover to their sorrow that those sitting on the benches opposite supposedly representing their States in this House are, in fact, centralists who believe that power and wisdom resides in Canberra and that the decisions for all Australia should be made in Canberra.

The honourable member for Moore who spoke before me made, to his credit, what I regard, frankly, as a very fine speech. I would like, with respect, to adopt his remarks in relation to imprisonment. He had the good sense to refer to the federation. But he will find to his cost, as will the people of Western Australia, that the decisions of Western Australia which should be made by Western Australians will now be made in Canberra. The Prime Minister will get on the telephone to Mr Burke and that will be the end of it. I repeat that a country as big and diverse as Australia has become great in its first 83 years because it is a federation and because it recognises the devolution of power. Under the socialist centralists now in power the decisions would be made in Canberra.

Why do I say that it is a socialist party? I do not have to prove my point. I admire people such as the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr Staples), the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) and the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) who have never cringed about the fact that they are committed to a philosophy of socialism. The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren), to his credit, hoisted his colours to the mast and has stood by them throughout his entire parliamentary career. I can tell honourable members that in the previous Parliament quite a number of members of the Labor Party objected violently when they were called socialists. They call us conservatives. I am no conservative; I am a Liberal; I am a reformer. But I will tell honourable members opposite that by their own policies they are socialists and their impact on the economy and the standing of the Australian reputation internationally will be as disastrous as are the socialist policies of Monsieur Mitterrand and discredited former socialist leaders.

The fact of the matter is that Australia now has a socialist government. Let not one honourable member opposite cringe from the fact that their own party policy and commitment is the socialisation of Australia. They take the oath of loyalty to the Queen. They support the motion for the Address-in-Reply. Yet they are bound by their policy to abolish the monarchy and to turn this country into a republic. They cannot shrink from that fact. I have never seen so many Labor politicians falling over themselves to shake hands with the Prince and Princess of Wales. When the Queen comes to Australia one cannot get within cooee of her because of Labor politicians.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Maher

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 76 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

The honourable member for Denison is insinuating all sorts of improper motives and making all sorts of personal reflections on members of the Government in relation to Her Majesty the Queen, to the heir apparent and to the Australian Labor Party, of which I am proud to be a member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Denison.

—I invite the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) after I have completed my speech to make a personal explanation and to tell this Parliament and the people of Australia whether he is loyal to Her Majesty the Queen and the constitutional monarchy or whether he is, as he is bound by his party policy, a republican.

SPEECH.PARA: We have before us a Government which is a oncer government. When I came to this place in 1975, after eight years in the Tasmanian Parliament, I heard for the very first time the word 'oncer'. It was used by the honourable member for Hindmarsh-not the present one but the former, distinguished, handsome, intellectual and extremely capable honourable member for Hindmarsh, the Honourable Clyde Cameron. He said that certain members of the Liberal Party were a bunch of oncers. I used to go home at night and think: 'What on earth does this mean?' 'It means', he said, 'that you will only be there for one Parliament .' We got back again in 1977; we got back again in 1980; and we were elected again in 1983. I welcome all new members. I hope their stay is enjoyable but brief, because amongst them are 13 oncers who will lose their seats at the next election and we will see the return of a Liberal-National Party coalition.

I will not be unkind enough to suggest that the competition is going to be ' pick the oncer'. I will not nominate which honourable members will be in that 13 . But let me give them that figure because it will stick in their minds from this day until the next election. A swing of 3.2 per cent will put the Hawke Government out and the Peacock Government in. The way the two of them are going at the moment, I have to say that Andrew Peacock is shortening in the betting. I have never seen a Government crumbling so soon after its election.

I do not have to remind Government members of the embarrassment which they all felt when the Prime Minister yesterday and today tried to talk himself out of one of the greatest bungles, one of the greatest examples of ineptitude in the handling of our national security, that I have ever come across in 18 years in parliamentary service. I wish the Prime Minister had a rear vision mirror so that he could have seen the looks on faces behind him as, minute by minute, he dug himself deeper into the hole today. Having sat down, he got up again and had another little dig. The Government is crumbling already.

It is already in deep strife and it knows it. Honourable members opposite have made the greatest mistake of their lives by calling for a royal commission into the activities of Mr David Combe. Someone on the Government side of the fence apparently does not like Mr Combe. Having destroyed his reputation, having killed his profession, having put him into a situation of Purdah where he cannot even talk to Ministers, some Government members now want to dig a little bit further. I am afraid that they will dig up a few things which will fly back into their faces. Through David Combe, Khemlani will live again. The beginning of the end of the Government will come because a Prime Minister failed to recognise that there are proper principles and precedents. Again I have to say, look at the record. In seven weeks this Government has broken more promises than Malcolm Fraser broke in seven years. Let me remind honourable members of one. Ninety-six per cent of the taxpayers of Australia are waiting for the tax cuts which the Government promised would be immediately introduced. There are six million people out there and every day that goes past--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about John Howard?

—Do not worry about the honourable member for Bennelong. He was a dashed good Treasurer and he will be back in the job very soon. We are wondering what will happen. Honourable members on the Government benches will find six million writing to them because these immediate tax cuts have not eventuated. They will not get tax cuts. They got a National Economic Summit Conference instead. That is marvellous! And when the Budget comes along, taxes will be increased. The Australian Labor Party is a socialist party. It has to tax hard and high to pay for its expansive and extravagant promises. I have to say, looking at the Governor-General's Speech, what went through my mind. I do not say this with any cruelty, because I do have a personal regard for the new Australian Ambassador to UNESCO.

SPEECH.PARA: As I heard the Governor-General's Speech the other day I said to myself: ' Whitlam again only worse; Bob is not as tall as Gough but the thinking is there, the policies are there'. The Government has not learnt anything from seven years in opposition. The Government to start its career has picked a fight with the smallest State in Australia and put the Federation at risk. Even at this late hour, Mr Deputy Speaker, through your good offices, I say to the Prime Minister of Australia: 'Call off this case. What more are you going to do to Tasmania? Two letters, a writ, the Royal Australian Air Force, the biggest High Court case in the history of this country'. One does not know whether Gareth Evans will give one a writ or the RAAF. He is the writ and RAAF Attorney-General. The Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) has had a remarkable string of successes in his first few weeks in government. He has changed the Royal Australian Air Force into the Luftwaffe as far as the people of Tasmania are concerned. He has amputated the Fleet Air Arm, after 50 years of experience. He is behaving, if I may say so, in a manner which indicates already that he will not be able to carry out his responsibilities.

The Prime Minister has the same attitude to Tasmania as General Galtieri had to the Falkland Islands. Prime Minister Hawke has made it very clear that there will not be any goodies for Tasmania. Tasmanians had the tremendous cheek to return five good, strong Liberal Party members for the House of Representatives. In the time remaining to me let me make one or two comments on some matters on which, for the first time in 2 1/2 years, I have the opportunity to roam just a little without restraint. I say to the Government-I say it with the utmost sincerity-do not proceed with your attempts to destroy the Federation. Do not proceed with your determination to crush and trample on the tiniest but most beautiful State in the Commonwealth. Do not proceed with your determination to centralise everything in Canberra. Remember that there are Australians big and small. I am sorry that in the first weeks of the Hawke Government in this Parliament I and my fellow Tasmanians have been called such things as maggots and vandals. It is not funny. It is a tragedy that members of the Government are prepared to use that language. I say to the Government: 'Try to apply a little decency and responsiblity to what you are doing'. One member of the Opposition will watch the Government very carefully on one issue. I have stood firm and resolute on the issue and never wavered one inch, and that is East Timor. I am now going to watch what the Government does in relation to East Timor. The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) can endeavour to interject but some four years ago his former leader, the present Minister for Foreign Affairs, (Mr Hayden), out of all the members of the present Government had the decency to stand in this Parliament and pick me as having been consistent in my view in relation to human rights and East Timor. When I look at the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) I remember his distinguished father. If the Minister would not mind my saying it-I am sure that he would not-his father is one of the greatest Australians I have ever met. The Minister should ensure that what his father said in this Parliament is adhered to and the position of East Timor is not forgotten.

In conclusion I want to refer to the remarks made by our Prime Minister over the last few days in relation to what has now become known as the ASIO-David Combe affair. It is an absolute tragedy that I have seen for the first time in a parliamentary career involving State and Federal politics a man's reputation destroyed in one hit by a statement made in the Parliament by the Prime Minister of this country. What we have today is a most extraordinary situation. Having destroyed Combe's reputation, taken away his livelihood and profession, we are told there will be a royal commission. I hope that the Press will print it up this way. It is the best example of a trial after an execution of which I have ever heard. Government members ought to be ashamed of themselves collectively if they do not stand up for the one inalienable right of every Australian and that is to be given a fair go.

The jurisprudentialist who preceded me, the honourable member for Moore, would know that there is a basic and fundamental right that one should be heard in one 's own defence, but what the Government has done is to pick out one man and make him its sacrificial lamb. I believe it is still not too late for the Caucus to stand up and say: 'Principle, Prime Minister, is going to come above politics and pragmatism'. I hope one of you in Caucus is decent enough next week to stand up and say: 'We have wronged a very fine Australian who has been a very fine member of our party'. The Government can still repair the damage it has done.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish the new members well. I bear the 13 honourable members who will go out at the next election no ill will but I must say that the sooner we can get rid of this rotten socialist republican Government the better it will be for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—I do. Because I took a point of order the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) became somewhat carried away. He implied that I was somehow disloyal to Her Majesty the Queen. That is untrue. I have taken an oath to Her Majesty the Queen of Australia and I will stick to that oath. I believe in that oath and I thought it somewhat hysterical for the previous speaker to carry on as he did.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, I do. Mr Speaker, the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) has misrepresented me. I just want the honourable member to indicate whether he is for the Queen or for the republic. If he does not answer he will be condemned, because--
—A point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is not a personal explanation.
—The fact is that you are all republicans and none of you is loyal to the Queen.

—Order! That is not a personal explanation. Before calling the honourable member for Calare I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask that he be given the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this Parliament at a time when my fellow Australians, having lost faith in the previous Government, place their trust in the Goverment led by the Australian Labor Party's leader and now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He offered Australians new hope, he offered Australians a new perspective and he offered Australians a sense of national purpose. The spirit that characterised the recent election campaign presents an opportunity for me to recall the words of one of Australia's greatest Prime Ministers, whose electorate is now substantially included within the federal division of Calare. I refer, of course, to Bathurst's most famous son, the late Mr Joseph Benedict ( Ben) Chifley. Mr Chifley said in late 1949:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor stands for the people. Labor stands firmly against all who would take advantage of the people.

Mr Deputy Speaker, how true these words are in 1983. The 1977 federal redistribution dramatically altered the Calare electorate. Approximately 45 per cent of the pre-1977 Macquarie electorate was included in the new seat of Calare as the boundaries moved in an easterly direction. Therefore, while I have the honour to be the first representative of my great party to hold the electorate of Calare since Mr John Breen in 1946, it is important to place the history of the seat into a meaningful perspective.

In this respect I must of course recognise the contribution to this House by two other great Australians who respresented areas now covered by my electorate. John England was the member for Calare from the by-election held on 5 November 1960 until November 1975. Mr England, though not a member of my party, was a highly respected man within both the Parliament and his electorate in his 15 years of service to this House. Anthony Sylvester-or, as he is better known, Tony-Luchetti served as the member for Macquarie following the death of Ben Chifley. He won the seat at the by-election on 28 July 1951 and retired prematurely following the traumatic events of 11 November 1975. Mr Luchetti appropriately referred to the late Mr Chifely in his maiden speech on 4 October 1951 in these rather glowing terms:
The name of Mr Chifley is honoured in Australia, and is known and revered throughout the world . . .

I come here this evening to honour that name. I represent those people who, throughout the years, have made their contribution to the development of Australia, and I pay tribute to honourable members of this Parliament who in other days, in various ways, inside the legislature as well as outside of it, made their contribution to its development and to its protection and security.

I embrace these words tonight, and in doing so know that the present honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free), who also holds Mr Luchetti in great esteem, would appreciate the significance of the political representation of Mr Luchetti 's old seat of Macquarie.

I acknowledge the overwhelming vote of confidence given to me by the people of Calare just over two months ago. During the election campaign I gave an undertaking to all people in Calare that I would endeavour to serve my electorate with vigour. The nature of the electorate will ensure that such a task will be demanding, exciting, frustrating at times, but nonetheless very necessary and fulfilling.

Calare covers an area of nearly 25,000 square kilometres and is an electorate of socio-economic diversity. It includes the tableland cities of Orange, Bathurst and Lithgow, the slopes and plains towns of Parkes and Wellington as well as a number of other significant urban centres such as Wallerawang, Portland, Oberon, Blayney, Molong and Peak Hill. My electorate is diverse in many respects. While only 15 per cent of my electorate is classified rural, the rural component makes a great contribution to our national income. The western section is part of the State's wool-wheat belt. Fat lamb producers in the central tablelands are anxiously monitoring the effects the recently negotiated closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand is likely to have on the local industry. Beef cattle, too, make an important contribution to Calare's agricultural base throughout the entire area. In the central portion of the electorate intensive fruit growing, notably cherries and, I am pleased to be able to boast to honourable members from Tasmania, apples, adds to the area's diversity. Forestry also contributes to the regional economy of Calare.

The drought of the last five years has now eased, but the post-drought period will be a trying time for the rural community of Australia. The severity of the drought will mean that there will be significant indebtedness amongst primary producers for years to come. However, I am sure that despite the dimensions of the task the rural community will once more begin to contribute strongly to our national wealth. Simple processing of many of these primary products takes place near the source of production. Timber mills, wool-topping, abattoirs and canned food production within the electorate provide suitable evidence for such an observation.

Significant public and private manufacturing enterprises are located in Calare. The Small Arms Factory was initially established in Lithgow by the Fisher Labor Government in 1913. The Wallerawang power station has a generating capacity of 1 ,240 megawatts. A number of important railway establishments are located throughout the entire electorate. The largest manufacturing enterprise is the whitegoods manufacturer, Email Ltd Orange, which has continuously added to its original site following its establishment after World War II. High technology industry also exists in the form of edible collogen processor, Devro Pty Ltd, located in my home city of Bathurst. Many other small to medium sized manufacturing concerns add to the local, regional and national economy.

However, in the face of the most serious drought probably in the last 100 years , coupled with the present economic recession, Australian based manufacturing has some serious problems. My immediate concern is to encourage our fellow Australians to support our local manufacturers. If we wish to maintain our high standard of living, which includes the payment of wages at levels significantly higher than exist in other countries within our region, the price we must be prepared to pay to enjoy such an amenity is to support Australian manufacturers rather than purchase cheaper imports. Unlike many countries that provide us with goods, Australia recognises the right of free trade unions to exist. Australia is a major trading nation that must, of necessity, be prepared to import goods if it wishes to export to the markets of the world. However, we need to recognise consciously that support for locally produced goods is beneficial to the nation as a whole. In other words, given the constraints of our trading obligations, Australians should encourage each other to buy Australian.

As one of a number of new members with an occupational background in education, I point to a strong educational base in Calare that keenly awaits our Government 's approach to education funding. Pre-school, primary and secondary schools, both government and non-government, with varying resource standards, endeavour to meet the needs of an ever-changing society that gallops towards the next century. Technical and further education is another area in which significant progress has been made in recent years. Still, the task is a daunting one when we face the technological, vocational and relaxational demands of our times. The Mitchell College of Advanced Education at Bathurst has a distinguished reputation and boasts a significant enrolment of external students. It is an institution that developed from the former teachers' college of which I have many fond memories-if I may say so-of my tender youth in 1965 and 1966. The Orange Agricultural College is a much smaller institution with a well-deserved reputation Australia-wide for academic excellence in farm management studies. Its foundation principal was my predecessor, Mr Sandy MacKenzie, who held the position prior to his election in 1975, and who has been my political opponent since the 1977 redistributution. Like so many other members in this place, I join the three times lucky club in getting into this place.

The college has been the target of unneccessary attempts to destabilise its reputation, with strong indications of forced amalgamation being made in the last few years. I am delighted that assurances have been given by our Prime Minister that we will not accept further forced amalgamations in the college and university sector. In many cases the economic grounds in support of amalgamation have been shallow and little attempt has been made to assess the impact of these educational shotgun marriages. I strongly support the need to ensure that our tertiary education institutions are both economically and, more importantly, educationally viable. However, the interests of the smaller, specialised institutions, such as the Orange Agricultural College, need to be carefully assessed.

Calare is a seat that has a great place in the history of our nation. The city of Bathurst is Australia's oldest inland centre. It was proclaimed by Governor Macquarie on 7 May 1815. the Orange area is the largest urban centre of Calare and is recognised as the site where the gold rush of the ninteenth century had its origins. Lithgow, the centre of the western coalfields, was the birth place of the Australian iron and steel industry. The town of Wellington was a significant location in the inland exploration of New South Wales. Parkes is named after one of the founding fathers of Federation, Sir Henry Parkes, and this year celebrates its centenary of local government in the area. Many great Australians were born in the area of Calare or have made a contribution to its development. I recognise these people and their contribution in this House tonight.

Another aspect also warrants comment. Prior to the election only 12 1/2 per cent of recognised rural and provincial electorates throughout Australia were represented by members from my party. My party now holds one-third of all such seats, with the Labor vote in provincial centres almost matching the vote in metropolitan areas, whilst the recognised rural vote is over 44 per cent. I believe that this evidence is testimony to the fact that the Government's legislative program as outlined in the Governor-General's Speech was endorsed by all Australians, irrespective of their location, throughout our huge and great continent. The Government is truly a representative government. I am proud to be a member of the Government party but I am particularly conscious of the fact that I represent the 113,000 people who live in one of the most historic regions of non-metropolitan Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to to convey my good wishes to Mr Speaker and the Chairman of Committees. Like so many of my colleagues who have had the opportunity to wish you well in your important positions in the Thirty-third Parliament, I now add my voice to that chorus. I offer the occupant of the distinguished post of Speaker my congratulations and good wishes. In my limited, but selfishly optimistic, desire for a longer tenure in this chamber I am only too aware of the importance of their respective roles and the dignity that they both bring to their new positions. I look forward to a long and professionally satisfying association with them both as I enter my first parliamentary term as the member for Calare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I also wish to add my congratulations to you on your appointment as a Deputy Speaker. You and I came to the Parliament together and we enjoyed each other's company during the time in which we were introduced to the workings of this place. It is interesting to see that the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross) is in the chamber. As I recall, he was one of those who instructed us at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General's Speech, as was said earlier this evening, is the policy document of a government. This particular policy document is more interesting because it is the policy document not only of a new government but also of a government with a different political philosophy from the one that has governed Australia for quite some period in recent times and, of course, over a great deal of time in the last 30 years.

The Governor-General's Speech is a very wide-ranging document. I guess it could be said that it is somewhat like the policy speech put forward before an election which promises something to all people at all times. Of course, whether it will deliver the goods in the long term will be proved by history. The opening part of the Speech contains the sub-heading 'Economy'. Reference is made in the very first paragraph under that heading to the National Economic Summit Conference. I attended that Conference as an uninvited guest. I did so for a very special reason. I do not deny a government or its leader the right to hold conferences of any nature. However, I take strong objection when the Government chooses to hold a conference in this place, before calling together the new Parliament and the people who have recently presented themselves to the total voting population of Australia. I also take strong objection to the fact that the delegates attending this conference were presented to the Australian public as community representatives. In this day of the media one must take steps to draw attention to such a situation. I quite deliberately did that to make sure that the seat which I occupy tonight was mine by right-the right of being presented to the Australian public under the democratic laws that apply in this nation. I had been judged by the electorate because I had been its representative for a previous term of parliament. I had put myself before it with competition quite widely spaced among four opponents. I was re-elected with an increased majority and I believed that if anybody was to represent my electorate at the Conference that person would be me.

I do not subscribe to the theory of American presidential style politics that we elect a leader by way of some great media event and then that person gathers around him a group of advisers who make up his Cabinet. This group basically runs the country and the elected parliamentarians are used as a rubber stamp. I saw the Summit Conference as the first step in that direction. I objected to what was happening. I took the steps which I am entitled to take. History will show that I established one thing of certainty-that a person elected to this Parliament has the right to be in this place at any time the doors are unlocked. It is a great pity that the newly elected members of this place, most of whom belong to the Labor Party, did not show similar courage. They did not feel insulted by their leader and, in fact, they were prepared to be subservient to the representatives of big unions, big government and big business.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a publicity stunt, the whole thing.
—That is quite right. I thank the honourable member. I agree with him completely. I presume he is talking about what the Prime Minister did.
—Your publicity stunt.
—No, the publicity stunt was organised by the Prime Minister. I attended to represent the people who said to me: 'We are terribly concerned--
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, my constituents said to me: 'We are terribly concerned that a Prime Minister who as Leader of the Opposition said to us during the election campaign that he was able to give us tax cuts and that he was able to reduce our tax burden all of a sudden, prior to calling together the people who had been elected to the Parliament, started to make statements on the Mike Walsh Show-a great forum for political debate-in which he said that if there are delays in the promised tax cuts they will not be because Bob Hawke has decided so but because the community, through its representative bodies, will have decided that that is basically necessary'. Let us look at the people the Prime Minister was talking about. No wonder my constituents were concerned. They saw the Summit as the biggest tax dodge in the history of Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used it to get out of his tax promises.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) today gave us some very good advice about where the money comes from to run government. It was a great contribution by a new member. But what did the Prime Minister say? He said: 'It is your money and governments only spend your money'. A person seeking to handle that money said: 'I can manage with less; I will reduce your burden'. No sooner was the Prime Minister in a position to give tax cuts than he created a new forum in this place to give him an excuse not to do so. Whom did the Prime Minister call together? He said that he would call together community representatives. By coincidence, some 30 representatives from the Australian Council of Trade Unions sat in the seats now occupied by Government members. Members of the Labor Party can probably tell me as easily as I can tell them how many members of the Australian work force are affiliated members of the ACTU. Over two million people-a large number-are in this category. However, there are six million workers in Australia and I thought I had better come along to look after the other four million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the Aborigines.

—The honourable member should lift his game because the party of which he is a member is in government now. If he wants to take the time I will tell him about that. What would he do if his wife was getting beaten up? Would he defend her? Anyhow, let us get off that subject.

SPEECH.PARA: My constituents are worried because the National Economic Summit was a carefully engineered tax dodge. Firstly the Prime Minister laid the ground work. He told us that the community was represented. He said that the Confederation of Australian Industry was there. That confederation has 50,000 affiliates. I am told that there are 700,000 small businesses in Australia. Admittedly there were other representatives, but if the Confederation of Australian Industry can claim to represent 100,000 of those 700,000 small businesses then I will be surprised. The people who were elected by all voting Australians were denied a place. Honourable members opposite carry that burden more than any because they had the right through their Caucus which, we all know now is another rubber stamp, to say: 'We will attend, we will do the job first because we are the representatives of the Australian people.' But no, the Prime Minister sold the Summit on the Mike Walsh Show; it had to be right.

But that was not all. It was not only a case of denying tax cuts, but also stating that taxes would probably have to be increased. How do we justify that? We call on the sorcerer's apprentice, a Mr Kelty. We know who the sorcerer is in trade union terms; I should not have to tell honourable members. In previous days his name was Hawke. The apprentice came into this place on behalf of the two point something million people he represents and said: 'I think my members should accept greater taxes'. I suggest two things on that issue: Firstly a proper referendum could be held, not a referendum with a muscle and a bit of elbow, but a nice clean cut one like we generally have held under the same auspices. That referendum can be held amongst the two point something million members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on a straight yes/no basis. We would then see how many of those members agree with Mr Kelty and would voluntarily accept increased taxes. When we have finished with that lot let us get to the other four million. Let us decide what they would do about increased taxes. I am a gambling man. The odds on those people voting against increased taxes would be a lot shorter than Maggie Thatcher is in the current polls in Britain.

What was this tax dodge, this Summit, supposed to deliver? It is unfortunate for honourable members opposite that they were not here; they have to rely on what I tell them because I was here. That is their misfortune. They did not have the courage to attend. They subverted themselves to their new leader. They denied everything that the Labor Party stands for. They did not operate Caucus in the democratic tradition of the Labor Party. It is interesting that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), talked about Ben Chifley. We will look at that again. An interesting thing about the Labor Party is that Ben Chifley's demise and death saw the decline of the working man as an influence in the Labor Party. I would like honourable members opposite to stand up one at a time and tell me what their professions are and when they last had dirt under their fingernails.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have always got dirt under yours.
—Quite right. It has been achieved by hard work. The honourable member for Werriwa should not worry about it.
—I am a worker.
—Are you a worker? Tell me about it quickly because I have not got the time.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am a turner and fitter by trade, and I am very proud of it.
—There is no point of order.
—I am pleased to hear it; there is one left. The facts of life are that the Summit was designed for a purpose, but what did it achieve? I listened to all those people speak.
—You were not there. I was. I do not know what you were up to.

—Can I tell the honourable member for Hunter something. The Prime Minister saw me. The honourable member must have been blind on the day. The facts of life are that the Prime Minister made a reference in this place and, by a strange coincidence, on the first day as I crossed the chamber because I wanted to go out the door opposite we actually bumped into each other and he said: 'G'day, I saw you sitting up there'. So I think he knows that I was there. It is a great pity that I did not contribute to that Conference because I would have told a few of the people present that they were falling over themselves to deny everything that they had been saying for some time. The great con trick was played on the working class. Bill Kelty stood there and said: 'We will accept increased taxes'. The sorcerer's apprentice! If the sorcerer can pull that one off he is not too bad. I invite Government supporters to put that to the people, to go back to them and say: 'I am sorry'. It does not matter whom they blame; it is history. They should just tell the people that they intend to run a government based on ever increasing taxes. I would like to see how the vote runs in those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy Speaker, let me congratulate you on your appointment to that office. The Governor-General's Speech addresses all these matters. Some great words came out of the Summit. I especially recollect certain words, which I quoted to the Parliament the other night, of Sir Arvi Parbo. When any one of us gets to his feet in the future and decides that he knows it all and can predict it all we should remember his words. People as senior as the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), with his great academic achievements, claim to be able to tell us all about what will happen in regard to aluminium, for instance, but let us remember what Sir Arvi said. Briefly, he said that if three years ago anybody in Australia had stood up and predicted the present economic circumstances he would have been not only the only person in Australia to do so but also would have been considered mad by all the experts. That should be a great lesson to all of us, it is something that we should not forget.

Let me also touch on a few other things that occurred at the Conference. Certain scenarios were presented. They were quite good in that they attempted to lay out the situation under given sets of circumstances. The Press tells me that they were embarrassing to the union movement to some degree because the union movement was a party to them. The union movement knew that what was said was right but did not want to believe it. The scenarios were classified A, B and C. Scenario A is usually the preferred option. It would be reasonable in presenting the scenarios to those gathered here to have had them begin at one end of the scale of preference and end at the other, but that was not done. The soft option , the middle position, was expressed as category A. Government supporters may tell me why that was done, but I believe that it was a bit like the great tax dodge. We knew, and they knew, because they did a deal, that there would be a 3 per cent wage rise this year. We have a judicial system that is supposed to decide these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five per cent.

—Is it to be 5 per cent? We have a judicial system and other decision makers but, as I have said, I am a gambling man and would dearly love to bet that, irrespective of the economic circumstances in Australia this year, that wage rise will take place, whatever the cost, because the deal has been made.

SPEECH.PARA: During my election campaign I had reason to speak on the same platform as the Labor candidate, a young farmer who was a member of the Primary Industry Association. He wanted to talk anti-tariff. That is a catchy phrase in my electorate but I had to draw his attention to the accords and advise him that it would be in breach of contract. The contract entered into by the Australian Labor Party, states that there will be heavy tariffs, that there will be no reduction. The only requirement is that there be an increase in employment. Whatever the cost, that will be good enough. That is what the economic accords say. Accordingly, I had to tell him that he was in breach of contract.

I repeat, the scenarios did not cover the range from the worst possible situation for Labor to the best possible situation for industry, or for the community. I happen to have the funny feeling that the welfare of industry and employers is very similar to that of the work force. Unfortunately we have been told differently for a very long time. However, a lot of unemployed people have eventually got the message. The soft option obviously is option B. That was just another little con trick. I do not propose to worry too much about that now and will proceed in the little time remaining to look at some other situations.

Finally, to my mind, the Summit was the greatest publicity stunt one could ever dream up. Some day honourable members opposite will tell me what it achieved. It is interesting to note that a great group of unionists said: 'We will give this and we will give that', but that one group said: 'Like hell, we do not want to give anything'; and there is a good reason for that. The metal trades unions, the major union participants in the Summit, have done their dash. They have conducted so many caesarian sections on the golden goose that they will not get another egg for a long time. No one knows that better than their leaders. But the building industry sees it a little differently. The employers have a number of half-finished buildings. The building industry unions can screw hell out of their employers for a little longer, but they know that when the Christmas tree goes on the top of those buildings they will get no more eggs out of their golden goose either. That is why they want to get out of the system; that is why they want to cop out. The accords and the conciliation came about because necessity demanded them; there was nothing else. So much for the Summit! I would dearly love to cover a large number of other areas in this Summit document. I have marked them in yellow. I think I could have said many things about them.

In closing, I remind new honourable members who have made maiden speeches and who have said wonderful things tonight that there is only one place for the representation of the Australian people. That is called parliament. We have State parliaments and we have the Federal Parliament. The members of those places are the representatives of the people. If honourable members opposite want to desert the people again and let their boss run an economic summit, let them do so; but they should tell the people they represent that they are secondary in the representative business and that other people can be picked up at their leader's choice and that those people will make the decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Newcastle, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech. I ask for the usual courtesies to be observed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Madam Deputy Speaker, I join with my colleagues in congratulating you, other Deputy Speakers and the Speaker on your elections. It is particularly significant that I make this speech under your chairmanship, and I appreciate the honour. In making my first speech in this place representing the people of Newcastle, it is appropriate that I thank those members of my party who encouraged me to become a member, those who supported me during my preselection, and those voters of Newcastle who placed their faith in me and gave me the honour and the privilege of acting on their behalf in these very difficult times. I also thank a loyal and trusting family who share not only the burden of responsibilities but also my confidence in the future of this nation. I would like to pay my respects also to the three previous members for Newcastle for the efforts they have contributed to the well-being of the people of Newcastle. I shall comment further on these men later.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to indicate at this stage why I am proud and privileged to represent the people of Newcastle. Newcastle, the sixth city in Australia and regional capital of the Hunter Valley with a population of over 600,000 people, is a city without peer in Australia for its contribution not only to the industrial, resource and shipping growth of our nation but also to the aesthetic , artistic and sporting growth of Australia. In the field of art, Newcastle of course was the birthplace of Sir William Dobell, John Olsen, John Molvig, William Groves and many others. Other famous Australian artists such as Tom Cleghorn, Paul Beadle, John Passmore, John Montefiore, Marilyn McGrath, Mario Ermer and many others have had part or all of the genesis of their artistic endeavours in the city of Newcastle. It may be surprising for honourable members to find that Marilyn Rowe, Assistant Artistic Director of the Australian Ballet Company, is a Novacastrian, as are other members of that company. There are authors, poets, sportsmen and musicians from Newcastle working and performing not only throughout Australia but also throughout the world. Newcastle is also quite prolific in the production of politicians. One of my delights on the night of 5 March was to see another Novacastrian elected to this House. I refer, of course, to the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) whose parents are still alive and well and very much honoured in Newcastle.

Since it was first established as a penal colony to mine the first coal ever in Australia, Newcastle has known the richness of Australia's booms and the miseries of its depressions. Throughout our long and chequered history the strength and courage of our people have been apparent. We have seen the coal industry oscillate between unpredictable extremes and watched with apprehension as a once great shipyard was ground into a relic of its former years. Now, even as I speak, we must try to anticipate the intentions of BHP. Throughout all of this, the people of Newcastle have never been lacking. They have kept their faith in the future of their city and their nation. What Newcastle and Australia have lacked in the 82 years since Federation has been national governments with a vestige of a policy towards manufacturing industry. We have had national governments whose industrial policies have been those of simply ignoring our industrial future, whose policies were moulded to ensure that the future was totally unpredictable and whose policies on shipbuilding and shipping seemed to be to let other countries do both.

The industrial strength that was Newcastle was built during two wars. Our industrial engines thrived on the demand created by monstrous events. Since the 1950s we have seen those engines corrode and fall silent, one by one, through lack of care and maintenance by a nation they had served so well. For the past seven years Newcastle has plunged further into a trough, with the government of the day sitting aloof and remote. Last year, when BHP commenced a contraction which for many people has been and is as devastating as the recent tragic bushfires in the south, not one Minister, let alone the prime one, came to look at our ashes. It has been very hard for the people of Newcastle to maintain their faith in a government which obviously did not care.

In 1976 our State dockyard employed over 2,000 men. Its work force today is just over 600. The BHP has shed, to use a polite term, over 5,000 employees in the past two years. A great number of the 480 companies that depend for all or part of their income on BHP have closed with loss of jobs even greater than those of BHP. To add insult to injury, two years ago it was announced that our university and college of advanced education were to amalgamate. This amalgamation was to achieve no savings, nor were any benefits specified. It seemed just one more step in the humbling and degrading of a proud and caring community. I say 'caring' because, after the tragic bushfires of which I spoke, an appeal launched by the Lord Mayor of Newcastle raised $170,000. The fact that a community faced with such massive problems of its own can show that kind of compassion is justification for the pride that I feel in representing it.

Newcastle does not have a history of begging. It has contributed more than its share to the wealth of our nation and we have never asked for more than we give. During these lean and barren years, we have asked for the same degree of concern and compassion that we have shown fellow Australians. We are a proud city, and rightly so, for we have a great deal of which to be proud. I speak on behalf of the people of Newcastle not only with pride and honour, but also with relief. Had the Australian people chosen otherwise and on 5 March given us a government of the kind that Newcastle has known and suffered for so long, this speech would have been of a vastly different complexion. I have spent more than eight years as an alderman for the City of Newcastle. During most of this time we have had as our Lord Mayor a lady of great talents, the first female Lord Mayor in Australia. During our most despairing moments she has managed to radiate a sense of optimism and faith in our future. I assure honourable members that during this time I have not always shared that faith and optimism. However, she has been proven right as she always believed that Australians would give Newcastle a government that cared about its future, was committed to our industrial manufacturing sectors, and believed in our people. It is with both pleasure and pride that I find myself part of this Government, a Government faced with one of the greatest challenges ever, but one with more commitment than ever before in the history of the Australian Parliament.

I turn now from Newcastle the City to Newcastle the electorate. As an electorate, Newcastle is unique in that it has previously elected only three representatives to the Parliament. I would like to pay my respects to those three-Mr David Watkins who was elected at Federation in 1901, his son David who was elected in 1935, and my immediate predecessor the Honourable C. K. Jones who was elected in 1958 and who served as Minister for Transport in the Whitlam Government. Because of this uniqueness I have taken the liberty of examining the maiden speeches of my three predecessors. On 22 May 1901 when Mr David Watkins made his first speech as the first member for Newcastle he touched on a number of issues which included his support for the protection of Australian industry. He stated:
I have always believed in excluding all the forms of cheap labour possible, I was at the same time prepared to go to the logical extreme, and refuse admission to the products of cheap labour.
The story is very familiar. Newcastle in 1901 was a much smaller place. Our major industry then was coal mining. It was still a major port as the Year Book shows. It states:
No seaport of the State can be compared with either Sydney or Newcastle.
Mr Watkins senior was succeeded by his son David who spoke for the first time in October 1935. The population of Newcastle had by then almost doubled, but the issues were similar. He said:

I cannot understand how the Government can forget that children, in order to become good citizens, must be brought up in decent circumstances, and under proper conditions. No doubt the Government will argue that money is not available for housing purposes, but if war were to break out tomorrow, ample money would be found for the destruction of human life. Why, then, cannot money be made available for the uplift of the masses of the people? Is it better to destroy than to build?
That has a very familiar ring about it. Those comments are similar to comments that have been made in this debate. Mr Watkins junior stated further:

I urge upon the Government the need for proceeding immediately with the development of industries for the production of oil from shale and coal. This is vitally necessary, not only for defence purposes, but also for the re-employment of our miners who, like the returned soldiers, seem to be an army of forgotten men.

The decline in the mines between Federation and 1935 was, of course, dramatic and the coal fields around Newcastle had been in turmoil. However, the establishment of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in 1914 meant that Newcastle had become the major industrial centre of Australia and that shipping was still our second most important industry.

I turn now to the maiden speech of my immediate predecessor, the Honourable C. K. Jones, on 24 February 1959. Newcastle had grown even more, but the issues that Mr Jones raised were remarkably similar. He said:
I propose to deal with the effects of mechanisation on the coal industry and workers in the Newcastle district.
Mr Jones said:
So far this year five pits have closed down and 787 men have lost their jobs.
Mr Jones referred to an aspect of the speech of Mr Watkins junior when he said:
A committee was appointed to investigate the possibilities of a coal-based chemical and liquid fuel industry.
Later he said:
In Australia today 13 ships of the Australian National Line are tied up because there is no cargo for them.

Mr Jones also referred to high unemployment and to a lack of a clear shipbuilding policy. My intention in referring to these three predecessors and their maiden speeches has not been to provide a session of nostalgia but more to indicate that the problems of Newcastle are not new problems. They are problems that have been endemic to our city since Federation. There has been a tendency for some people in Newcastle to interpret these continuing problems of our city as being ones of lack of care by a party they have always supported. It is clear that since Federation Newcastle has rarely had the kind of government that industrial cities need.

I take particular heart at that part of the Governor-General's Speech in which he said that this Government will be committed to the development of a strong competitive manufacturing industry. He said:
The Government intends to preserve a viable and efficient steel industry.

I am more privileged than my three predecessors because I am making this, my first speech, as a Government member. I am the first member for Newcastle to have done so. It is not enough to be a Government member; what is important is the objectives and capacities of the Government to address the problems that Newcastle has faced since its birth and is still facing today.

At present we have one of the highest unemployment rates in Australia. We have a floundering steel industry, a shipyard with no ships to build, coal mines producing more coal than we can sell, and a work force with more skills and more ability and more talent than ever before, but no jobs. In the few short days since election on 5 March much has been achieved. The BHP and the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) are obviously coming to terms with their respective futures and there is emerging a steel policy to which both the industry and the Government will be committed. The unnecessary amalgamation proposed has been terminated and discarded. Within weeks of his election, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has seen fit to visit our area, and start talking to our people and looking at our problems.

We in Newcastle recognise that the issues that are facing us will not be solved overnight. We recognise the structural changes that are needed and the difficulties that they pose. However, we recognise also that at least we have Ministers and a government who are paying serious attention to these problems. So where does the Newcastle of tomorrow go? If one looks at our past we can see where we do not want to be. We do not want to be faced with perpetual crisis, with perpetual unemployment, with constant concern and apprehension as to whether our industries are relevant or have a future. What we expect and need is a government to create a context in which solutions can be developed, a government with the courage to create the policies that will allow us to work again. Those policies must relate to the Australia of the future, because for the first time in our history our Government is looking ahead and predicting where we are going and trying to plan our objectives. For too long we have been the victim of other countries' economies and other countries' attitudes. If Australia is to have a future that is meaningful and significant and if places like Newcastle are to contribute what they are capable of contributing to the national economy, we have to know what role we can play in the years ahead. Newcastle has manufactured for Australia in the past. We want the opportunity to manufacture for our future. Tell us what Australians will need in the decades ahead and our people will produce it.

I could not conclude this speech without remarking on these first few months of experience as a new member of parliament. It is more than somewhat disappointing , with so many real problems facing us as a nation, to find that so much of the time has been spent on trivial issues, on issues that are not relevant to where Australia will be going in the next decades up to the end of the century. I find it rather tragic that so much energy and ability are being wasted in so many trivial and meaningless exercises.

On behalf of the people of Newcastle, I remind honourable members of the responsibility we all have not to ignore the plight of our people who are suffering. The hollow words that have been coming forth in the past few weeks about the concern for the unemployed and for Australian people seem to have a particularly cynical ring about them, when so much of the time of the Parliament has been wasted on issues that have no relevance to the suffering of those people or the insecurity of their futures.

If it is nothing else, my task here as the member for Newcastle will be to ensure that I address myself to the real issues that confront us and avoid the quicksand of flimsy controversy and the trivial political exercises that seem to abound. I trust that these first two weeks will not be an indication of what the future of this Parliament holds. I and so many of my colleagues have come here because we want to help. We want to work at improving the future of Australia and it is with some degree of sadness and even resentment that I find energy being wasted on issues which are not relevant to the problems facing my city and our nation.
