DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Child Care Facilities: Parliament House-Drought Relief-Employment of Women- Department of Health-Australian Broadcasting Commission-Welfare Benefits-Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform

PROCTEXT.PARA: Child Care Facilities: Parliament House-Drought Relief-Employment of Women- Department of Health-Australian Broadcasting Commission-Welfare Benefits-Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform
Motion (by Mr Uren) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday the people of Wannon decided who should represent them in this chamber, and we will all have an opportunity later to congratulate the new member. But I had the distinction of meeting and compaigning with the Australian Labor Party candidate, Mrs Nancy Genardini. She is a person who greatly impressed me with her sincerity, her compassion, her interest in all problems, her commonsense and her intelligence. I worked with her, as did other members, in Stawell, Ararat and other parts of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: My reason for mentioning this outstanding candidate tonight is the fact that had she been elected she would have had a great problem because she has a three- year-old pre-school child. My wife and I also have pre-school children and she discussed with us last week the problems she would have faced had she been elected to this chamber because there are no child-minding facilities in this area. Her husband and she have other children and he could not have run a farm and looked after a three-year-old child at the same time. She explained to me that on a parliamentary salary she could not have afforded to employ a housekeeper. I told her that she would have only four occasions on which she could bring her child to Canberra if she wanted it minded here.

TALK.START.PARA: —On three occasions.

—I am reminded by the honourable member for Grayndler that she could have brought her child here on only three occasions. She also said that she could not afford the fare for the child to come to Canberra with her. I raise this matter tonight because I am told that to date no provision has been made in the new Parliament House for child minding facilities. If anyone here tonight has a pre-school child he or she will know that it is extremely onerous and very trying for one to try to look after one's children while one's family is visiting.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members know that the Magna Carta, one of our basic constitutional documents, guarantees that admission to parliament shall be free. It is a rather quaint expression but it means that no citizen will be hindered in his entry to parliament. I am raising this matter tonight because I believe that entry to parliament is not free for a candidate who has responsibility for pre-school children. We have to take cognisance of this fact and look at this problem as I looked at the problem in discussions with this candidate last week when she was confronted with the prospect of being elected to the national Parliament and then having to try to sort out her difficulty concerning her baby. I am very sympathetic and concerned about this matter. I am raising it tonight because more and more new candidates are being elected to the House. It is not only a problem for women but also for male candidates who are widowers or single parents. I trust that as the new committees get under way and we revive the committee for the planning of the new Parliament House action will be taken to ensure that some form of child minding assistance is made available to members in the new edifice rising on Capital Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I take this opportunity, as it is the first occasion on which I have spoken since your election, to congratulate you on your appointment to the high office of Speaker of this House. It is certainly an appointment that I wholeheartedly supported.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter I want to raise tonight is the serious concern I have about the time it is taking to process drought relief payments, especially the interest subsidy . As is the normal thing to do on occasions such as this, I advised the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) that I would raise this matter but unfortunately I understand that as a result of his returning from Europe today he is not able to be here tonight. A number of farmers and farm advisers have approached me regarding the lengthy delays between the date of lodgment of applications and the date of payment. Clearly, as a result of the drought many farmers have had no income for a long time and some have had to borrow extensively to meet their day to day living requirements. In addition, following the recent rains, they need funds to be able to re-stock and to get back into production. Grain growers need funds for fuel, fertiliser and seed. Their position has been seriously aggravated by the lengthy delays they are facing due to the hold-ups in the processing of these applications. The Department of Primary Industry has been very helpful to me in cases which I have raised with it, but it appears that it is just not able to deal speedily with the number of applications it has on hand . I understand that the Minister may like to give us some information at a later date, but the figures I have show that some 3,000 to 4,500 farmers are awaiting payment. Of course, each farmer may have made more than one claim. In fact, I have heard that up to 30,000 claims are outstanding. I am not absolutely sure of those figures. I have received them second hand. I would welcome the Minister's verification or otherwise of those figures.

Recently I was approached by a person who was assisting farmers in cases concerning the interest subsidy. Amongst those cases with which he is acquainted , four months is the fastest time in which an application has been processed. I therefore ask the Minister-I welcome him back to Australia-to take the appropriate steps to ensure that all these cases are dealt with before the end of this financial year. Clearly there is an urgent need to get this money to the farmers now. Some concern has been expressed that by delaying payments to farmers the Government has been able to fund the extra $260m it has spent this week on other projects such as the Australian National Line, Qantas Airways Ltd and Trans Australia Airlines. I trust that the Government will not use this delaying tactic as yet another means in inflating next year's Budget deficit whilst blaming the Opposition, because it will not wash. Finally, I urge the Minister for Primary Industry to take action to speed up immediately the processing of drought relief payments, especially the interest subsidy, in order to help farmers recover from the disastrous drought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seeking to govern in these difficult times is an awesome responsibility and one which the Australian Labor Party does not take lightly. Now, more than ever, we must recognise that our most important resource is the human one and that women comprise half our population. We must ensure that they are able to contribute skills and talents to their fullest extent. During the early 1970s women in Australia experienced a sharp rise in their expectations for education, employment and equality in the many facets of private and public life. Unfortunately, many of these hopes have been disappointed by the deepening economic recession. Thanks to the short-sighted policies of the former Liberal Government, Australians face a bleak prospect in the 1980s. In its blind pursuit of the goal of lowering inflation it attempted to implement policies which are out of touch with the social and economic realities of the twentieth century and which are totally out of touch with the needs of the people. Now after 7 years of severe economic restraint the burden falls heavily on the unemployed and the disadvantaged in our community. It is a measure of the deep-seated inequality in our society that the largest disadvantaged group among the unemployed comprises women. This represents an unacceptable loss of talent, creativity and skill to the community at a time when these assets are needed more than ever.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the post-war period, unemployment figures for women have been consistently higher than those for men. For young women the situation is now serious and it can be expected to worsen as schools continue to stream girls into subjects which prepare them for a narrow range of jobs, many of which are disappearing. Education plays a huge role in guiding and determining women's career options. In June 1982 women comprised 61.2 per cent of all social security pensioners and beneficiaries. Over 95 per cent of those on supporting parents' benefits are women. The total picture these figures represent is what some analysts have referred to as the feminisation of poverty. Lone parents, the overwhelming majority of whom are women, are in an especially difficult position and face an enormous climb to pull themselves and their families out of the poverty trap.

More and more women are taking on the role of breadwinner for their families. Women in this position are in a double bind. The strains of lone parenting often make paid work less feasible than for a two-parent family but paid work may be their only escape from poverty. Few of them, however, have the necessary resources to get off welfare and very often the harder they try, the more they are disadvantaged. We need to broaden the number of services available in the community so that people in the no-man's land between total dependence and independence are not penalised for taking the first step to self-reliance. We need to create opportunities for employment, with special emphasis on employment for women. We need also to change our education system so that girls do not have their perceptions tailored by the education system into predictable narrow streams and their horizons and expectations restricted.

Our pattern of life is changing very rapidly, and the idea of the male being the sole breadwinner of the nuclear family and the woman being the exclusive home-maker is very much under challenge. More and more women are both the head of the family and the breadwinner. We no longer have just the standard family unit. We also have the dual worker family, the no-worker family and the one- parent family and the reconstituted or blended family. These diverse family units all face different problems. In the single-parent family, though free from any marital conflict, there are the problems of an absent father, the problem of economic survival and the decision on whether to try working or to exist in poverty on welfare. Australian women deserve better than this.

The gains women made in the early 1970s towards their own advancement have been seriously undermined by the neglect of the previous Government. The economic strategies pursued by the Liberal Government have led directly to high rates of unemployment especially among women. Unemployment leads to poverty and waste of human talent. It fosters anxiety, powerlessness and dependency, and the cost to our country in this loss of human potential is incalculable. I make a special plea tonight to our Government on behalf of the thousands of unemployed women: When job creation is discussed, let us give special attention to the girls and the women in our community who want to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I rise to inform honourable members of the high -handed and unaccountable behaviour of the Department of Health-though that is probably an inappropriate name, if ever there was one. Perhaps I should try to start again. I am talking about the high-handed and unaccountable behaviour of the Department of Medical Interference, particularly in the way it seeks to dictate which doctors may prescribe what treatment to which patients. Tonight's theme is total parenteral nutrition. Broadly, I understand this to mean feeding a patient intravenously when for some reason the digestive tract is out of commission. An example would be after major intestinal surgery. In April 1980, a decision of the Department, in effect, made total parenteral nutrition unavailable outside government hospitals. Doctors whose patients would be adversely affected by this decision objected to it, naturally, and later that year it was agreed that it should be reviewed. Two and a half years later the outcome of that review has not been made known.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go any further, it is necessary to explain, in accordance with my limited knowledge of the subject, a little more about total parenteral nutrition . Anyone who has been in hospital or who has watched M.A.S.H. or The Young Doctors-I confess that I have not-will know that fluids of one kind or another are very commonly given to surgical patients by intravenous drip. The usual fluids contain water, chemicals to maintain the electrolytic balance of the body fluids, and often glucose-I suppose that is a sort of intravenous Staminade. They do not contain other substances, such as fats, proteins and amino acids, for instance, that the body needs to maintain and heal itself. Ordinarily this does not matter because the average person has enough reserves of these things in his or her body tissues to last a few days, without any ill effect. But if the patient is malnourished or intravenous feeding has to be maintained for long , some of these substances must be supplied intravenously.

The decision that I mentioned by the Department of Medical Interference in 1980 was to remove intravenous preparations of amino acids from the schedule of pharmaceutical benefits. The reason given by the then Minister for Health was:

As hospitals other than public hospitals frequently do not have appropriate facilities and staff to provide and monitor such therapy, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee recommended that preparations which provide amino acids for parenteral nutrition should no longer be listed as pharmaceutical benefits.

This is remarkable reasoning, even by the Department's standards. Because many non-government hospitals do not have the facilities to provide this treatment properly even those with qualified staff and equipment are to be prevented from doing so. Using the same logic, since a proportion of government hospitals also do not have these facilities no government hospitals should be able to provide the treatment. Mr Speaker, we might as well say that because kidney transplants cannot be done at the woop woop regional hospital they should not be done anywhere. That situation is absurd. I know of two doctors in Perth who each work in the intensive care units of two major hospitals; they work half time in each. One is a government hospital, the other is not. In the government hospital they can prescribe and supervise total parenteral nutrition but once they enter the modern and well-equipped non-government hospital two miles away the Department says that they are no longer competent to do so. I am making two distinct complaints against the Department this evening. My first complaint is that it made an arbitrary decision based on fallacious reasoning. Secondly, it is taking a scandalously long time to review that decision. I recognise that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is new to the position and that he may be able to get on top of the situation very early in his career. I will draw this matter again to the attention of the Minister and I will ask him to act immediately on both the complaints I have made this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yet again the Australian Broadcasting Commission has shown its contempt for affairs in remote areas. Last Saturday it axed the Winners program without prior notice. I understand that the explanation being given by the Commission is that that program is not rating well down south . One might ask why the national television service is concerned about ratings in Sydney and Melbourne. After all, the people of Sydney and Melbourne have a choice. They have three of four channels at their disposal. In the Northern Territory there is no choice. One can watch either the ABC or nothing. The report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission was completed some two years ago. The Dix Committee got the message loud and clear about the feeling of outback people on television coverage of sporting events. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of televised coverage of sporting events, exclusive rights to which have been secured by commercial television stations, was never far below the surface of any of our outback hearings. It was a question raised by institutions as well as individuals. We were informed of resolutions on the matter by associations such as the Graziers' Association of Central and Northern Queensland . . . . In Port Hedland one citizen had organised a petition of 16 000 people in the Pilbara about the lack of the cricket and such events as the Melbourne Cup on ABC television, and had travelled to Sydney to pursue the question with the ABC . . .
Sporting telecasts emerged as a talisman for feeling, amounting almost to resentment, in rural areas against the ABC's effective television 'monopoly' in many areas of outback Australia.

One would have thought that by now the ABC would have got the message, but it seems not. This is the second assault the ABC has made on sporting coverage of remote areas in recent months. The rugby league coverage of Sydney and Brisbane events was axed this year. It is possible for the ABC to use its subsidiary rights even though the rugby league coverage rights are held by commercial stations. It is possible to use those subsidiary rights and to televise the rugby league in remote areas originating from Darwin, Townsville or other places such as that. But it does not do that. It is about time that the elitist and arrogant people in the ABC, from the Chairman down, woke up to the fact that there is a growing and deep resentment in Australia over this issue.

The second issue I should like to mention briefly tonight is a statement made by Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, about the Commonwealth Government's subsidy for the Darwin Shipping Service. He said that this subsidy was to be axed by this Government. That is incorrect and the Chief Minister knows that it is incorrect. In other words, he has deliberately misled the people in the Northern Territory about the true position. The true position, and the Chief Minister knows this, is that the Federal Minister for Transport ( Mr Peter Morris) is still waiting for a proposal that he invited from the Northern Territory Government on the future of that service. The true position is-and Mr Everingham knows it-that the subsidy is due to expire in any case on 30 June. That was a decision made by the previous Government. The true position is that the Northern Territory Government originally agreed to accept responsibility for the service after 30 June. I sincerely hope that the Chief Minister is more careful with the truth in future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to call the attention of the Parliament to some of the problems that surface in our welfare area. I do not do this to criticise the general concept of welfare or assisting the needy but I do believe that there are sectors of it to which we must address ourselves. I sincerely hope that the new Government, while attending to these particular problems, will look at some of the abuses when considering the assistance it would like to give in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Just recently a constituent of mine brought to my attention the case of a worker who promised two weeks hard work in return for dismissal. That is rather incongruous. My constituent is a farmer. He had a wheat crop to take off and he badly wanted labour to assist him in the task. He approached the Commonwealth Employment Service, and it sent him a man. He installed this man at his property , complete with family, at a wage of $200 per week, all found. The person concerned commenced work and he appeared to be a good worker. But then he became inconsistent. He started not to appear for work. The farmer was pretty concerned but he decided that the devil he knew was probably better than the devil he did not know and he wanted to continue to employ this fellow. He was eventually confronted by this individual, who said: 'I have done all these things wrong. Why haven't you dismissed me?' The farmer replied: 'I want to get my crop in. Why do you want dismissal?' His employee said: 'I have calculated that I am working for $25 per week. I would be much better off back on unemployment relief but I cannot get that immediately if you do not dismiss me'. The result was that the farmer and he had a good chat. They decided that probably the bulk of the crop could be taken off in two weeks and, if the gentleman concerned was prepared to work hard enough, at the end of the two weeks he would be dismissed. Who can we blame for that? We cannot blame the farmer; we must look at the system. We must address ourselves to a system which in many circumstances makes it as profitable not to work as it does to work. My Government did attempt to overcome that problem by introducing the $10 per week child support for low income earners.

The other case I want to speak about is one which I know my Government was looking at. It has to do with the very worthwhile exercise of giving financial support to supporting parents. I heard a remarkable story of a European lass who was living in a de facto relationship with a European. Neither of them was an Australian. Another European lass appeared on the scene and the consequence was that, possibly to protect herself, the lass with the de facto relationship became pregnant. What she did not know was that the visiting girl also became pregnant. Both were pregnant to the same de facto husband.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to confess to being the father.

—No, I did not think you would. This is a true story. It raises an interesting issue. The outcome of this was that the fellow concerned, I am told, found a simple solution; he bolted. Two children were to be born, one of whom eventually was born in Australia and the other in a European country. The interesting fact is, so I am told, that the one born in Australia is now a burden on the Australian taxpayer but by an interesting arrangement the European country has managed to find this gentleman and make him pay support for the child for whom he is responsible and who is in that European country. It seems remarkable to me that good family people in Australia who are meeting their commitments on a daily basis are required to take on the responsibility of someone else's child when in fact there are probably financial resources available-the fellow is employed-to look after the child. It is time that the situation was considered. There is no such thing as a single parent. To my knowledge, it still takes two to conceive a child and as such the burden must stay.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: — Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sorry, Mr Speaker. I am so used to talking in the adjournment debate to the Deputy Speaker . I am very pleased that you have placed sufficient importance on this debate, which is one of the few chances private members still have to raise matters of importance in the Parliament. I hope that you will give sufficient importance on this debate to ensure that when the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings Committee looks at broadcasting the adjournment debate you will place your power and authority behind having the debate broadcast on the nights when the House of Representatives is normally broadcast.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise tonight to support the remarks of the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher). Earlier in this debate, he quite properly raised the plight of members of this House, and indeed the Senate, who have young children. In the past, most members of this House and the Senate did not have young children. People tended to enter the Parliament of Australia in the latter years of their careers and their children were either teenagers or grown up. In recent years we have seen a marked change in the average age of members of this House, in particular, and we have seen an influx as members of this Parliament of people who have young children. It is high time that this House and the Senate took cognisance of that fact and started to change some of the rather outmoded responses to these problems that we have adopted today.

It is rather interesting that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) arranged to have facilities made available in this House for members' wives. However, there are no facilities for members' children. There are no facilities for members who wish their children to partake in their parliamentary life. It is probably quite possible for wives of members who do not have young children to take part in the life that they play as a member of parliament. My wife and the wives of a number of other members around my age cannot avail themselves of that opportunity because they have young children who live in the cities which those members represent in Parliament. In my view, it is high time that many of these things were changed.

For instance, I find it rather condescending that, when members' children come to Canberra on the three trips that they are allowed per annum, they have to fly economy class but members and members' wives fly first class. I do not think children are second class citizens. I find it fascinating that the Parliament and the Remuneration Tribunal consider that they are. Maybe that is because the Remuneration Tribunal is made up of old men. Maybe it is high time that the Government had a look at putting someone on the Remuneration Tribunal who knows about or remembers the problems of having a young family. I wonder what the new honourable members from Western Australia, for instance, who all have young families, will do when they commute to this city with their young children, as it is so far away. I find it rather obnoxious that there are no child care facilities in the House.

I spoke to the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) this week. She is a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, as I am. She will be taking the matter up at the next meeting of that Committee, which I understand will be held next Monday, to look at whether those facilities will be available in the new Parliament House. I think it is high time that we looked not only at providing those facilities for members but also for those people who work in this House, whose lives are interrupted because of the late hours this House works. I think this House should accept that the future of Australia lies with the children of Australia. There is no reason why, for too long, this Parliament has considered the children of members and of the staff are second rate citizens. I hope, Mr Speaker, you will add your weight to the movement which will be demanding that these facilities be made available in the new Parliament House which we are building not far from here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks tonight to the matter of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that will be looking at certain things. While I know that there are many matters of greater moment than what I might discuss here, I hope that the Committee will have a close look at some of these aspects. The first matter I want to mention is the 8 p.m. close of the polls on Saturday night. In most of the State electorates, and certainly in local government elections, the polls close at 6 o'clock. I fail to see why this extra two hours is required if the States and local governments can get their elections through by 6 o'clock. I think the extra two hours are a waste of time, particularly when we have daylight saving when some elections have been held so that we have the two extra hours and then an hour on top of them. It is not so much a matter of that. I do have certain feelings about daylight saving. For instance, in Canberra I can well see that the extra hour of daylight that one gets in the summer is not unreasonable when compared with areas closer to the Equator. But, as far as I am concerned, Queensland's attitude to daylight saving is legitimate, and I think the situation in the south is just as legitimate for other reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect to which I want to draw attention is that some States have a separate roll for State and local government elections, when compared with the Federal roll. I believe, particularly in Queensland, it is time we combined the electoral rolls, not because I think the Federal roll is any more significant than the State roll, but I have received complaints right up to election date from people whose names appear on one roll and not the other. Inevitably, the Federal roll has been correct and the absentee voters are those who look to the State rolls. I believe it is time that the Attorney-General in Queensland is prevailed upon to bring the two rolls into one. I understand that the situation in Western Australia was that there were two rolls but now the Western Australian Government is to make one roll. I believe also that in every other State of Australia we operate off the one roll. It is not only common sense but also economically sensible and legitimate to use the Australian Electoral Office 's roll.

One other matter with which I have some concern is the manner in which electorates are divided into subdivisions. My own electorate has eleven. I believe some others would have more. At present a person voting outside his subdivision is regarded as an absentee voter and his vote is not counted until some time in the week following the election. There should be a better indication on the night of the election of what the results might be. Surely absentee votes in a subdivision could be counted as ordinary votes delivered on the day and counted on the night. We would certainly have a better indication of the situation before the day was over. The other aspect is one in which I believe Queensland failed prior to the last election. There should have been a redistribution of the Federal seats. I draw attention to the fact that three rural seats in Queensland have a greater electoral number than some of the Brisbane seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order it being 11 o'clock the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 2.15 p.m. on Tuesday next.
